headline: I had a very good and pleasant experience working with the company
pros: My boss was very helpful and accommodating. The company also have a good work-life balance where time is given for family activities if only it does not affect productivity. Special considerations are given for emergencies
cons: there was limited personal growth

headline: Great Place to Work
pros: Great culture and place to work
cons: It can be a bit of an old boys club

headline: Very poor management.
pros:
- employee benefits I.e Discounts 
- Work colleagues
cons:
- poor management
- Bureaucracy leading to miscommunication 
- Poor hourly rate
- Americanisation of the company and its policies.

headline: Small cog in large corporate machine
pros: Working at Head Office offers free parking (if you're willing to get up at the crack of dawn to get to the office by 8am otherwise you'll have to pay!) There's also a subsidised canteen (it's a running joke most Head Office colleagues put on 1stone in the 1st year). There are also some nice people to work with (note: these are generally NOT the senior managers. If senior managers *are* nice to you, it's probably because they're trying to show that they're "good manager material" to their own line manager, in order to get a promotion.
cons: If you're not a senior manager (B grade or above), be prepared to work long hours for lower than market rate pay. Be under no illusion, you are just a very small cog in a very large (green) machine, and as such, easily dispensed with. You will be expected to show the *right* "behaviours", which basically means that senior management want you to "behave" (ie; they don't want the 'worker bees' causing a nuisance and taking up time / energy / money to 'sort out'). If you're wiling to be a well behaved drone, then you will go far. Be prepared to work in a niche job with no prospect of promotion (unless you fully embrace the "happy clappy" world of back-slapping). If you're trained in any specialist area, don't expect to be acknowledged or rewarded for it - any contribution over and above your designated job function will be frowned upon. Generalists are appreciated - Specialists are to be quashed. Box ticking is the name of the game if you want to succeed. (And no, I wasn't 'let go' - I just saw through the cracks, and have moved on to a better / better paid job!)

headline: It was a good seasonal job during uni, but I was definitely just a number and not a valued member of the team.
pros: The times flies very quickly during shifts. You are often working with the same people every week so can build up friendships.
cons: Due to the large staff numbers, management did not know anybody's name even after working there for over 3 months. Very difficult to find someone to ask for time off etc.

headline: Typical supermarket
pros: 10% discount, local to me
cons: Cutting hours to save money added pressure to team

headline: Overall good place to work if you are looking for part-time work.
pros:
- Good wage for simple work especially during your studies. 
- Great opportunity to enhance work experience and skill-set. 
- Assisting and speaking to customers everyday was always insightful and unpredictable for good reasons. 
- Using own personal intuition to complete tasks.
cons:
- Under appreciated. 
- Management ignore good work and don't commend. 
- Management had their 'favourite' staff members. 
- Management at times would disappear for hours on end, only to be found sitting in the canteen with their fellow managers. 
- Management and section leaders would sometimes come across as very unprofessional especially when discussing other colleagues. 
- Management would also ignore what workers suggested or requested, for example: holiday leave or departmental transfers.
- Have to be very thorough when noting pay and hours and very wary of management in general, the management and office workers were not very trustworthy or reliable. 
- Technology was very outdated and certified safe equipment was always scarce. 
- It was clear that to work well with the management and the section leaders you had to basically give in to every command they ordered without question. 
- Anyone who was "different" or "didn't work as hard" as the management or section leaders was usually spoken about in a very negative manner.
- Hypocrisy and inconsistency were rife within the business.  
- Managers acted as if they were untouchable and were not responsible for any action they took. They were very good at passing the blame.
- Certain procedures just add complication to the working environment. 
- Management were always pushing for workers to work overtime, even when the answer was a categorical no. 
- Always felt that management and section leaders were very judgemental and that there was a hidden motive.  
- Very sloppy at making sure workers are 100% satisfied and happy, it took over two years to realise that someone had not actually been properly trained.

headline: Checkout worker
pros: The work is flexible, with shift swaps and overtime regularly available. Section leaders normally friendly and helpful.
cons: Check out work is extremely mundane. Breaks are pretty poor and unpaid. 7 hour shift with a half hour break. Trapped at a checkout for up to 4 hours at a time.

headline: Expect you to be available at all times.
pros: 10% discount (honestly, no pro's).
cons: Differing pay rates...you get nowhere unless related to another asda employee.

headline: Mostly good, some drawbacks
pros: Good colleague support - I work on the checkout, and learnt far more from colleagues than from very brief, and in my opinion, inadequate "training". Section leaders usually friendly and communicative, and try to be supportive. Job can be interesting as every new customer has different needs and expectations, which greatly alleviates the tedium of the repetitious aspect.
cons:
Low pay,  management's focusing on trivia like colour of nail polish to be worn, when daily customers are complaining about length of checkout queues, too many missing items on shelves and not enough checkouts open. Could do with listening more to what customers actually expect from shopping at Asda, and making it easier for them to express opinions, suggestions etc.
Also at present very understaffed - especially on selfscan/hybrids - making it potentially easier for theft to go undetected. Inadequate security. Some checkouts too narrow for larger pushchairs, customers with disabilities etc. Being spoken to and treated like children (I don't see the "respect for the individual" much in evidence here)- patronising "training" videos.

headline: Exhausting
pros: 10% discount that's really it
cons:
Lazy workers
Too much work given to one department 
Managers expect far too much

headline: It's OK.
pros: Friendly employees. Pays the bills.
cons: Customers. Poor training. Bad contract.

headline: Shocking
pros: Discount card annual leave and colleagues
cons: Stupid managers who don't know how to run a department

headline: Poor Leadership
pros: Fast paced and competitive environment with a previously great leadership model and beliefs.
cons: Culture now changing into a Tell and Do environment rather than a Challenge and Involve team working ethic. I saw these changes taking place from 2010 to 2013. Where ASDA previously adopted a Servant Leadership Style within its Senior Team, getting things done with and through others WILLINGLY and WELL to now just GET IT DONE! Wages and productivity are continuously being squeezed and challenged to reduce prices, meaning more volume is being pumped into the shops with fewer hours to deliver a standards.

headline: Great for university flexibility, at a store level probably not a career
pros:
The best part of the job is definitely the other colleagues, especially when you're not on checkouts.

The ability to progress and develop through opportunities without being a section leader. Colleagues can become part of the recruitment squad and other opportunities which is something different and spices work up a bit.

Being verbally and physically rewarded if you do a good job.

10% Asda & Wal-mart discount.

Supportive leadership, especially with applying for the grad scheme.

Flexibility with hours if in education, ability to move stores for summer and Christmas breaks.
cons:
The colleague experience differs a lot from store to store, due to different management and different parts of people policies being enforced.

Technology is lacking. Everything is second hand from Wal-Mart and it doesn't feel like there's any investment in trying to make colleagues jobs easier. If DVDs and CDs were tagged automatically at the depot then it'd enable MVG colleagues to focus on refill than tagging for hours on end.

No way to search for stock/location, there are 400+ DVDs out in the charts alone - you can't answer customer enquiries efficiently. Location changes on telxons a few days before modular implementation so restocking can become hard.

The photo kiosks take up a lot of colleague time, customers don't get the software. In my store the MVG and Photo Centre is joined so one colleague is doing what two colleagues would in another store.

For retail the wage is quite high, but this wouldn't be an option for me after uni as it can't support you properly.

The ability to print POS and Swap Sleeves at a store level would be amazing. The technology is there.

headline: Amazing place to work
pros:
Very Supportive Management at Spondon Branch
Polite Staff
cons: Management should give growth opportunities to employees at a lower level

headline: Asda chepstow distribution..modern day slave labour
pros: Good wage,and home time good staff saving scheme
cons: Excessive pick rate which is ok if u under 30 ,the union which u pay ya subs to then realise they dont do nothing for u

headline: Excellent
pros: Staff, Flexibility, Customers, Satisfying, Enjoyable
cons: Management, Store Practice, Customers, Staff

location: Warrington, North West England, England, England
headline: Good if you are just looking for part time work
pros:
10% Discount
Double Discount events
Flexable for hours
Friendly collegues
Wage

Your average supermarket bonuses
cons:
Along with the pro's some of the senior management can be very rude and very unprofessional. There is no real communication between management and your average colleagues. This is potentially down to some in the higher positions being disassociated from your average colleague. It's understandable that they are subjected to preassures from people in higher positions again but they does not warrent the behavour that i've witnessed for example. 

Before therestructure there was blatant bullying from department management, there would also be preassure on you to work when you've expressly said you won't. Often this would be ignored and you would be informed you are working and that is the end of it. I have personally been bullied by a previous manager, however no one would openly say anything and I did not feel comfortable taking any action because all the management are friendly with one another and openly discuss everything. I felt it would lead to further bullying. 

In the colleague handbook it is fairly stated that you will be required to work flexably within the store and undertake an array of tasks, which is fine to a degree. However, hours get cut and they give out the minimum amount of hours then when things suffer and management come asking questions, as to why departments are half empty or shelves in disaray they are not satisfied with the response that you are short staffed due to lack of hours and refusal to recruit. As seasons become busier it becomes near impossible to complete work handed to you, as you are expected to undertake large amounts of work that ideally require at least 2 or more colleagues. It can be exhausting. 

I'm unsure if this is the same for all stores now but within the store I work, they are expecting everyone to become till trained to queue bust but this leads to you being stationed on a till for around an hour or more of your shift leading to the department you are also expected to work becoming neglected and work not getting completed which leads to unhappy section leaders/managers.

They seem to recruit relations within the store. Nearly everyone is related to one another across departments. So gossip is a widespread, especially from management. Confidentiality is non-existant. Colleague investigations for example get discussed openly within departments. 

The new restructure changed the order, as in you now have; Colleagues, Section leaders(replacing section managers), main managers then, the store general manager and their Sub general manager. They have eliminated the title of a Section Manager but have given all the duties to the Section Leaders for a fraction of the pay. From general chats with my own current Section Leader they are expected to do a lot of work for hardly for very little extra money. 

Training is quite poor. You get your expected on paper training, watch a lot of training videos. Practical training isn't fantastic, not within my department anyway. I was employed as a Baker, yet when my old manager was in charge, I was expected to persue my own training from the other Bakers, which is fair, I have initiative and would ask but would be met with, ask the manager, or sort it with them. Over a year down the line and it has taken that long for me to be allowed to progress with training, I have become quite set that I will never complete Baker "training" to earn the Bakers wage. Despite working as one for a year, I do not feel I have been paid fairly for the work I have done. You are required to use the "guns" within your job. No training is provided for these though then you're looked at a bit foolishly for not knowing what to do. 

Last but by no means least, it is an extremely thankless job working for ASDA. Equipment also needs serious updates across the stores. Lastly, god forbid you become ill, 12 weeks is all you get, if you're not fit and well by then you can expect to be let go. Their own ocupational health can override your own doctor too from what I understand.

headline: Very enjoyable.
pros: Really look forward to going to work as all of the employees are friendly and I'm kept busy so the time goes quickly.
cons: Having to deal with any difficult customers or when the shop gets busy as you have to try and quicken how you work but still provide excellent customer satisfaction.

headline: Treat you like rubbish!
pros: 10%discount Apart from that absolutely nothing, asda will leave you feeling degraded and undervalued,used and bullied.
cons:
*managment treat you like rubbish
*no flexibility 
*no praise
*clicky managment
*poor management 
*disorganised

headline: Gone down hill fast since the 2014 restructure. My review is based on the Frozen Department.
pros:
I used to love working at Asda and could see myself staying there for some time, but since the 2014 restructure, Asda really has gone down hill fast.

Share save scheme is a good idea with a possible good return on your money.

Benefits like the cycle to work scheme and discounts on days out, attractions, holidays, restaurants etc.

Little bit of an yearly bonus but if you break the bonus down weekly doesn't really mean much as we are on such a poor wage anyway.

Store discount card helps a little.

Really great shop floor colleagues without these guys Asda would really fall to bits, Not sure if store management really value colleagues . . . Its only them that are keeping it going after last years restructure.
cons:
Lack of colleagues on day and night shifts, Too much stock that we don't need coming in from Asda depots despite stock issue and P.I. process, Too much work load for colleagues.

Store itself is falling to bits and not fit for purpose, Store is too small for the growth of Home Shopping which has a knock effect to the rest of the store plus store was never built to take the stock levels and money it takes every week. Health and safety issues in store and tight budget to get things fixed, Closed staff canteen to save money.

Relying on the few colleagues to do overtime to keep the store running and the shelves stocked,

Customers becoming aggressive and more ignorant due to products not on shelves because of colleague shortages, There needs to be some basic rules in supermarkets to protect staff and stock in shops i.e. not eating as you walk around, Dumping fresh food, Shop lifting etc. I know they pay the wages but some people really do take the mick.

More pressure on colleagues. If you don't cover holidays you are left with even more to do on your return from your holiday or day off. No colleagues to cover you as there is no one ( or nobody wants to work in frozen )

Not sure if some managers are up to being mangers, Some can't manage there way out of a wet paper bag. Some store management seem distant and aloof.

So many fellow full time colleagues have left my store, People leave but are not replaced or replaced with part time inexperienced students. Also Asda doesn't like full time colleagues anymore . . . they cost too much !

Better pay structure, Asda as a store has so many diverse departments. Some departments have it easy while some departments have it hard in relation to the work they do with no difference in hourly rate and pay.

I know retail is extremely tough at the moment with the supermarket price wars, But the management in Leeds live on another planet and seem intent on destroying Asda. 

The management restructure of 2014 made the better managers redundant and replaced them with less paid  inexperienced section leaders and was supposed to put more colleagues back on the shop floor which has simply not happened.

Some of the section leaders have stepped down in there roles in my store because of work pressures. There is simply to much work to do and not enough people. 

Maybe there is some kind of master plan to all the extreme cut backs Asda are making. All I have seen is customers shopping elsewhere because of empty shelves as a result of colleague cut backs which equals less money being taken at the checkout as products that customers want to buy are not stocked.

So much fresh store waste being thrown away, Again being created by too much stock coming in and not enough colleagues to put the stock on the shelves . . . Its a real shame seeing good food being thrown away because of being out of date. I will never forget Christmas 2014 by the amount of waste being thrown away some of which never even made it onto the shop floor, Just crazy:-(

I think Asda now is all about % and figures. As long as they balance the store books waste, wages overtime, consumables etc to what the store takes in sales every week nobody really care's:-( All smoke and mirrors and robbing Peter to pay Paul:-( and not about the customer.

Met some great colleagues which I will miss, But have now left Asda and looking forward to the future away from retail.

headline: Avoid this Depot ASDA TEESPORT IC
pros: 10% Discount card but by the way they go on about it and the risks involved with using it you would think it was 90%. I do believe the ASDA ethos is a brilliant thing but its not adhered to at all at Teesport.
cons: Untrained, unprofessional, inexperienced and unapproachable Managers. No Leadership No direction. Managers spend far to long in meetings amounting to nothing other then revolving the same pathetic ideas over and over again. Managers are Teflon coated in that nothing ever sticks to them they constantly bully and discriminate against Colleagues but when investigated by another Manager they get away with it to do it again and again. As a Colleague you go through a process of hearings with these uneducated Managers who treat you in a unprofessional and unfair way normally ending in a final warning or termination of your contract. This is normally then told to everyone else as confidentiality does not exist Managers cant wait to tell colleagues what has happened in a investigation . For such a so called "GREAT" place to work the turn over of staff within Teesport in its 9+  years of been open is huge this in itself speaks volumes as to what sort of place it is. Health and Safety is a total joke it looks good on a paper but so much is covered up and hidden by dishonest Management and a Health and Safety Manager who is only interested in himself and his own career the colleagues mean nothing to him he has made colleagues afraid to report things because of his unprofessional and unfair handling of so many cases. Advice given or suggestions offered to him are just met with a negative and unprofessional response. I strongly believe that ASDA is a great company to work for and has invested a lot of time and money into making it so. Sadly they don't look into how depots are run they don't vet the calibre or quality of Managers who are suppose to practice and preach the ASDA "Values" i can only speak for ASDA Teesport IC i have worked here over 9 years since it opened and watched something that started so brilliantly become the awful place of work it is now.

headline: Positive experience, very slow and limited career progression and at times can be very disorganised but it is a fun job!
pros: A lot of job freedom and have some degree of responsibility, very healthy and happy culture, amazing colleagues and the job itself is surprisingly enjoyable!
cons: Very disorganised, career progression prospects are small with poor pay when compared to competitors, contracts are somewhat unfair for example, I work 20 hours a week yet my contract only says 8, meaning that I get less pay for holidays etc

headline: Personal Shoppper
pros: Once you are up with the pace, it can really really easy to do the work. Early Start, Early finish (rest of the day to do other stuff)
cons: During seasons - Christmas, Can be really stressful

pros: Once you are up with the pace, it can really really easy to do the work. Early Start, Early finish (rest of the day to do other stuff)
cons: During seasons - Christmas, Can be really stressful

headline: community Life Champion
pros:
Loved the job.

headline: Average stop gap job
pros:
Pay is okay
Work with great people, if it wasn't for the people I wouldn't still be there
Management are ok, some are easy to get along with but prone to power trips
Shifts go in very quickly
Lots of overtime 
Very flexible
Can get a shift covered when you need it most of the time
cons:
Lack of communication from management

People on back shift don't get included as much as people that work day shift

Queue busting and q clarity is a stupid concept, I feel as if I'm getting into trouble whenever I get called to queue bust, if I go I'm letting my department down and section leaders are often angry at the fact I get left on a checkout for 1hr+ but if I don't go then it's unfair to checkouts as I am down as queue buster and it means those that do go to queue bust are kept on for longer than they need to be - it is a no win either way, if I go or if I don't someone isn't happy, I'm confused even though I'm just doing my job.

Lack of training on checkouts, as I'm a queue buster I'm often left to figure out how to handle situations myself and kind of figure out things as I go along, I've been working in asda for 8 months and queue bust frequently and have only just figured out how to do a top up on checkouts ??!!! 

I work in grocery and still haven't been trained on how to use the guns, I know how to do basic things like check the price and print out a tag etc but have never received the training even though I have asked numerous times

You don't get trained enough in asda you are just left to pick things up as you go along

headline: Cashier at Asda
pros: Money was good compared to similar jobs. You were paid for the exact number of minutes you were there - if you got caught up and clocked out fifteen minutes late, they would add that, unlike many other places I have worked. Staff facilities were good. Rules about lunch breaks, holidays etc were generally followed.
cons: Management never backed up the staff if it didn't suit them. Manager made me sell a woman Paracetemol over the legally accepted amount - I was told initially this was a fireable offence but then treated like a jobsworth when I tried to enforce it. If someone didn't turn up to relieve you, you were expected to wait until they said so, even if that meant staying an hour after your shift ended.  Rules changed depending on who it suited. Again told that I must never, ever leave the till unattended - when I called a runner to fetch a replacement for a customer (something which is a huge part of their job...) I was told to stop being lazy and go get it myself, leaving till unattended for a few minutes, only to be told off by a 2nd runner on my way back for leaving. Management were also extremely clique-y and the environment was very toxic. Food hygiene rules utterly ignored - a pack of raw meat burst on my till, spilling meat juices everywhere, but once I'd cleared up the obvious evidence on the belt, I asked to wash my hands and they said not to bother, and if I was going to be really that fussy I could spray my hands with the industrial disinfectant. Training almost non-existent - shown the very basics for five minutes then made to work on a busy shift immediately. Overall the unhappiest I have ever been in a job.

headline: checkout operator
pros: share save and  10% discount  on my shopping are two reasons I work for asda. I have hours that suit my lifestyle that I probably would not be able to get in another job. cons: the overtime is a big problem it seems to be given to same colleagues every week they are working up to 50 hours and some of us only have contracts for few hours and have to fight for overtime and the ones that get all the overtime never seem to go on checkouts even though that's what they are supposed to be working overtime for

I've been working for them for 12 months and I put all my effort into the job but never gets noticed. we do have a ASDA star thing where good work is rewarded but countless times I've come out ontop of those nominated and never have I been rewarded so don't get your hopes up when your work colleagues get nominated and you don't even if you both are good

headline: Squeezing Out the Fun
pros:
Best bunch of people I have ever worked with (colleagues, not managers)
Flexible so perfect for students, parents, semi-retired people
cons:
The whole supermarket industry in the UK is in real trouble, particularly the 'big 4'. People shop based on either brand loyalty or based on price. No one is going to pay a premium to be loyal to ASDA so they are (correctly) trying to cut the prices, although not as effectively as Aldi and Lidl. The upshot of this is that they have been putting more work on less staff to cut costs. Layers of management have been laid off and replaced by 'section leaders' - people doing the same job for half the money.

Asda was once a fun place to work and there are still many good people there but don't expect to be paid fairly to reflect your increased role.

cons: Walmart always has challenges to best service sometimes but as a team and sharing ideas we can come up with new ideas and ways for all.

location: Farnworth, Greater Manchester, North West England, England, England
headline: Current shop floor
pros:
Wages are on time.
The only thing  I can put because I have to use to use twenty words minimum to put this.
cons:
Lazy management with strong blame culture.

A lot of young students work here. Managers see this as a "dating platform". "Dating" being a loose term.

Low staff retention means section leaders try to run departments with little training. They get blamed = So do you.

 The Social media policy is damage control. Can be fired for any negative "talk" of the company.

Booking holidays needs 2 weeks notice. Holidays have been denied the day before requested date. Constantly.

Can't progress past section leader unless you're "friends" with a higher up.

Hard to get a full time contract.

Passed an inspection by regional whilst dealing with an infestation.(they must have forgot this from the store to the car park)

The store is spotless when we have a visit on(the parts you can see, anyway). Yet not the rest of the time.

Waste gets thrown in the compactor without being reported to keep numbers down.

Chilled goods don't follow the 20 min rule. Can be left out for 45 to an hour.

Staff coming in drunk/hungover due to inflexible hours/holiday requests denied

headline: Abysmal management, treat staff unfairly, do not value customers
pros:
Good work once trained if your left to your job
Work with some fantastic people across multiple backgrounds
cons:
Steal holiday pay if your holidays are not put in
Stuck working both weekend days the past 2 years with them 'looking for a replacement'. 
Written warnings for doing things as managers do although they don't get disciplined. 
Written warning for less than a week off over a year although stores absence rate is much higher than my own. 
Changing your shift pattern without contract change, then 9 months later telling you to go back to your contract hours regardless of how that would affect you
Breaching daily rest rule on contracts
Massive lack of staff but forcing more experienced colleagues out of the door.
Telling you that you cannot have specific holidays as they have no cover, yet when anyone goes on holiday they have no cover,
Be given multiple peoples jobs to do including you own.(e.g. work your racking and process it, then take dates off another department, then do markdowns, then work delivery)
Being asked to tidy the shelves when the racking has not been worked all day.
Not allowed to talk to other colleagues on department even if working.

Please note that the recent restructure made the majority of managers redundant (some with over 20 years service at the company) and the ones kept now have to cover sections of the shop instead of single departments

The company handled the whole process terribly,and even after over 10 years at the company, where I had some good times, after the way they treated me, I would not recommend working at ASDA to anyone.
Maybe this is why they are doing so badly at the moment!

I've witnessed them selling out of date meat to families to try and beat waste budgets, although couldn't say anything because they have a social media policy in which you are fired for slandering them in any such way.
I was not long ago told that I can be spoken to like rubbish because I'm a colleague but must treat managers with the upright respect (by a manager of course).

Team leaders are trying their best! You just cant beat the amount of effort staff will put in. Great xmas parties, buffets regularly put on for different reasons well in with the community having regular community activity events or coffee mornings. Plenty charity events happening. When working well its a great atmosphere. 10% discount is quite good n the occasional colleague discount days they have where we get more didvount is even better.. great breakfast served from the canteen  (always look forward to that)
cons:
1)Hours kept a minimum yet work requires more...
 2)Told we have to take holidays when they want so they can save hours to fit in with the restrictions on hours.. 
3)When a staff member is ill or on holiday it is rare that they will cover them so other already stretched staff are expected to take on yet more work.
4)With hours restricted, the little staff that are on have to prioritise jobs resulting in other jobs getting missed such as racking of over stock which then lead to stock going out of date in the back and later being wasted., restricted hours also lead to us rushing our jobs and date checks on shelves is not thorough leading to out of date stock still on shelves which customers have been known to point out to me and my collegues leading to embarrassment for us and asda, it also leads to  high waste which then leads to staff being lectured on waste volume but it is the structure they have on hours that causes this and they have their selves to blame no one else!! Yet they dont seem to blame them selves..
5)Hours restricted and jobs not getting done properly or not at all, leads to empty places on shelves resulting in customers commenting to us about it and again resulting in embarrassment for us and asda. 
6)already stretched on our own departments when queue busting is called we MUST go and work on a till wether we are busy or not (we are always busy) they have bern known to take me and the only other colleague on my department to queue bust leaving our department without a staff member for sometime.
7)Our rushed manner results in us rushing to take customers to products and not giving the full expected customer service that asda insist on and we are being tested on this via secret shoppers it is easy to fail given the amount of work we have and our rushed manner. This is not a fare test
8)better turn over leads to more hours but the restrictions on hours leads to poor turnover which then leads to restrictions in hours!! = we just cant win
9) when we are getting supposed surprise visit from the area manager, we know they are coming because other stores phone and warn us. Suddenly they are able to phone staff and ask them to come in and dish out a load of hours, all work is done as should be because there is enough staff! ...The store doesnt really work like that!!  But this proves it can if the right amount of staff is on
10) staff have been known to clock out and continue to work just to complete jobs they don't want to leave half done purely coz they dont want to let the team down.
In short the hour structure is causing more harm than good and is terrible!

headline: Graduate Retail Manager
pros: The people at ASDA are by far the biggest pro and each of the 6 stores I have worked in take the concept "team" very seriously. There is also ample opportunity for coaching from experienced members of management around any area of the job.
cons: Training is diabolical - very much a ticky box exercise. On the graduate scheme there is little to no opportunity to shape your own path - your roles, the duration you hold them for and their location are very much dictated to you by the regional teams. This only worsens after you have completed the scheme. Post re-structure, there is even less opportunity for advancement and competition is even more fierce for any step up - you really have to ingratiate yourself with the right people. Saddest of all is seeing the atmosphere drain out of our stores since the re-structure in 2014, particularly in the Section Leader and colleague populations - I hope the company find their way again soon for the colleagues' sake.

headline: Lost it's appeal in the last couple of years
pros: People, supportive environment, had a strong culture that needs to come back. "If we work together, we will lower the cost of living for everyone and give the world an opportunity to see what it's like to save, and have a better life." I believed in that noble cause.
cons: Too many cut backs & head count reductions. Fewer people having to run faster in order to stand still. Disillusioned & disenfranchised middle/senior management.

headline: Great student job/part time work
pros: Discount is available, pleasant atmosphere, always something to be getting on with, pay is reasonable.
cons: Shifts can be unsuitable eg. 10oclock finishes, pay could be increased.

headline: Proud to work for asda
pros: The people are without a doubt the best thing about working at Asda. Teamwork is important and most managers seem to have a genuine interest in people and development. A fast paced environment with never a dull day.
cons: Like all retailers Asda has been under a lot of pressure in a tough environment recently meaning some cutbacks both in store and in head office.

headline: Bad Company That Uses You - Beware!
pros: Staff discount off shopping only thing decent.
cons:
Started a Seasonal Temp 16 hours.Which meant 52 hours over Xmas totally spoiled my Xmas!
Team Leaders bullied you into working what suited them. They kept ringing me to come in on my days off and threatened you with your job when you couldn't come in. When I finished my shift they wanted to keep you working with no notice! The company use you to get what they want and don't care about you at all. Very different to what they say at the induction.I did get a 8 hour contract for a Saturday after Xmas ( big deal as all they wanted was tons of hours from you over Xmas)  I lasted 3 months then they decided to just put me in 5 hours on a Saturday and 3 hours on a Sunday. How to spoil your weekend! I hated it as they just messed you around none stop! I hated it so i left and got another job...a job that respects me..very happy now.

headline: checkout operator
pros: If you are white guy or girl, easy to get job here. Also, dont expect promotions if you are boy and dont get on with lady supervisors.
cons: No job offers to Indians or other south Asians. Only friends and family members of existing employees will get jobs in this store. Even if someone like Indian could able to get a job, they will not get any promotions even after working for years and years.

headline: Night Shift Colleague
pros: Good pay for night shifts, but when you start your pay will increase after 6 months. The staff are friendly and the sections leaders support the team really well. The managers are decent.
cons: Very large deliveries but not enough staff members to handle the job. Lack of team skills of some of the staff.

headline: Grocery colleague nights

cons: Worst management, discrimination between night &  day colleague, Stressful shifts

headline: home shop section leaders! burheath
pros: the only pros i can think of are if the vans didnt go out late all the time it could well be a better place to work, as the section leaders who only seem todo picking and thats it wont help you out if you need a hand on the road due to the late running of vans
cons:
if things are not going there way they can be rude shout and god knows what else to there staff,
expect there drivers to work ridiculous hours, 
i see a driver last week take out 11 deliveries in the mroning then come back and do another 15, then another 15 in the night!
im sure that must be some sort of law to that!
im ok as i do click and collect but i see it as a bit unfair to the drivers in general what they have to do, i was shouted at last week myself by a section leader so not happy at all, what will be done about this nothing!!!!
think this should be looked into by somebody higher up in asda and see how they run it

this is pointed at Burgh Heath KT20 5NZ branch, i cant really speak about other branchs but im sure its the same

headline: Service section  leader
pros: You have a chance to try diffrent roles so you don't get bored .And if u decide to go higher Asda do provide all the training u need x
cons: Low pay all bigger chains get more hourley rate and in supermarkets you do a lot more round the store

headline: Not to be trusted on any level, therefore, seek out a manager who you believe to have standards and work for him or her.
pros: It's local so travelling to work is made easy for the magority of workers. After a few years, you might be able to work the hours you want within reason, if your manager is half decent and new employees fill your previous work schedule.
cons:
Too many to list them all. Going back a few years, the bullying culture was rife in all areas of the business, and forcing people to leave in droves. Things may now have gone the other way as it appears a cull of senior managers took place during a cost-cutting phase. 

You can work as hard as you like but don't expect any rewards, whilst other can do as little as they like, either being sick, going on holiday, or leaving early. Standards are low across the board so don't expect integrity and good ethics when you most expect it - from the top down.

headline: Nice place to work

cons: Work is repetitive, but there isn't really much you can do about that working on a till. However, it is possible to do work on other sections.

headline: ASDA
pros: GOOD BENEFITS, WELCOMED CHANGES. Worked as a team and had great networking opportunities. Great colleague engagement
cons: NON - The ethos was very employee centric and maybe at times too much? Maybe utilise greater pool of experience?

headline: Choices
pros: There are many pros to working for Asda, for instance you can take your time with tasks and are not obligated to complete them in a silly time frame. I also love the fact I can drop what I am doing for a customer, or for tills without any repercussions. My managers are supportive and enthusiastic. My colleagues are around my age as well but it is also very diverse in every bracket which is lovely.
cons: The managers, as supportive as they are, are sometimes seldom seen on the shop floor. When going to the tills to queue bust I find myself stuck there for pushing 4 hours a go which is just impractical and against queue busting rules. The tools used (gun and printer) are outdated and need serious updates and there are also never enough in store. The same can be said for the tills which need a serious dose of TLC.

headline: Checkouts
pros: Colleagues are brilliant. Need more staff of more flexible hours to help mums our around school times etc
cons: Not enough colleagues at mo . Running around doing too many jobs and when it goes wrong managers wonder why??

headline: Hated it
pros: The people I worked with on my department were amazing people
cons: The management don't care about you at all or the customers for that fact! There more interested in getting a job done and going home. U get thrown in at the deep end when starting not knowing how to use equipment and having to work it all out for yourself. I have ms and if I get flu I get very very sick and they made me work in the warehouse on my own with both sutter doors open in winter with no coat, gloves etc. I then became sick and needed time off which made me get in trouble with the management team. I then had to be on sick and I also was put on antidepressants because of all this. I then handed my notice in because I could not take any more of what I went threw

headline: Home shop section leader
pros: Pros are when it good a day it all goes right
cons: No communication. Long hours and then sometimes back in early again. Certain people don't listen so might as well do job my self 9 times out of 10

headline: Home shopping picker
pros: work with a wide variety of people which is always a good thing. The Asda discount card. The canteen in the morning serves hot food incase you don't have your own.
cons: You get overlooked a lot of the time, especially on our department of home shopping. ie, management team have been well known for lying, fast judging, and making Accusations which have only led to reporting them for bullying.

headline: nothing but complaints!
pros: Can't give any good reasons to work there ...
cons:
Underpaid me by a substantial amount of money over Xmas 2014 (700). Took an hour lunch break off me when I didn't get a dinner and when asked about it was told we were too busy to have lunch breaks! Was paid nowhere near the right amount of money for the hours I was clocked in to work! 
I was told I would need to have a disciplinary or would be removed from my job if I had more time off work (I have arthritis) this was worse over the winter months. Therefore felt I had to struggle through work knowing that my arthritis would get worse. This company is a joke to work for. Whilst staff were working their back side off to make sure orders were picked in time the management and section leaders were sat around yapping to each other not doing any work whatsoever.

headline: Runner
pros: I have worked for the store since it opened and my colleagues are like a 2nd family.... the company were excellent when I lost a close member of my family .. very caring and understanding... they have always accompanied my needs.
cons: Not enough colleagues to work ... which puts a big stress and strain on us. Trying hard to keep things running as they should on skeleton staff is not good. I feel like I can't give 100% good service because of being so stressed.

headline: Services colleague review at asda
pros: Section leaders and managers are always very friendly and approachable. You feel part of a very close knit team working for asda and your hard work is always recognised and congratulated. Also very flexible with all personal circumstances.
cons: The rate of pay is probably the lowest of all the competitive supermarkets. Sometimes due to the high volume of staff important information about the store is sometimes not communicated to all employees.

location: Preston, North West England, England, England
headline: Piss-poor Management
pros: 10% discount (isn't that much though); meet some great characters and make some good friends; during the week the store is not very busy so not much work to do although it can be boring and make the day longer
cons: Poor management; sometimes treat like a child in school; younger people expected to do more work, especially if your a male; have to work a weekend day; the supervisors (section leaders) get paid 1.50 perhour more to delegate work and do nothing themselves; any ideas or helpful suggestions are shot down by 'know it all' managers who think everything they say is correct; if you do not have a degree you will be waiting years to advance no matter how good at your job you are; constantly micromanaged; monitored on breaks; poor health and safety - three cases of broken/fractured bones within the space of about 3 months

headline: Shop floor worker
pros: Its was a good company years ago but since saul  came things are not running as it should cuts on managers job and staff have had a big effect on the company ... gsm soends to much time about checkouts and staff from other section are being used to cover and left on there for 2 to 4 hours atime so there job on their section are suffering greatly
cons: The wrong people working at wrong times no process not being done .. not enough colleagues ..to much time on checkouts

headline: Most colleges are great, nice team feel
pros: Atmosphere is good, lots of staff benefits and 10% discount after 12 months, discount holidays and option to buy shares in the future. Also childcare vouchers and free eye tests. Free tea/coffee n snacks . Lots of charity work too.
cons: Low basic wage, short lunch break , only 30 mins for lunch unpaid on an 8 hour shift.

headline: Asia is going to the dogs

headline: Not too bad
pros: The people I work with are so great. They really cheer me up when I'm feeling down and make working so much fun.
cons: It can get extremely busy but it's a retail job so that's to be expected.

headline: Working at ASDA
pros: Great people, fantastic atmosphere, brilliant perks, a great place to work!
cons: Some days you will have a bad day but that's normal everywhere!

headline: Mixed feelings
pros: It really does feel like a team, those on the shop floor make working fun, we have a laugh and we all build up relationships with the customers. It doesn't matter what department you are on, everyone is friendly and will help you out. It's like a big family
cons: The management don't understand our job roles. They pile jobs on you constantly without thinking of the other 100 jobs on your list, then complain when jobs are missed. Asda is bout the customer so I put serving my customer first, however when my other jobs aren't done I'm expected to work long hours. Also working time directive has no meaning in the asda world!

headline: Pudsey branch only.
pros: At the pudsey branch, I made some good friends. And they were very flexible in my wife's working hours when she became pregnant (worked at the same store).
cons: Terrible training for the role. Consstantly battling along without manager support. they were more interested in wages been kept down rather than providing a good service for the customer. Managers also had favourites who would let them get away with murder, usually pretty, young girls who flirted to get what they want and usually did.

headline: A good place to work part time
pros: They are very flexible with working hours and shift patterns, which works for those with children or those still in education. Most staff I have met have been overwhelmingly friendly and pleasant, and it is a relaxed working environment.
cons: The pay could possibly be higher, in line with the wages paid by other supermarkets. The 10% staff discount is quite poor compared to other shops who give 20% or more. Furthermore, this cannot be used on groceries.

cons: Some colleagues think they have the power to boss other colleagues around. Some colleagues have better knowledge about the section leader jobs then the actual section leader.

headline: asda store

cons: They make up rules to suit themselves the management have no standard's the store looks like a jumble sale.

headline: home shopper
pros: Small shifts and contracts available for  those that need it. Over time available over winter mainly.
cons: I hated asda. I worked at mcdonalds while I was still at school and would rather go back there than work at asda again. Your under paid, under appreciated and under staffed most of the time. Section leaders are often on a power trip rather than being reasonable as are managers and no amoint of complaints help, in fact they make matters worse. Asda house, main office,  are an absolute joke and wont even process a complaint. There is no regard or respect for each other, and they certainly dont look after or care abput their colleagues.

headline: Checkout operator
pros: Great colleagues, everybody is treated equal, a sense of "teamwork" which is great, we all support each other, whatever our status,
cons: Not the best rate of pay, keep changing the way of doing stuff, new systems that don't work as good as the old ones.

headline: Lots of work for little money.
pros: Genuinely can't think of any plus points other than it's working for a recognized brand. It really is that bad.
cons: The pay is the lowest out of all the supermarkets. The management don't believe if you are sick or have to leave on time and constantly pressure the colleagues to work longer. Cases of bullying are widespread and go ignored or are brushed under the carpet when reported. Breaks are the bare minimum they can give and are often interrupted. They break trading laws by pressuring staff to finish late and start early often saying that "those are the only shifts available". The longer serving colleagues are treated much better than the newer members even though the majority do less work.

headline: Student collegue review
pros: The friendliness of all the colleagues and the respect you receive from everybody no matter how high up they are in the company, I also love the flexibility of the job because I know that if I need more hours I will be able to find them somewhere in the company
cons: The cons would be the pay is lower than other supermarkets and that the uniform doesn't look very nice at all

headline: live better
pros: The opportunities are good, facilities too, additional benefits are better than most. Great team to belong to and the company listens to its colleagues.
cons: Wages are lower than other supermarkets and there is always the pressure of saving wages. There is also the downside of the pay rate being the same for each department, whether you collect trollies from the car park, on the tills or drive a van.

headline: It has its ups and downs.....
pros: Flexible working, always try to help you when you have a problem at work or at home
cons: cutting hours all the time.

headline: Great.
pros: Great job, Good wage, Easy to pick up, good range of shifts on most days if theres overtime going.
cons:
I thought the discount for staff would be higher, as with APG coupons, alot of customers can get better money off than employees can. Don't like being rang last minute or same day within a few hours to cover would appreciate more notice.
Lastly Not so much a con as a trait you need as you also Have to have alot of patience when it comes to some customers also need to stay positive.

headline: service operater

headline: Working at ASDA
pros: Flexible shifts available. Lots of opportunities to develop. Friendly atmosphere with good staff benefit schemes including discretionary annual bonus.

Many stores reliant on overtime which results in awful results if people decide they only want to work their contracted hours.  ,  ma,

headline: Asda
pros: The group of people i work with are very friendly and i enjoy my job. The company can also be very flexible when needed around childcare issues.

headline: good craic

headline: Delivery Driver

headline: Delivery Driver

headline: Home shopping driver
pros: We was out of sight from public while at the store so we was able to have a bit of a laugh
cons: Pay was minimum wage, the times set for delivery was unrealistic only way to do what you was told to was to speed and drive dangerously, the section leaders knew this and would pressure you until you gave in or quit. I did over 18hr shift in the van on one day with only a ten minute break all day, our section leader knew this but did nothing. From this I now suffer serious back pain every day and no longer able to work.

headline: Decent
pros: The friendly atmosphere was very good the majority of colleagues attitudes were great. Usually very helpful with allowing time off when needed even if it was short notice.
cons: Not enough hours to atlas cover my basic 30 hour contract. Management hardly there after 3pm. Normally errors were made each day whether it be shopping missing on the van or just general carelessness. Lack of working satnavs. Phone calls before the cracks of dawn to ask to cover a shift that started 3 hours later.

headline: Manager

cons: Communication could be better within stores

headline: Manager
pros: Good team work .large world wide company.great deals
cons: None that is known to me

location: Farnworth, Greater Manchester, North West England, England, England
headline: Night section leader
pros: The colleagues that worked for me and with me at farnworth store. We were a small family that all came together to get the job done.
cons: Ruthless unforgiving untrained young inexperienced managers that wouldn't listen to reason and lied openly to get what they wanted. Bullying was seen regular as well as ignorance from the top few. Definitely an I'm better than you attitude.

headline: Working For Asda
pros: Getting to meet some great people, working for a company that notices your work ethic, Career prospects
cons: The early morning starts, the late finsh

headline: Great company, nice to feel valued
pros: Great company to work for, many years working in other sectors where you aren't appreciated for what you do. Feel there is a genuine opportunity to progress if you are interested in doing so - lots of people say there isn't, but you really do own your own progression plan here.
cons: Only issue is around pay; lots of home office colleagues on the same grade but with wildly different salaries. Would be beneficial to have a public pay matrix.

headline: Getting worst and worst to work for!
pros: If your looking for flexibility over reliability then ASDA has turned to this. With the huge turnover in staff and management a lot of different characters come in and out. This has lead to some really good friendships in my time here.
cons: With companies like Lidl paying a living wage ASDA refuses to listen to paying anywhere near those rates. Even though Walmart was ranked 1 on the Fortune 500s richest business' list. Managers are either complacent in their job role having been there for years or are in a different store less than a year from arriving. Progression is only upwards. If you do not want to progress into their gang culture roles provided there is no other way to earn money. Loyalty and morality is thrown by the waste side for yes men and women regardless of work rate.

pros: The colleagues in my store are some of the best people I've ever worked with

headline: A good place to work
pros: Flexible hours, opportunities, bonus scheme, clear policies and procedures. Twice a year double discount on certain items, sharesave scheme in place. Nice friendly place to work.
cons: Team leaders are often so busy they are unable to consider the welfare of colleagues.

headline: Better than nothing
pros: For a simple shop job, you do get a decent hourly rate - a lot of shops pay less. Even under 18s get 6.66 an hour, which is unheard of in retail. Good as a means to an end - get your bills paid and not too hard. Get to meet a lovely bunch of people, most colleagues are very friendly.
cons: Heavy lifting is requires, and usually strange hours. I have Tuesdays and Wednesday's off and work all weekend, which means my social life has diminished. I work sometimes lates and sometimes earlies, the hours are usually all over the place. While it is decent money, it's not great and one or two supermarkets pay better. Little chance of progression too, it takes years and years and will not get you very far.

headline: Pluses & minuses
pros: Its very clean and fairly quiet. You get staff discount. The hours are flexible. I have some lovely colleagues.There are proper staff designated bike sheds.There is free tea/coffee/squash/toast/spreads & newspapers in the canteen.
cons: The staff car park is mainly gravel with pot holes and you get your shoes muddy when it rains. There is no air con in the staff changeling rooms/toilets so it becomes a sweat box in the summer.The lockers are too small for work shoes + handbag, spare tops etc. I rarely finish on time as it is frowned upon if you leave before finishing your shop. We have no regular meetings/huddles where we can air our concerns. We only have meetings for training/information about change of policy etc.

job_title: Meat Replenishment, Serve Over Meat and Fish Counter
headline: Overall good employer
pros: Great benefits like 10% off everything with discount card. Everybody is treated equally, no ethnic or disability discrimination. Everyone is given a chance, don't have to have lots of experience and everyone is paid equally regardless of age. Pay increases after 6 months to reflect experience. Flexible working hours, can easily book holiday but if not can shift swap or take unpaid leave. Can apply for career breaks of a year so you can live life. Everyday is different.
cons: Have to work a weekend day, isn't a major problem though. Staffing can sometimes be short and can have very tough days. Expectations of managers can be too inflated.

headline: Section leader
pros: Colleague discount, it's a job that pays the bills. It's close to home for travelling.
cons: On minimum wage - Underpaid, a lot of stress. There's a serious lack of training and you do a lot more work than a section leader should do with no thanks.

headline: Smaller "Supermarket" Section Leader.
pros: I enjoy working with most of my colleagues. It's a smaller local supermarket and I like the fact we form a relationship with customers.
cons:
Although I don't mind, and at times really enjoy the tougher shifts; there's far too many tougher shifts which seem to be an uphill battle. 

This is usually due to the decisions made above us, like ridiculously low wage budgets, overly complex processes for what should be simple tasks. An awful ordering system that wastes so much time and money delivering what we don't need and a lack of what we do need (despite so much time invested in the processes).

As a Section Leader I feel I'm overworked and vastly under paid. It feels like we have to do the work of a Colleague plus a Manager as well as our own duties. We're often the Duty Manager for long periods and dealing with quite complex problems. I enjoy this challenge but feel I should be rewarded for it. I get just above minimum wage for this! 

We are under trained. I did my "training" over 3 weeks when I joined from Netto. It was basically a box ticking exercise. A series of people reading to us from dummy cards. If we asked questions we were usually met with the same answer from all, "I don't know, this isn't my area, I'm just covering". We then had to sign to say we'd had that area of "training".

We often make the joke, "in order to progress at Asda, you have to sell your soul to Asda". We are expected to do long shifts. We're contracted to 38 hours but it's taken for granted that we'll stay til a job is done. This is frustrating as the job would be done on time and to a better standard without the fact we're working with one arm tied behind our backs by those above, managing their figures to look good at our expense.

We learn as we go along, pick up new skills from other Section Leaders we meet and always have the feeling that we're missing something.
We have so many people in deadwood positions visiting, demanding we follow their rules and processes for their particular area of concern. It's not nearly possible to find the time to do any of this for even one of them. Never mind all of them. These are people simply trying to justify their job roles. 

I don't believe this is unique to Asda, it's the down side to working for a big corporation but it's just magnified ten fold when working in a small building.

In order to get on, you have to play the game. You'll thrive if you accept the bull, talk the talk. Say the right things, then when you get above, keep up the presence as though you didn't experience it yourself and carry on making the decisions that cause those bellow so much stress.

I have no ambition to go further and stay in this job as it's just a convenient location to me.

I will move on when I find a better alternative.

headline: Reasons to go to college.
pros: Reduced goods (damaged/out of date) to suite your low budget, 10% off most goods, doesn't do zero hour contracts, it's not a sweatshop.
cons: It's the employees "privilege" to buy out of date or damaged goods at a reduced price to cut company losses, low wages, monotonous work, employees are either over worked or hardly working, too many managers some of which are awful at there job, the CEO will get paid more for bathroom breaks at work then you will for a years work.

headline: Don Asda
pros: Nice and friendly colleagues. Many benefits including 10% discount on all food. Easy work and good money for what it is.

headline: Good people, bad management skills.

headline: Check out colleague Asda living oxford
pros: The pay is generous, management are supportive and other colleagues really help to build a team spirit. Flexible hours mean I can work around my degree and allow me to go home for Christmas.
cons: Customers are regularly rude and aggressive and there's little I can do to defend myself. Some members of staff are noticeably not pulling their weight and receive no punishment when issues are raised.

headline: Checkout Runner
pros: The Discount, the Friends, the interaction with interesting people, the flexibility of the job and not much more to be honest.
cons: Wage, SUPERVISOR STAFF (not managers) The new system of creating supervisors that have minimal training and qualifications, chosen by the management staff in the store is simply RIDICULOUS! You're getting staff members who have been there for less than a year sometimes or completely unqualified to handle a team of people, doing all the managers work and treating every normal staff member like rubbish. They believe the have the right and authority to treat some staff members like they're beneath them and personally i think its a terrible system. I could go on about any other problems with the job.

headline: Low pay's not okay!
pros: I'm a home shopping driver so I get to do my own thing. There's no take home pressure, I simply turn up, do my job and go home. Always plenty of overtime when I want it.
cons: Can be really physically demanding. Low pay, At £7 an hour it's the lowest paying company in the sector. 4 Weekly wage.

headline: Home shopping - Loader
pros: Great place to work for likeminded staff who are always happy to lend a hand and help in everyway they can. Pay is reasonable and work is rather enjoyable.
cons: Some of the section leaders like to skate by doing the bare minimum wont lend a hand and will leave most the pressure on your shoulders. But that is certainly not all of them just a couple. Although nothing seems to get done about these problems.

headline: Recognition
pros: I love my hours, the people I work with and the company it's self.
cons: However They have a lot of Asda stars, ladder climbs, yet working nights none of this seems to apply. It's us guys that do all the hard work and that's a fact. I come out of the place sweating. Then will shop the next day to see groups of 3/4 colleagues standing around chatting to then find out one of them receives an award the following month. This issue really needs to be addressed. Hayle harbour.

headline: Shop Floor Assistant, Home And Leisure
pros: The staff are great people to work with, get on easily, easy to talk to managers and section leaders that'll listen to you rather than just hear you and then not take action on anything.
cons: Can be very tedious when it comes to asking for overtime, for example if you were on 20 hours a week and could be doing up to 40, and you tell many managers of the situation and then they'll tell you they will find more hours for you (almost as a promise) soon and you'll be able to work more. But they never do, and your request kind of disappears.

- Having to be graded on customer friendliness by Asda's own mystery shopper. I always provided good service, but it's hard to be jolly after 7 hours into a 10 hour shift.

headline: Generally alright!
pros: The job itself is okay, nothing too hot about stacking shelves, making pizza and queue-busting. There's not one colleague there who I don't like working with. Fresh Manager's awesome. Generally looked after well.
cons: We're no longer allowed to take lunch with people on the same department - yet all the management go for breakfast at 10am every morning. Our General Store Manager has no idea how the shop floor runs because she was a George manager. People can't be hired due to budgeting reasons. Staff's hours are being cut and holidays are forced to be taken due to overspending,  but then they realise that there aren't enough colleagues so panic and have to spend money in overtime to get colleagues who aren't off to jump onto other departments.

headline: Pharmacy assistant
pros: I worked at Asda for 20 years.  I started as checkout operator in the evening, I did this for 6.5 years.  I then went on to work on the jewellery counter which was the best job instore!  I did that for another 6 years and when I got divorced I bought a house with in walking distance of Asda. For a few months I worked on the Kiosk but then the job in the pharmacy came up and I applied for it and got the job.  This job ment doing 2 Buttercups course  which I found very interesting and it  prepared me to do my job well.
cons: Working on a small department ment we were not always informed of things happening in store.  There was not always enough staff on to attend huddles.  Also we had to work extra when colleagues were on holiday or off sick.  Not everyone was prepared to do their share.

location: Winsford, North West England, England, England
headline: Could be worse
pros: People are decent, 10% colleague discount (20% around Christmas), relatively relaxed most of the year, good share save scheme. February Bonus. Great compassionate leave policy.
cons: Pay is poor and very hard to live off, having to do very long hours to get a reasonable pay packet. Often refuse to give a proper contract preferring you to hold a part time contract whilst doing full time hours and thus preventing you from holiday pay. Have to work a few bank holidays a year, growing reluctance to hire more staff. Regular weekend work often including the entire weekend. No extra pay on weekends. Night rate only kicks in after 10 pm until 6 in the morning so you may be forced to work unsociable hours without a pay rise however night rate is also poor in comparison to most other places.

The Home Shopping section is the only section that has not Voice rep....

location: Farnborough, Hampshire, South East England, England, England
headline: Lovely colleagues at local level, unsupported by corporation
pros:
Asda colleagues are the best, really friendly helpful people. There is a great team spirit as everyone mucks in to help each other get the job done. 

Customers are usually nice, understanding and have low expectations as it is known as a cheap shop.

They do sometimes promote from within if you are willing to put in the hours and sing the corporate song - literally!

You will be busy, busy, busy which is good for people like me who like to feel useful not bored.

If you can handle the workload, at shop floor level it is not too stressful as section leaders and managers get all the heat.

Given how disorganised things are, it is very easy to get away with doing little to no work (also a con!)

Good union presence has led to reasonable benefits and treatment of most staff, or at least paying lip service to same.
cons:
Ridiculous pressure is put on section leaders who receive a very low wage for their level of responsibility.

Dead-end job: There seems little point trying to progress as you can work a long time as a section leader and never make it to management. Many section leaders step down again as it is a nightmare job for very little reward.

Chronic understaffing which only seems to be getting worse. There is never enough time to do a job properly, so most jobs are rushed and left half-finished by staff. Queue-busting (leaving your job to help out on checkouts) just exacerbates the problem. High workload and low staff leads to stress, staff absences and resignations, which leads to even lower staff numbers, ad infinitum.

Rotas are rarely updated on time, badly planned and sometimes you will find out after the fact that you were meant to be on shift. Due to low staffing and overworked section leaders there is often a lack of communication about rotas which leads to problems like this.

You are often alone on shift which is fairly miserable. Some people use this as an opportunity to do no work, which means more work for their colleagues who come on shift after them.

You have to work at least one day every weekend, and often evenings as well, often at little-to-no notice.

10% staff discount is lower than other supermarkets offer.

Lip service is paid to things like Health and Safety, which is then routinely ignored if it gets in the way of doing the job. Basically you have to sign a form to say you are aware of all H&S issues and will report any, the sole purpose of which seems to be to implicate you personally if you get injured at work. Eg, In my department's section of the warehouse the fire exit was routinely blocked by rails of highly flammable clothing which had nowhere else to be stored. This was hurriedly hidden elsewhere before a senior management inspection.

Store management at local level are doing the best they can, but can only follow the instructions of their corporate masters who turn a blind eye to anything inconvenient. They are all about numbers and don't seem to realise overworked, stressed, untrained staff will have a negative impact on their bottom line eventually.

headline: Home shopping Delivery Driver
pros: Some of the people you work with are really friendly and helpful. The majority of customers you deliver to are also very friendly.
cons:
Well where to start! The wages are a joke for the job you do. You might as well sit on a checkout (no offence checkout people!) and earn the same money. You are out in all sorts of conditions, battling the traffic, trying to deliver within time slots, attempting to locate house numbers in the dark...

The shift patterns, for me at least, are rubbish. Friday, Saturday and Sunday every week, when there are other staff who don't seem to do any weekends or night work. Guess it depends on the length of time you've worked there? It would make more sense if it was done on some kind of rota system, then at least I'd get to spend some weekends with my kids!

The management are terrible, no communication, constantly shanging my shift pattern without actually notifying or asking me. The senior management don't seem interested in even saying hello to you!

All in all, I personally think it is a terrible job and I am looking to leave as soon as possible. I would recommend you think hard before accepting a job as a delivery driver at asda.

location: Watford, East of England, England, England
headline: Checkout operator
pros:
The pay. 20% Discount card.

That is honestly it, and that is the only reason why they have staff. There is 0 job satisfaction.
cons:
Management are useless and pretty much non existent. Managers are always changing, so you don't get a connection with anyone.

Equipment is outdated (why are we still using a dirty keyboard, have you seen sainsburys and tesco?) Every checkout has bits of equipment missing (eg. Important phones to contact the runners) we have to wave around our hands waiting for someone to see us while the customers are getting frustrated at waiting in the queue and taking it out on us.

Never get your lunch at the time put down, (your name "accidentally" gets crossed out because they thought you've been already) always have to nag staff walking past that you haven't had your break yet. The excuse is "we don't have enough people to do breaks" Yet you see plenty of staff standing around chatting doing nothing!

You get left on the self checkout by yourself. This is impossible to control by yourself and very stressful. This ASDA must lose so much money from all the stolen goods at the self checkout. It's impossible for one person to control.

These may not seem like really big problems to some but they are when you're doing this type of job.

Everyone on checkouts has these issues and more! The turn over is so high people are always leaving.

ASDA don't care though because there are always students and desperate people willing to work for them because of the pay.

The managers are imcompitant, two faced and lazy. They have too much power and abuse the hell out of it. It's okay for them to take, not only several more than they're supposed to, but also stupidly long brakes but the moment you take 5 minutes extra you get a counselling for it!

They don't tell you about any benefits. I didn't even know I got a floating day or that I had to sign out for my breaks so I've been losing money.

Please don't take this as working at every Asda will be bad. I'm sure it's not just please, don't work at Asda Burnley, I promise you will regret it.

headline: Pros and Cons of Night/Day shift.
pros: Rotor is always up to date, key colleagues feel part of the team and don't behave like a higher members of the store. Always paid on time and always the correct amount.
cons:
Night Shift: Pallets arrive at the store a mess. Takes up to 2 hours splitting up pallets into there departments before I can even start working (warehouse staff have time to separate stock for every other department apart from home and leisure which is the biggest in the store I work at). 
Canteen staff never fill vending machines so no food can be purchased whilst working in the night.
Never enough cages on a night to put cardboard/plastic into, we use plastic 'baths' instead which we are told we can't use but it leaves is no other choice. 
Day shift: Lack of store phones so some customer calls may not be heard. 
Communication isn't great, many times I was no longer needed for a shift and no-body told me. 
Smoking Shelter leaks constantly as it never receives proper maintenance.

headline: Soul Destroying
pros: The 10% discount is ok as it all adds up.
cons:
You must give a minimum of three weeks if you want to make changes to your rota, but they give less than 24 hours notice, if you don't do it you get treated like a criminal. Management look after their own, they have multiple prolonged breaks where they get takeaway food and treat select colleagues, but everyone else is timed by the second. Working in Langley mill you are not likely to get the job if you are not related to management, in which case you don't need any skills or qualifications. People work hard, others will just show their face and chat for 4-8 hours, but everyone is paid the same. If you are a section leader or manager you can walk around the shop and do your shopping during your shift, you can also take items off the shelf and pay for them at your convenience, if you remember to pay that is. If you are a colleague do not stand and talk ever, you must make sure you do the work load which used to be split between maybe 4 or 5 others because hours are constantly being cut. if you do arrive at work and realize you have left your name badge at home you had better be prepared to go home and retrieve it, even if is an hour commute on the bus on a bank holiday (which you have to work) but dont worry if you are close with management because your manager will just have a laugh with you about it and give you another, free of charge. You cannot expect to get a full weeks holiday if management don't prefer you, you must stagger it out throughout the year never exceeding 6 days at a time. Depending on your manager the rules vary to their liking. 
I would not recommend working for this company. Management are paid peanuts, and they get the job if their face fits, doesn't matter how good they are at the job, which means they do discriminate, they do favor certain colleagues and will make your life difficult if they want you to leave. 
At this job i was often finding myself reading up on laws because these guys have no idea what the laws are and do break them, constantly. when i tried to report issues to higher management they would advise you didn't raise a complaint as it would effect managements friendships. Once when a formal complaint was passed to a manager she read the form, which has to be processed and action must be taken, she took it read it and screwed it up in front of the poor colleague and threw it in the bin saying she would not go against another manager.
