headline: Home shopping
pros: Used to be a good feeling to get up and go to work with a great team all pulling in the same direction. Not so now
cons: Since we have got rid of managers and they have taken the step to go for Section Leaders most of which are kids with no experience and certainly no people's skills the stores moral has gone downhill. And now we are told that we have to take tea break at 0830 which would be fine except the canteen is not open until 0900 now that's what I call good planning

headline: Hard grafters need only apply
pros:
The 10% discount card was handy to have and do miss it, though that said, I now don't feel compelled to spend all my hard earned cash there.
The colleagues, right across the board, were what made staying for so many years bearable.
cons:
Poor management. Lack of communication. Night team not included in rewards/celebrations leaving them feeling unimportant despite the fact that they work so damn hard.
Very rare to receive positive feedback, regardless of how much time and effort you'd put in... Nitpicking on the other hand seemed to come regularly.
One to one reviews just never happened. Infact, I didn't even get a leaving interview. I felt like I'd given them 6 years of my life and they hadn't even noticed I'd gone.
Would I recommend working there? No. It's OK if you're a university student just working seasonal for a bit of pocket money, but the wages are awful, (£9.65 an hour on nights), and there are very few opportunities to progress due to the fact that they've done away with most of the management now. Section leaders are paid £1 an hour more that regular colleagues but are expected to work longer hours and get a Hell of a lot of grief.
The only thing that made the whole thing bearable were the friends I made during my time there.

headline: Working for Asda
pros:
I work with some very nice people and the job in itself isn't too bad. 
I was working full time over Christmas.
cons:
I've been with the company some time and still do not have the same hours week to week or a contract. I am given roughly 3 days notice on my shifts. This has made booking days off almost impossible. 
I am not allowed water and have been made to go hours without a toilet/water break, even when ill. 
There are a lot of members of staff that do not contribute to the team and constantly slack off, but due to their lengthy time with the company are treated far better than the newer staff members.
I feel as though I am treated unfairly on a very regular basis and hope to find a new job away from this company soon.

headline: Managers pay gap to Colleagues in Logistics
pros: I've worked for ASDA for 10+ years, I have met some great people and worked my way up to management. Benefits are good - discount card, double discount weeks (before Xmas), lots of different benefits on the greenroom employees website. Opportunities are there if you're willing to learn, travel and development yourself.
cons: The pay gap between D zone (first tier management) and logistic colleagues is now in the negative, meaning a Lates and Nights warehouse Colleague earns more per hour than his Manager. This is due to recent pay awards for colleagues of 8+% and managers only receiving 1%

headline: Bad upper management decisions
pros: Good pay and usually a choice of work to do around the store. There are still paid breaks. They have a lot of seasonal and part time work which does fit students or people with other commitments, such as I did when I started. There were usually opportunities for overtime if you were willing to be flexible.
cons: They are constantly cutting jobs which makes the company feel very insecure. In 3 years we had our hours changed 3 times and lost over 300 hours on the department. The cuts really stress people out which means what should have been an easy, part time job became a constant burden.

headline: Restructure is killing the company
pros:
Friendly colleagues
Staff discount is handy
Very good with community projects
Flexible with hours
Standards are high, which shows in presentation
cons:
Managers were promoted too quickly, don't have enough experience to be telling others what to do
It's got an "if your face fits" mentality
My store had a terrible male-to-female balance, only 5 of the 31 section leaders were female, no female managers
Zero progression opportunity since restructure
Unrealistic targets
Not enough colleagues
Very high staff turnover
Section leader pay is abysmal for what is expected of them. Most tasks are things the managers couldn't be bothered (but should be) doing.
Terrible work life balance. Full time is 38 hours a week, not 50, no one should have to do that.

headline: What can I say
pros: other staff members are a laugh to work with , however just don't get seen talking or even walking with another member of staff as management and Section leaders disapprove!
cons:
It used to be a decent place to work for but its gone down hill !! You get rudely spoken to , get shoved onto different departments without any training , management and section leaders treat you disgutingly when all the colleagues are doing are working ridiculously hard and get no
Praise for it!! If you make a complaint against a manger it doesn't stay confidential as all the managers are best buddies , so you've got no one to help
You.

headline: Glad to be gone
pros: Pay was reasonable and work was easy enough. As a supermarket it's good and so discount card is worth having.
cons:
Managers were really unpleasant and had unreasonable expectations. Didn't understand how long a task took and weren't happy when it wasn't done in their unrealistic time-frame. Rotas were a mess and I ended up with a disciplinary for missing a shift that I was put on at the last minute and not informed. 
Wouldn't give me study leave for exams, despite assuring me that they would. This was the reason for me leaving.

headline: Nice people - encourages progression

A fantastic team to work with. Give you plenty of

headline: Lots of hours and lots to do
pros:
Very accommodating: I had a part time (16h/week) contract, but was offered shift cover to make up more hours. I also worked with a woman who could only do part time and she was not pressured to do more. 
Keeps you busy running around, and free coffee/tea even food sometimes in the break room. 
Other colleagues made sure you got our breaks. 
Were accommodating with holidays.
cons:
A bit hectic - sometimes got called to cover shifts with a few hour's notice (though I was welcome to refuse). 
The work schedule changed each week and wasn't always up to date so I didn't know when I was working unless I found a supervisor to ask. 
Understaffing was an issue when a trainee manager came in. Left us understaffed at the end of the day or with trainee staff doing supervisor roles.

headline: Never again.
pros: It's a job when jobs are hard to come by. A set rota means you'll always have shifts.
cons:
- I received little to no training for quite a complex job. Had to guess my way through the majority of my paperwork for months, unacceptable considering magazine promotions required me to deal with an external company and an external moderator.

- I was a 19 year old girl, petite, being required to drag extremely heavy loads around the shop floor every day - on warehouse trolleys that were often breaking or refusing to steer

- I was the only person trained on newspapers and magazines, but I was only given three shifts a week. The other four days were "covered" by someone who had to do it on top of their other job and didn't know how to do it. Hundreds of papers/magazines were wasted each week, left on the shelves for days, or left unreturned to the printer. My manager always gave me the blame.

- Because I only had three shifts a week, I had to work another part-time job at another big company. I passed out cold one evening at my other workplace through tiredness and stress. Due in at Asda at 6am the next morning, I called in sick so I could rest, fearing I'd pass out again. Told Asda I'd been unable to see a doctor yet because of the timing of it, but that they could call my manager at my second job if they needed confirmation. They refused, and I was given a yellow warning - one disciplinary away from being fired. Apparently if you have worked there less than six months, you don't get the luxury of being ill.

- My manager was rarely working at the same time as me so I couldn't talk to him about my frustrations. I left him messages, which were always ignored.

- Other colleagues in my own department must have felt the same about their jobs - no one cared, everyone was grumpy and rude. Without exception.

Left as soon as I was able, will never go back.

headline: The transient nature of retail.
pros:
Colleagues
Decent benefits package
Flexible hours available

Asda has long enjoyed a reputation as a great employer, famous for treating their colleagues and customers with respect and dignity.
cons:
Brutal workloads
Limited progression 
Inconsistent leadership

However, largely due to increasing competition from continental budget retailers and the slow shift from the traditional supermarket model towards e-commerce and other online retailers, standards have slipped significantly. 

At the moment colleagues in all parts of the business are bearing the brunt. Increasingly excessive workloads, less and less manpower to complete tasks and largely unreasonable expectations have decimated morale.

headline: Neatural Experience, Poor Training
pros: Staff are very friendly, enjoyed replenishing stock, enjoyed working nights because it's quiet and you can work faster, money is good working nights £9.24 after 10pm.
cons: Asda don't provide full time hours unless your a Manager or Section Leader, No gloves provided after 2 weeks of working on frozen, hands would stick to the metal cages and I'd come home with skin peeling off my hands, only half of my uniform was provided in time for me to start, cages are very heavy for a petite young girl who had to take them off deliveries. I would have 8/9 cages and I would have to take them one by one through the back yard, through the back warehouse and into the freezer without gloves and I don't have a huge amount of strength and not enough time, i really could have done with some help, I definitely would have stuck out the job if I did. In addition, the poor man that trained me had an AWOL which I understand is unacceptable but the fact that ASDA then used him for 2 days to train me and then sacked him is disgusting and I would never have expected this to happen. Also, he had a feeling he was being released and had never trained anyone before and wasn't trained to train someone. Therefore, I did not receive the correct training and had to basically learn everything by asking other colleagues as I was thrown in the deep end on my own. I also cannot get through to Asda as no email address is provided and the number doesn't let you select options on mobiles so I hope I am paid correctly otherwise I have no way of resolving this issue.

headline: Not bad, but not the best job
pros:
The job is easiest when you have members of staff who are actually doing their job without slacking. 

Most of the colleagues are alright
cons:
Your off-days are usually interrupted with a message or a call from your manager or supervisors due to their inability of being able to recruit reliable members of staff. So get a secondary phone number and ensure you switch it off when you are not scheduled to work.

Also, you'll sign a contract but will be told to change the days you can work with a week's notice, which defeats the purpose of signing a contract, especially when you are frowned upon for not agreeing to their terms. 

Drivers do not need to deliver groceries past the communal entrance ofa block of flats, however, customers are not aware of this as it is hidden within the terms and conditions, meaning they'll blame you for being lazy, while the company will find a way to place the blame on you as "It is at the driver's discretion".

headline: Not what your sold!
pros:
Never had an issue with pay.
Nice mixture of people who on the whole were a joy to work with.
Its a relatively secure job.
The work is easy
cons:
Pay is now only minimum wage. 
You will have a basic contract which is normally a 8 hour weekend flex but there will be overtime however even if you were to do the same hours overtime wise week and week they are massively reluctant to contract you to it. 
Everyone is very stressed and very overworked causing moral to be through the floor due to a lack of other colleagues in terms of staffing levels and help from management. 
The management at store level is massively, massively lacking in ever sense oft the word. From lack of support to complete lack of  communication and even though they cannot accept it there is very much a 'us and them' culture.
When you have a visit from head office management (area manager and up) it becomes a comical farce because then there is pandemonium and only then  will you see the management try and take control in order to get the credit.
Praise and acknowledgment is very slow in coming if indeed you ever receive any at all.
Training used to be excellent now your just thrown on the department with a very basic idea of what to do and expected to just do it. The work is easy but not until you know what you are doing.
Colleagues are treated in general poorly. There is nothing to motivate you in general to do a good job and so a lot of people just don't. Things like breakfast of a morning have been taken away. The bonus received yearly has been massively reduced  to the point none of us even recognise it.   
They are undergoing a mass 'reinvention' in order to make them more competitive due to the struggles that have been well documented in the news. This has been handled badly and is causing untold issues for customers and colleagues alike. 
My advice to you would be to walk around the store before you join and look at staffing levels on the shop floor, the level of product on the shelves and the general happiness of the staff it will tell you a lot before you start. 
Asda is all about the customer however it is severely neglecting its colleagues and now it really isn't a good place to work and the customers are dwindling down in numbers. Improve things for colleagues and the store as a whole will improve!.

headline: Great for learning about grocery
pros:

Lots of opportunities to transfer to other areas both within UK and in other territories to broaden skills and knowledge if that's what you want to do.
Great company attitude to disabilities and mental health (though that might depend a bit on your line manager)
cons:
Expected to regularly work 60 hours a week with last minute demands for 'urgent' work that wasn't then used.  
Little evidence that the advertised commitment to ethics and values is taken seriously by senior management.
Culture of fear at senior management level.
Flexible working not understood - being able to work on a laptop all night at home after a 12 hour day in the office isn't really flexible working.  Condensed hours not available because they'd end up with people only working 4-day-weeks, but you can work for no pay instead.

location: Basildon, East of England, England, England
headline: Stay away - unless you like being a nobody
pros:
The only good thing I can think of regarding working for ASDA are the employees themselves, many of whom are very friendly and approachable people.

Furthermore, there is some degree of flexibility with shifts and hours worked. However, this is very dependent on the willingness of the management team - which often leaves a lot to be desired.
cons:
There are numerous. The biggest downsides in my opinion are the following:

- Atrocious management. I was never personally introduced to the store manager, and the only contact I ever get with any managers (not team leaders/section leaders) is when they decide to give me a new task that has absolutely nothing to do with my actual job, or they decide to complain about something. As the saying goes: "Once I did wrong and that I heard ever; twice I did good but that I heard never".
- Unfair absence policy. I called in sick once, and was explicitly warned (without ANY sympathy to the fact that I was actually very unwell on that day) that if I was to take another day off during the probationary period (12 weeks), I'd most likely lose my job.
- Zero value. I feel that no-one in the store really cares at all about me as an individual, or even as an employee. The only person in a management position (section leader) who actually cared about me was one of the youngest people there. Anyone in a senior rank than you (and even those who simply perceive themselves to be so) simply does not care. It is quite depressing frankly, knowing that you are essentially treated as a well-paid slave to the company.

headline: Terrible experience. Recruitment procedure is terrible. Management were rude.
pros: They pay £7.20 which is good for my age! (student)
cons:
Bad recruitment process
I applied for a Job in groceries and was given something completely different. I felt like I was just somebody filling in a space and under valued. I was given a job that wasn't for me however I accepted it  (what did have to loose). First day of shift was awful, was introduced to section leader for 2 minutes then was told to go do my job, no training at all or heads up on anything. When I asked them general questions they didn't answer them or show any care or engagement.
The person who sorted out hiring me wasn't helpful. When I approached her to ask if their was anything else available she didn't look into it and was rude towards me. When I asked about doing a different role she said I wasn't capable of doing it (I just wanted todo something like groceries or staking shelves!, their were open jobs available) I am perfectly capible of doing that.

When I called to resign I was passed around from place to place, different people. They haven't evan paid me since I had that conversation and I doubt they will.

I think the Job would of been great if they would of listened and given me the chance. I hope different stores aren't like this (Im sure their not, they do promote good values).

headline: some great people...some less so!
pros: Some really great people to work with. Reasonable pay, but great flexibility of hours to suit as needed.
cons:

headline: Good place for students
pros: Good place to work for students, if you are at university. Part time was helpful to fund my degree. Management were supportive and friendly. Overall a good experience.
cons: Can be long days and shifts can be inflexible. Some colleagues lazy.

headline: Plenty of opportunity to move around
pros:
It's a friendly and open working environment, with a real buzz about the building. They hire for personality and competence, and you can be trained to do most jobs you have an interest in, so it's fairly easy to move internally. 
Training is good, and you are encouraged to attend training for soft skills. 
The 10% discount is useful, and they hold a few double discount events throughout the year.
cons:
Progression can be difficult, and you often have to move department to move up. They will pay you as little as they can get away with, and even if you move department or level you might not get a significant pay raise. 
Personally, I'd like to see more women in higher positions - it feels a bit like "jobs for the boys" in some departments, which can be discouraging.

headline: Senior manager
pros: No pros business is in turmoil
cons: Lots too many to mention

headline: A thankless task at times.
pros:
Development opportunities frequently available, due in part to the high turnover rate!

Offers flexibility if you're only after part time hours.
cons:
Constant cutbacks to wages, staffing levels mean that the workload is spread more thinly across fewer and fewer workers. This leads to a vicious cycle where the shop gets worse (availability, cleanliness etc), so sales drop, so they cut back even more, and so on.

Work life balance is non existent on nights. Regularly expected to pull 12-13hr shifts on a daily basis. Days managers come in and treat you like an errand boy when your shift was due to finish an hour ago.

Standards only matter when there is a GSM or regional manager visit due. Management cares more about looking good in front of their mates than they do about providing the best shop possible for customers on a daily basis.

Don't offer full time contracts so good luck trying to make ends meet if you're on your own.

Constantly missing targets and forecasts, I feel my store is a sinking ship.

headline: Job is ok, company feels big and uncaring at times

headline: Section Leader
pros:
I am well established within retail, having worked for tesco for 5 years.

No Pro's (anymore)
cons:
No training

Payroll budgets are tiny so constantly asked to send people home to save money, even if the team available is too small

Dirty stores, inadequate budget for cleaners

Benefits slashed in recent years

Canteen removed from most stores

Recruited as a section leader, expected to do the role of night manager (Rotas,overtime planning,time management,disciplinary)

Extremely poor pay (75p more per hour than replen colleagues with all the responsibility of running entire store)

Management are extremely critical with a very negative and suspicious outlook

Staff morale extremely low, 90% of people were either thinking about leaving or felt undervalued in some way

headline: General Assistant
pros:
Step up programme available for colleagues that want to progress in the company. 10 percent discount and 20 percent on a day near Christmas. 
To some extent you get left alone to get on with your job which is quite nice.
Flexible for contract change - I was allowed to go seasonal when I started university and the hours were good. 
Pay isn't so bad for a supermarket.
Hard working colleagues rewarded with a gold star on the wall and a free lunch party - although if this falls on your day off you either come in for it or don't get one.
cons:
Step up programme is a long process. 
Managers have favourites.
Bitchiness among staff, playground atmosphere - managers not very discreet, some not even approachable.
Not many incentives, staff Christmas party very low budget, Christmas bonus is poor considering how much the store makes. Staff aren't particularly valued in my opinion.
Training could also be a lot better, some staff given very minimal training and then told off for being slow or making mistakes.

headline: A race to the bottom
pros:
Some excellent colleagues that really do deserve better than ASDA. Also some that don't.
I can see how the 10% discount on groceries can help out a family being paid minimum wage.
cons:
All the huddles, magazines and fancy noticeboards in the world cannot hide that ASDA pays as little as it can get away with. All its competitors pay more, some quite significantly yet ASDA continues to under perform financially - and its a downward trend. Any correlation?

Behind the cheery family facade there is low morale. To make a decent wage significantly more hours than contracted need to be worked. This is what ASDA rely on, people desperate for more hours that say yes at the expense of their work life balance. The work culture dictates that if you say no sometimes then other requests may be viewed unfavourably. Take that as you will.

Poor holiday entitlement, no opportunity for rostered weekends off. Would a shift system really be that difficult? Lots of staff on different contracts doing same job.

The cynical side of me thinks the only reason they give 10% discount is because ASDA want the money back they begrudgingly paid you in wages.

headline: Warehouse Colleague

headline: Not Horrible
pros:
- Often flexible about holidays, shift swaps etc.
- 10% discount, some other benefits like cheap health insurance, share save etc.
- Can get overtime across multiple departments
- Most customers are pretty reasonable
cons:
- Low contracts (8-12 hours usually) combined with semi-regular overtime bans and cut-backs mean hours are not reliable. Only way to get a full time contract would be to become a section leader. This despite understaffing in most departments. Our department can't afford to replace workers who left on part time contracts but apparently can afford two section leaders on full time higher pay? Then they wonder why the profits are slimming....

- Rotas changed at shorrt notice, unsocial hours. I'm lucky in that I don't need a full time wage at the moment so I can turn down ridiculous shifts demanded the night before but some colleagues are not so lucky and managers take advantage of that.

- Section leaders are useless no power to actually implement any changes or support workers but paid more for relaying management orders.

- Management is incredibly indiscrete,  very gosspiy atmosphere. Playing favourites and politics between managers and departments.

-Constant reinforcement of 'family' ethos contrasts with huge pressure for departments and stores to compete against each other.

-Middle-management only help out if there is a visit and even then only sporadically. Very uncommunicative (will only send messages through section leaders even if you have directly approached them about something) and unresponsive to shop-floor-level staff's complaints. Incredibly uncaring about chronic health issues or other problems staff may have and will discipline you rather than engage if you complain

-Training only provided once you've done something wrong in which case you will be told off for not doing it right and 'retrained' (despite them insisting you do the job with no training initially).

cons:
very money orientated, if they've had a bad week in sales they cut back on wages the following week. 
don't employ enough staff to run a busy supermarket! they seem to invest in office staff more than frontline staff.

headline: Hard work, not great pay
pros: Good team spirit, good social life, within a store people are great. It's the policies that filter down from higher up that make life hell.
cons: Hard work. Lowest wage of all supermarkets. The only supermarket who doesn't let union talk to employees, probably because they are owned by Walmart who are notoriously draconian toward employees. Senior management is rude to your manager by not turning up to visits that they said they would. Your manager has to cope with a policy of fewest-possible-staff which means that any imperfect situation, e.g. somebody on holiday or off ill, results in the remaining staff being overworked. This company policy puts undue stress on the staff, and is the reason for the high turnover.

- Management in my store is awful, GSM deals with people awfully. Once called a meeting on Christmas eve where he told section leaders he was going to "stomp on their necks" if they didn't do whatever he was asking of them.
- Stressful environment, lots of pressure to get lots done each day but no real thank you for your performance when targets met or exceeded.
- Unfair treatment of colleagues, people get away with doing no work and turning up late constantly but others will get serious reprimanded if they done the same.
- They promote young, not ready people into section leader roles meaning you have clueless, lazy people telling you what to do.

headline: Unfair. Horrible Place to Work
pros: Plenty of overtime, which sometimes you may be pushed to take.
cons: Not everyone is treated the same. Managers don't care about you, you're just a number and they will talk down on you (based on own experience).

headline: Section Leader
pros:
Not alot anymore.

Great Colleagues to work with.
cons:
So many recently!
Managers restructure that saw some very good and skilled managers leave but some not so skilled managers stay! The reduction in colleague's leaving stores looking unstocked with gaps in almost all aisles as we do not have enough colleagues to keep up with the work load. It's as if Head office forgets that customers are in the store and are asking colleagues where items are. They must think we just refill stock all day with nothing getting in our way. And on top of that most of our shop floor colleagues are on checkouts for most of the shift due to lack of colleagues for checkouts and queue build up. The company also makes a big fuss over area manager visits. If the store looks good it's only because the area manager is due to visit not because we want to WOW our customers. I think such visits should be out of the blue to keep stores in top condition all of the time. It's the customers we need to impress no the managers. Asda recently stopped its £20 gift card at Christmas for colleagues. This is a little thing that colleagues liked and it all helps for those who are not on full time contracts which are hard to get now. A new computer system and lack of tanning. Colleagues hate this new system due to this reason. Again it was another rushed feature and no thought.

headline: Asda House
pros:
Family friendly employer 
Great for reviewing your performance and progressing your career
Open plan and non hierarchical working environment
Great facilities on site
cons:
Believes that positions of the same level are interchangeable irrelevant of experience e.g. HR moving into Marketing
Restructures seem to happen quite often and aren't always managed professionally  
Car parking is an issue, even by 7.30 car parks can be full

headline: The most depressing job of my life
pros:
-You get to go to the toilet without asking
-10% discount card
-Sweet green uniforms
-Poverty wages
cons:
-Clock in, clock out
-Monitored on CCTV
-Employee management is via threats

headline: Delivery driver
pros: working outdoors and meeting new peolpe.
cons:
The vans are old and very very dirty, some of them were so smelly in the fridge compartments, like they haven't been washed for years.
The job is EXHAUSTING, at least for the new comers, they give 40 deliveries a day to the new guys and 20 to the older employees, and when you carry peolpe's shopping all day up and down flats your back starts to hurt.
The shifts were two, first one starts from 7 am and the other one starts at 2 pm, i used to work 8 hours every day but many days i had so many deliveries that i worked 10 or sometimes 11 hours, and with NO BREAKS!!! i never had a single break!! i worked 5 months there and i always worked 9 hours straight with not a single break ever, not even to eat lunch, i used to eat an apple or a sandwitch while driving in between deliveries.
Some of the older drivers did have a bit of time for breaks because they had less deliveries.
I worked there over the winter, so it was always so cold, and was raining most of the days and i remember getting home at night completely soaked, even my underwear were wet from the rain...
I dont know how i lasted that long there but i had to pay the rent, and obviously in the meantime i was looking for other jobs and as soon as i found another i quit.
And on top of all this, the salary was minimun, 6.50 at the time, while other companies for the same position pay 10 or 11.
Definetly the worst job i ever had, dont reccomend it to anyone, go to other companies.
I'm not a person that tends to complain normally but trust me, go elsewhere.

headline: Delivery driver

Understaffed,  broken , old equipment, sat-navs are only updated every 12 weeks.
Took me approx. 5 weeks to get safety gear supplied.
Management only interested in figures not people.

pros: Always supported and given as much help as required, you're never left on your own by the team that works there.
cons: ASDA tends to tread seasonal employees like puppets; you're only there when they need you there and even still, you're still a pain. They tend to call you up about a shift the next day and they don't give you enough time to check to see if you're free. The health and safety training is also not so good, you watch a load of videos and tick boxes on a sheet which contain things that you've "apparently" gone over.

headline: A decent company but IT has been mismanaged for over a decade
pros: The place is nice, outside of IT a very good company to work for and the people have a lot of passion. Location is great, in Leeds center (Head Office).
cons:
Crazy hours (you have to get in hours early to even get a parking space and will be expected to stay late often), very low pay, 'mafia style' management structure at the department head level, promotion based upon being in the mens' club/running club/rugby club. Lots of doing silly management favours on a whim - such as build their wife a laptop on company time etc...

Bonus's can get convoluted and you have very little impact on how it gets calculated. 

Lots of un-common sense decisions which cost lots of time and money wasted - often out of hours too. 

Very bad appraisal process - review yourself in a huge form and then argue with your manager over a pre-determined score that was decided months earlier at a management offsite meeting with little to no baring on the work you actually did and more on personality opinions.

Promotion process itself is pretty ludicrous and changes names and style every few years. Expect it to take 6 - 18 months when you are already doing the role to the level they want and then up your deliverables to the point where you are working 60 - 80 hours every week. Maximum pay rise you'll get out of that is 10% and that's not even guaranteed.

headline: Complete Joke
pros:
-A lot of genuinely nice colleagues

-Double discount every 6 month
cons:
A lot heel dragging and time wasting by certain colleagues which always goes un-resolved. 

During my probationary period it was extended unfairly and without reason 4 days before completing it (by an extra 3 month). It took me 5 Month to have it investigated by ASDA only to be told the same excuse over and over again. They stated that it was for all employees as of December however other colleagues who started at the same time and even new colleagues do not and did not receive the probation pay reduction. Due to this i have lost several hundred pounds which i have worked for.

Feeling intimidated by thieves and customers resulting in alot of nervousness from colleagues. This majorly goes un-resolved due to lack of security. I personally have been threatened several times since starting there.

Management do not listen to suggestions and complaints. But would rather ignore them and hope they go away.

headline: Barely legal.
pros: Nothing comes to mind. Some days the only reason I can find to go to work is to see my work mates, the pay is certainly no motivation.
cons: They pay a few pence above minimum wage and tell you its above the industry average. Treat you like cattle. Promise you full time hours, you're lucky to get more than 16/week. This month (Feb) we will be paid an "industry leading" annual bonus of  £91. Minimum respect for health and safety that the law allows. Almost daily bag/pocket searches and locker searches in absentia for staff while known shoplifters and the gang of local hooligans are allowed to roam free because they don't want to cause a fuss on the shop floor. We're forced to work Christmas eve, Christmas day (night staff), Boxing day, New years day etc whether they fall on a day you're contracted to work or not. I'm quite convinced that one is required to fail an IQ test in order to become a manager. Customers who are abusive to staff are often rewarded with a good will payment and whatever it is they wanted whether it is legal or not, the use of healthy start vouchers for prohibited products and the sale of alcohol to a group of people not all of whom can prove their age, are the most common examples. Anyone who is not inclined to brown nose has no hope of any sort of promotion or even overtime unless it's on ASDAs terms. Flat rate pay, no higher rate for evenings sundays etc. ...

headline: Great culture

cons: Can get a little too political at times. Oh and they need more meeting rooms at the HO!

headline: Nice people, poor ethos

cons: Poor working procedures that resulted in many work related injuries for people I worked with.

headline: Checkouts
pros: There are non anymore sadly
cons:
Runner jobs given to those too young to understand that it is not an excuse to discuss your social life or go easy on your friends at the expense of others.

Section leaders a little power goes to their heads one or two are great but most have a lot to learn about the ASDA value RESPECT OF THE INDIVIDUAL.  Discussing others matters with runners is a breach of data protection folks.

Management has been extremely terrible and moral low since the store lost its original manager.

The way your made to feel when your ill and phone in is ridiculous

headline: Home shopping is a joke!
pros: There are literally no pro's that I can think of with this company, they take advantage of their staff when other supermarkets pay considerably more for the same job!
cons:
Daily arguments with the home shopping manager

Delivery routes that make no sense, given 10 minutes to make a 12 miles trip during Friday rush hour traffic.

Clueless pickers that make stupid substitutions Customer ordered Bonjella and was sent Robinson's juice?!  Yet as the delivery driver, you have to deal with it and take the flack from the customer.

Vans that are not road worthy and management who pressure you to drive them.

Fridges and Freezers full of mould that is usually left for months. 

Loaders that "consolidate" totes to fit more onto the van making totes too heavy and drivers getting injured.

HR/Management losing accident books when claims are put in due to staff negligence.

cons: Can't give a low enough score....10% discount, Late hours, managers that don't care, poor rate of pay, high staff turnover, THE GOOD ONES GET OVERLOOKED, the but suckers get far.... I could go on, the list is endless.

headline: Great place to work as a student
pros: Flexible hours and lots of opportunities for overtime during university holidays. Pay is as expected for an unqualified supermarket role.

headline: Mix Match of Things
pros:
- The people who work in the store kept me going, with good humour even in bad circumstances.
- Very good manager who had the give and take mentality which is not often seen nowadays, very flexible.
- Very good experienced team working with me, kept me going even when I was doomed and gloomed on the place.
- Learned a lot from experienced colleagues which have helped me in my new job.
- Developed my management style within ASDA within their belief system, which is a very good system and catches all, even out of the retail sector.
cons:
- Hours were cut often and more work was expected to be done with a smaller team.
- Home shopping and checkouts often took most of your colleagues to support, due to their lack of hours, all while expecting you to achieve the same results with less people.
- Very poor career progression available beyond Section Leader level since ASDA restructured with less management positions.
- It isn't the same company I joined, which had the ideals placed on the worker, now a worker is just a number who is easily replaced.
- Never received a proper thank you for a job well done, only ever off my manager never higher up. However, higher management were quick enough to criticise you and your team if something had been done wrong.
- Higher management listened to issues you raised, but the problems never get resolved.

headline: Great staff members
pros: Treated by management like humans not a member of staff. Had staff of all ages so people always had people to speak to.
cons: Multiple 12 hours shifts near xmas but was expected. Sometimes was late on to break on lunches as you couldn't get someone to take you off the till.

headline: Asda
pros:
Good pay, especially if young and in education.
Easy enough work, always kept busy.
Good breaks.
Trusted to do work.
Good diversity in work.
Can be flexible if you have to work around education or raising children.
Very friendly people and some managers. Most are willing to help.
10% off employee discount (after 12 weeks) and twice yearly "double discount days".
cons:
If you stand out more will be expected of you. You will need to do more work than those who put little effort in.
Trust to do work is largely down to the manager. Some are fair but some will constantly check on you, and it can be demotivating.
Twist your arm into doing extra over time, if you are weak willed or shy, you will be exploited. Often do not understand that you have commitments outside of work.
Heavy hours during holidays, eg Christmas, but this is to be expected.
Some section leaders are unmotivated and seem to not care when asked for help or advice.

headline: Great Colleagues,Not So Great Management

cons: Poor management attitude, lack of staff (and security staff). Being treated like a criminal for failing Challenge 25. Personal situations not not treated as confidential. Being brought in to work bank holidays, then being sent away again "to save money". Admin. staff unfriendly and unhelpful. Having to ask other staff to cover your shifts when booking holidays - just wrong!

Wouldn't work for them again even if I was paid £1m per Shift. It affected my health and well-being and I'm glad I got out before it was too late.

headline: Worked like slaves
pros: Great colleagues, 10% discount card, double discount at Christmas, yearly bonus depending on store performance.
cons: Gone downhill in the past few years, more and more work piled on top of colleagues. Threatened within the sack constantly if targets not met. Night shift is the worst, depleted staff levels, no communication, ignored and abused! Management are lazy, they have their favourite members of staff, lucky them! One of the managers enjoys sleeping with as many staff as possible, whilst planning his wedding!

headline: On a slippery slope

headline: Interview
pros: A great opportunity to learn new things. Great stuff and a really good atmosphere.
cons: Doing your best with no stress. Beast deal I could choose.

headline: Great, until anything goes wrong
pros: I started working there as a Christmas temp last year, and was given set hours and overtime at a good hourly rate, with the promise of being able to pick up overtime after the seasonal period. The people I worked with were great, friendly people and I was made to feel right at home from day one.
cons:
However, after the seasonal period, I was completely dropped with no communication from management. I was left with no income but still technically employed by them. Then, several months later, I was suddenly given a call giving me less than 24 hours notice of a shift I had been rota'd for. Turns out my contract had been altered without me even knowing, let alone giving permission. At this point, I asked for adjustments to be made to my workspace in order to accommodate my disability which I clearly stated I had on both my application, and at my interview. Upper management denied I had ever informed them of this disability, and refused to make changes. I was forced to leave as I couldn't work there any longer without these adjustments.
Also, the staff discount is 10% which is the lowest I have had in any job.

headline: Job Satisfaction

headline: Head Office
pros: Asda is a vibrant, dynamic and caring place to work. The head office in Leeds is easy to get to from the station and from the moment you walk through the doors of Asda House you're almost always greeted with a display or activity about the latest product launch or initiative. It's a momentum you can't help but get behind. The will to support you, develop you and do the right thing for you is very much there too.
cons: As with any big organisation sometimes "simple" projects can take longer than you might expect to land but you do get there and when you do,  your work will be celebrated. Some investment in IT is needed but is no doubt on its way.

headline: An alright job but ran by morons
pros:
10% discount 
Friendly colleagues 
Meeting new people everyday
I really can't think of any more pros to working for Asda stores
cons:
'Senior management' expects far to much from section leaders and colleagues. Majority have no common sense and couldn't organise a piis up in a brewery let alone run a superstore 
Very tight wage structure which always seems to be overspent even though there's next to no colleagues.
Employ the wrong people i.e. People who only want to work certain hours for tax credit purposes or to fit in with school hours. 
If your face doesn't fit or if you don't brownose then you get overlooked. 
No such thing as a reasonable request or response if you decline a shift or need a day off for a reason.
Management quick to blame you and won't take anything you say as a valid point (from personal experiences) if they think your wrong then your wrong even if your not and this gets proven. Treat you differently if you've made them look silly. 
Very sly and untrustworthy as the targets and 'goalposts' are forever being changed/tweaked.
Impossible to have a life outside of Asda if your a section leader
Computers and robots will be in charge and working here in a few years time.

headline: Checkout Colleague
pros: Lots of development opportunities and room for growth if this is the kind of company you want to be in.
cons:
Shyer or quieter colleagues are very easily exploited/ placed doing undesirable tasks. 
Some people not promoted based on the quality of their work but how much they get on with the right people.

headline: Worked to death on home shopping
pros: Shift days are set. Generally most staff are easy to get on with
cons: Will work you to death with very little break time. Home shopping is extremely hard work and very physically demanding. Management would call us in at 3am when my shift was meant to start at 6am. We would still be on the shop floor at midday and sometimes there until 3pm. Working a 12/13 hour shift with one 20min rest break and one 10min drink break is not acceptable. People were off sick due to injury and regularly attending physio

headline: Good company
pros: All staff are paid the same, regardless of age. Free uniform and plenty of spares (not always given in retail). Bonus scheme (although not vast amounts of money), Friendly staff. I got to work in different departments and the best was the Petrol Station. You were left to manage it yourself, obviously there was a manager at some points. Till work, customer service, cleaning, merchandising and keeping the forecourt safe. There was a management scheme, but I'm not sure if it is still available. Staff were friendly, mostly. Managers were friendly, mostly. Subsidised canteen. Clean, pleasant environment. Extra pay after 10.30pm approx.
cons: Obviously retail shifts including earlies, lates, weekends and holidays. But this didn't bother me too much. Working 9 to 5 can be tedious to be honest! You don't get extra pay for public holidays. Obviously retail pay isn't the best, but the level of responsibility matches it, I would say, Working with money, you need to always keep yourself right, so check your till etc before you go onto it to check for it being down etc.

headline: Why I had to leave
pros: The majority of managers are professional and fun to work with. Colleague benefits are are a plus too.
cons: Its about who you know not what you know. You'll never be able to develop. Especially on South London region. The new SMP is a disaster and will only get along with you if "we're the same age and have kids" . If you don't fall under that catergory don't expect your career to go anywhere.

headline: Not as advertised
pros:
Good colleagues to work with
Double discount at Christmas
Try to be flexible if you have other commitments
cons:
The upper management dump everything on the Section Leaders who then expect more from you especially if you are a hard worker. Work hard and do a good job and more work is expected of you. Whereas the lazy colleagues get away with it every time. 
Understaffing is a constant problem, as people leave, recruitment is non existent as the wages budget for each dept is squeezed more and more so there are fewer people to do the same amount of work which means corners are cut. 
Christmas is the worst time for stress. The music Asda plays over the radio is just dire and depressing especially as it's played from October. 
The whole management structure is very cliquey meaning those who are part of the inner circle get promoted first. 
Training is almost non existent especially those who are advanced to Section Leader. You could be in the job for months before you get sent for training. 
Stress is rife and nothing is done to alleviate it. 
I still have the second hand jacket I was given when I started 4 years ago, getting uniform is like getting blood from a stone.

headline: Working at Asda

headline: Store Manager

headline: Deli-staff
pros: Everyone is friendly. Section leaders are generally very understanding and nice.
cons:
The main issue I seem to have is getting any time off. You have to give three weeks notice, so I gave five. I only got it accepted about four days before I was actually supposed to fly out, even though there was nobody other than me off work on the shift.

The store is always understaffed and morning cover is always given priority over evening cover. This is in regards to weekend shifts when the deli is ridiculously busy during the evenings, compared to the mornings. 

You are required to do far more than is expected of you. This includes keeping the counter full, whilst completing ten customer orders at a time on pizza. On Friday, you might as well not even have a break, because you are scalded for taking one and get in trouble for taking it at a busy time, even though that is your right.

headline: Not bad.
pros:
Excellent colleagues, feels like a large weird family. Always a fun time with them around! 

10% discount card after 3 months employment. 

Step-on initiative to allow you to move up positions within ASDA.
cons: To echo many other sentiments on here; the management are awful. They treat colleagues with what (seems like) contempt, some are actively causing people to leave the store. Their lack of organisation and man management skills is downright laughable as they seemingly never talk to the section leaders for them to relay information to colleagues. Only one or two managers who genuinely care for the colleagues.

headline: Not a nice place to work, look elsewhere!
pros: The people who I mainly worked with I would consider friends, great to work with.
cons:
- No loyalty from senior management. 
- No one is replaced who leaves. 
- You can't live on the pay. 
- In my first year they tried to pull a fast one on £200 of my wages. 
-Long hours and hardly any break time.
- Always an excuse why I couldn't take annual leave.
- You will be overworked and underpaid.
- When customers are rude, expect no support from Senior Management.

headline: Asda

headline: Stay away
pros:
- Good pay
- 10% discount on everything except fuel after 12 weeks
cons:
- Toxic environment between section workers, section leaders and managers
- Lack of equipment for work that requires it such as printers, Telxons and omni trolleys
- A plethora of favouritism from Section Leaders, especially where there is a potential relationship involved
- A clearly defined hierarchy as superiors place themselves up on a pedestal above their subordinates
- Section Leaders are abusive if the tasks they set (which are often unrealistic) are not completed by the time they expect
- No real goals from one day to the next
- Work becomes very monotonous
- Lack of training besides some videos on the introductory day
- No real sense of belonging or purpose
- Unrealistic expectations from management
- Often overworked and left extremely fatigued, even after a 4 hour shift
- Management believe that no one has a social life outside of work
- Lazy work from management shoves the consequences of their actions onto their subordinates and blames them for not getting the work done
- Someone needs to give the managers a f*cking A-Level Business textbook because the information in it means that I could probably run that sh*thole in Peterborough better singlehandedly than they could.

If all of this doesn't give you a reason not to work at ASDA, you NEED to get your head checked.

I felt pressured to take hours that I didn't ask for or want and the tiers of management often got things confused between them. Rotas were a mess and constantly changed without me being informed. I was repeatedly contacted when I was off sick and pestered for a doctor's note after one day of sickness and also rang numerous times whilst on holiday.

headline: Too much pressure
pros: Colleagues fantastic, supportive store manager, plenty of overtime, excellent training opportunities if you want to progress. Brilliant benefits and incentives for bonuses.
cons: New fresh restructure is leaving Section Leaders stressed, wanting more out of us but offering no support or extra bodies. Departments not given enough hours and it feels like we're up against unachievable targets. Manager can't increase hours as his hands are tied over wages. Not enough praise when you're doing well. Left short and told you're not allowed to be stressed out as it affects morale! Area Managers need to be having 1-2-1's with section leaders and offering support. More and more colleagues discussing leaving or stepping down. I regret stepping up. I used to love my job, now, not so much.

headline: Hate every second
pros: Most of the colleagues are nice, 10% staff discount.
cons: Favouritism. As of the new contract; No extra bank holiday pay, unpaid breaks, reduced pay for night hours. Frequently sent home early so rarely get a full day's pay anyway. No support for colleagues if customers are abusive. If you do no work, managers don't care; if you work really hard and make a minimal mistake, you're belittled. 1 weeks contracted days for bereavement, but goes as absence of you have picked up uncontracted overtime during your time off. Worked at Asda for 2 years and have never seen anyone promoted, all management roles have been sourced from other stores or companies.

headline: Terrible management.
pros: I have worked here for quite a long time. Have loved most of it. Most colleagues are lovely.
cons:
Unproffesionism to the up most. NOTHING is confidential.
Management is poor. 
No communication.
Hard work ignored, lazy people praised.
Management do not care in the slightest about their colleagues. Brakes are clock watched but management can take hours.  I was told on starting at asda that if you make a decision involving a customer I.e ID  checked etc. Then section leaders and management would back you. I have witnessed the opposite and management even telling customers that their colleagues are in the wrong etc when they haven't been just make themselves look good.
There is no compassion where personal circumstances are Involved.....
20 minute rule with fresh food is ignored as is colleague safety. 
Nothing is ever appreciated.
The list could go on forever.
There is a good reason for all the good members of staff leavinh.. ..before long you will have none.

headline: Overworked, underpaid and undervalued
pros: Can't think of any, whatsoever
cons: Dirty smelly vans and crates, dirty warehouse, customers treat you like dirt, low wages, impossible time deadlines, patronisingly unhelpful bullying and miserable dispatch staff who only do that job to dodge doing deliveries, dangerous working conditions, you are expected to deliver crates of water up many flights of stairs, sometimes up to 25 crates per customer (who just watches you break your back then just slams the door in your face) stressful journeys, pointless journeys, getting messed around when you return filling out re delivery forms and putting customers shopping back, having to explain to customers why you cannot make their delivery, to which you get verbally abused, getting home at one in the morning, only to do it all again the next day, it is a demoralising job and I would not recommend it to anybody. Do this job and eventually something will happen to you, ie accidents and injuries are commonplace, no matter how careful you are. Half the drivers are off sick with bad backs, knees, shoulders, and work related stress. Arguments and bickering between dispatch and delivery drivers are a common thing, all in all it leaves you going home feeling miserable. Absolutely horrible job. I wish I never took up the position. I am going to leave.

No one to speak to if a major problem occurs till after the event unfolds where you will get the blame.
Stay away from Asda Small Heath. Asda as a company is heading one way only and that's downhill.

headline: Supervisors are clueless!
pros: The discount at 10% is just bearable. The wage is decent  for a student/young adult. Once you understand the job the process is fairly straightforward and can be easy to follow.
cons: Supervisors don't have a clue what they're doing. Clearly not trained well enough to lead their staff properly, over the year I work there I could name countless issues between regular staff including bullying and sexism which were brought up to supervisors and managers yet only led to meetings that didn't change anything. Most of the staff in my department regularly had wages and overtime not properly accounted for and when this was brought up to the supervisors they wouldn't care in the slightest taking months to have even the slightest issue resolved. Very disappointed.

location: Corby, Northamptonshire, East Midlands, England, England
headline: Live your life at the cutting-edge of the retail sector with the best colleagues in the world.
pros:
The home shopping department at my store is like a little hidden Utopia amongst the mean streets of Northamptonshire.

This particular store also enjoys the presence of the best Personal Shopper in the Whole Wide World and 2 of the best beards in the UK.

You get to drive a lovely van around the lovely countryside delivering shopping to lovely, lovely people, listening to lovely music.

Love the wide-angle mirrors.

Automatic vans so you can steer with your left hand and leave your right arm on the window sill, and as to what to do with your free hand, use your imagination, the sky is the limit.

Savage and relentless banter in the depot.

Seriously green uniform.
cons:
"We're one of the biggest private sector employers in the world"......... But 2 months to get a pair of trousers.

Being paid the bare legal minimum, to the penny, doesn't make you feel too valued. No extra money for driving.  Considering the difference in potential consequences of messing up your job when stacking a shelf to driving a goods vehicle, that's pretty harsh.

Reversing an Iveco autobox up a steep hill is an acquired skill for sure, u get used to it though.

You might find yourself driving your own car miles down the motorway in 4th gear, and pulling up to roundabouts in 5th and wondering why you start to stall.

Getting promoted would mean working in an ASDA.

Other than that, no cons. Great job.

headline: Its a job
pros: Limited list if I am honest but will give it a go. Good overtime depending on department/skills. Some very good colleagues, section leaders and managers.
cons: Certain departments short staffed most of the week. Section leader favouritism is very obvious. Managers who seem to take the line "have you told your section leader" or "well? what do you want me to do about it?". Also managers who shouldn't even be in the job. Colleagues that work the hardest are rewarded with naff all, rarely have I had or heard a thank you from managers, section leaders will often say thank you in such a tone you know they don't care. As an example I could name two managers who shouldn't be doing the job they are doing, they have no clue and treat everyone like dirt.  I could add about 20 more things to the list but I think the page would crash when uploading.

cons: Retail, Work Bank Holidays, Customer Service

headline: Part time worker

headline: Working as a porter

cons:
When busy expected to cover tills then get in trouble when the car park is a mess

headline: Friendly people/too much work expected during shift
pros: Friendly colleagues, very helpful, by and large managers were helpful and friendly with just one exception who was full of his own importance. Decent conditions, good canteen, uniform supplied etc. I was driving/delivering and so a lot of independence here and decent technology back-up. Staff discount after qualifying period.
cons: Drivers should be paid more than shop floor workers because they have a lot of responsibility. Training was good but I was sent on my own too soon and found I was trying to deliver more than I could in the time allowed. However, more experienced drivers who were use to the routes, could often complete their deliveries with time to spare.

headline: Process colleague
pros: Easy, not much else to say
cons: Boring, not enough time to get job done, checkout calls

headline: Boring and aggressive with hours

headline: Basic job
pros: Easy work load. Paid on time

headline: not too shabby for a student

headline: Delivery Driver

Friendly staff.
Extra shifts available especially at xmas.

headline: Home Shopping
pros: Due to the type of job there is not a lot of interaction with work colleagues
cons: Money and lack of organisation, there are no Home Shopping section leaders available for help or advice after 2:30pm most times.

headline: Bakery Colleague Review in superstore
pros: Decent pay if you're under 21
cons: poor working atmosphere in the stroe. Management were all under 25 and didn't have a clue what they were doing adn had very unreasonable expectations of staff

headline: ASDA
pros: some of the colleagues, although departments are 'clicky' within the departments generally have good team work
cons: management in store looked down on you, the regional manager is amazing, he is such a lovely warm person who makes you feel like he has all the time in the world for you to talk through anything.

headline: hit and miss!
pros:
very flexible, lots of overtime available, discount card & double discount events, very sociable environment to work in, the kind of company you can stay with for years (i've done 7!), always something to do, active and fast paced, suitable for students, parents, part timers, and older people - lots of departments to choose from, opportunity to move if you get bored or if personal circumstances change
complaints are dealt with well, particularly ethical issues
cons:
the company changes its processes regularly, nothing stays the same for very long. quite often they'll change the way something is done and within a month it'll have changed back again. occasional jumped up managers, some managers/team leaders communicate poorly
management was restructured a few years back and a lot of people lost their jobs. a lot of employee benefits e.g. canteens were lost, the company try to scrimp and save wherever they can which is quite often a bit of a curse. therefore now it's more difficult to step up anywhere from section leader. section leaders were then burdened with managers' work for the same rubbish wage (and therefore they often don't care about the job!)
flexible but quite boring/time consuming as a full time endeavour unless you step up to management and deal with the rubbish thrown at you - often not worth the wage for what you're expected to do!
poor wage especially full time
hiring process is often poorly communicated
new contract base is an absolute scam, a little extra money but no flexibility! you become a slave to the company

headline: Not the best but know worse
pros:
10% discount
Store no longer 24hrs so night shifts are quiet
Easy money
cons:
Kids as managers who have NO skills in how to manage/treat colleagues
Never recruiting...7 colleagues short yet still expected to do yours and theirs work with no thanks

headline: good if you need a job on the side for 1-2 years max!

easy no stress job
turn up and walk away at the end of the shift
10%discount
cant get fired
cons:
low morale
depressing
no one cares
bad managerial 
dirty
understaffed
departments never mix
your job will be much worse if you get the wrong dept

headline: Exploitive, rude managers

Fitted around my College and University timetables.
Alright Pay
Good working environment most of the time.
Make lots of friends
Good first Job

Don't get valued for your work.
2 faced colleagues, not everyone is like this and it will vary from store to store.

headline: Worst place to work
pros: 10% discount and great colleagues to work with the ones you can rely on to help you finish the work.
cons: The one I work in needs more staff and most of the delivery needs to be worked during the night because it there's less staff during the day which cannot do 10 cages including the racking during the day. Plus the management needs to start thinking about the other departments instead of groceries and our sections leader doesn't do no work and gets away with it which puts an extra load on everybody else who is working that day. Plus if ignite doesn't work on produce how is it going to work on chilled.

headline: Chilled Colleague
pros: Good staff and flexible hours
cons: Tiring work at times, but no real complaints

headline: Has it merits along with drawbacks.
pros: Staff are amazing, job is not stressful or demanding, discounts.
cons: Management seem to be arrogant, long hours, no rewards for hard work, lack of planning in quality running of store.

headline: Awful
pros: Great colleagues (cos all in the same boat!)
cons: Where do I start?  They dont care about you one jot!  Canteen facilities a joke.  Work hard?  They'll work you harder!   They used to be flexible, now they want you when THEY want you.  Just awful, go work elsewhere unless your a student desperate for a job.  They will seriously take anyone on!  Oh and don't "progress" cos they'll then work you to death or a nervous breakdown!

headline: The job is good but can become repetitive.
pros: Decent rate of pay (compared to other unskilled jobs). The days can be calm and easy when there is sufficient colleagues. Everyone is friendly and helpful.
cons: Frequently under-staffed which can result in a fairly stressful work environment. Poor management means some jobs arent done to a high enough standard. Consistently doing the same roles means it can become repetitive/boring.

headline: Repetitive with basic pay, but ok share scheme
pros: Ok for a first time job, Easy work. Ok share save scheme. Helping customers is rewarding.
cons: Pay is very basic, Management treat you bad, but i suppose thats the same in most jobs like this.

headline: Non existent training on tills, runners rude & dismissive
pros: Discount card and uniform provided
cons:
Giving a massive 30 minutes of till 'training' then left on your own. When ask runners to help they are very rude and short. Won't take the time to show you gift cards/vouchers and then get irritates when you ask. Makes you almost scared and definitely embarrassed to ask!
Absolutely shocking.

headline: shocking place to work full of meat
pros: absutley Terri me place full of monkey bashers
cons: I would not recommend any human this side of mars

headline: Bullying managers
pros: Discount card, great colleagues, made some good friends
cons: Out of all the managers at my store only 3 were not bullies, complained to head office....nothing!. Asda doesnt take bullying seriously. We were also told too many people off with stress, this isnt an illness and they could lose there jobs. Loads of dodgy working practices that would harm the company if the press got wind of it

location: Crawley, West Sussex, South East England, England, England
headline: Checkouts
pros: Nice people, nice customers, discount card.
cons:
Only 4 hours of induction training. Only 45 minutes 'shadowing a colleague on the till' then let loose on your own. No point of contact if you have problems, no HR department that's easy to contact.
All queries are done through their internal email/website, including holiday requests.
Understaffed.

cons: Little chance of progression off the shop floor. As with all retail jobs expect to work shifts over xmas and new year.

headline: Useful stepping stone to work elsewhere
pros:
- 10% Discount Card, Frequent Colleague Double Discount Days, 
- Relative Flexibility with time off
- Plenty of opportunities to learn new skills or train on new areas of the business
- Opportunities to get involved in fun community projects, supporting local charities & community groups
cons:
- Long hours, unsocial hours & working late shifts-into-early shifts
- Working two in three weekends & a rolling rota of early / late shifts makes a work-life balance difficult
- Section Leaders have low pay for taking on a significant portion of management work
- Equipment is outdated & frequently breaks down. Even 'new' equipment being installed in stores runs on a background of Windows XP software. 
- Management culture can vary greatly from store to store, some stores really value & build a team culture, other stores have little workplace culture.
- Broad company culture seems to be struggling, taking anti-customer cost cutting measures rather than investing in more efficient practices or better technology.

headline: Lovely team, useless admin- still unpaid after leaving
pros:
- The team I worked with were mostly lovely people 
- There was always something to do, no pointless standing around
cons:
- There seems to be different standards of work throughout the whole store
- Admin staff (located out-of-store in Leeds) are useless- I worked at ASDA for 6 weeks and never received a penny from them until after I left. I have been working elsewhere for nearly 3 weeks now and they still owe me over half of my pay, that's nearly 9 weeks of NO PAY
- They are incredibly slow at getting you registered on the system and say there's nothing they can do about it- this means you will miss paydays and when they pay you there's a high chance you won't be paid correctly so make sure you track your own hours

headline: Customer Service Assistant Part time

headline: ASDA
pros:
Very flexible, can work alongside studies.
Colleagues are very friendly and am in a welcoming environment.
If you want to progress in store, ASDA is willing to invest time in nurturing your skills through step up to section leader or becoming a first aider as some examples.
cons:
Change to contracts recently making it a little more difficult for new-comers to fit work around other aspects of life.
People of power can sometimes abuse it by taking longer breaks and taking holidays when they want.
If the ASDA store has little to no profit, sometimes you don't get  a Christmas party.

location: Washington, North East England, England, England
headline: Very authoritarian
pros: Some good colleagues and decent pay. 10% discount and Christmas voucher plus Christmas lunch.
cons: It boils down to people all in all. The work can be very repetitive and the management never train you up on anything new, just box pick, hanging and replenishment (the latter 2 if you are lucky) and you do this for 8 straight hours. Department and shift managers are just plain lazy and how they ever got to the to where they are is just a joke. All you have to do is say your related to someone who works there and you are in. The favouritism is just rife!! DMs have no people skills and stand at a computer screen all day. All in all managers and some colleagues are just plain jobsworths. I wonder if when they retire or die they will get the Asda guard of honour? Even though pay is good, they impose such tight restrictions on you, they don’t trust you, they constantly think you are trying to rob the place and you are treated with contempt. In conclusion you are either working non stop or you are sat down taking it easy! I’ve refrained from naming individual managers on here despite the temptation

headline: Part time working at Asda
pros: Great firm, lovely people and flexible hours
cons: Pay wasn't great and management could be difficult

headline: Customer service/driver
pros: Slightly flexible that could fit with studying timetable
cons: Shifts are not good e.g. sometimes put you on one hours shifts too and there is no sense of accountability towards employees. Pay is not reasonable compared to responsibility.

headline: Don’t reccomend it
pros: Some of the colleagues were friendly
cons: Was taught poorly for three weeks by different managers how to do things on my shift and when I was caught doing something I had to be retrained. After that I was told I seemed lazy before because suddenly after being trained properly I sped up faster, shocking how learning where things are and the order they go in seems to make a difference!! Also refused to acknowledge doctors note and wouldn’t change hours due to mental illness/ physical complications, absolutely a nightmare  of a company

headline: Customer Service Assistance
pros:
-Very Flexible if you are a student.

cons: #NAME?

headline: A fine part-time job.
pros: Colleagues are more than helpful and usually a joy to be around. There's enough variety in the work to not feel too repetitive. Breaks, general tone, etc. are merciful.
cons: It's likely to be very intimidating at first. No training regimen at all, the fellow staff are expected to help you find your way. Sometimes the end-day cleaning can feel very tedious.

headline: Challenging
pros: Most colleagues at the same level are friendly and willing to help, Pay is exceptional for this type of job (especially for a student)
cons: certain night shift colleagues can be very rude and miserable for example not allowing us to use the lift to bring stock downstairs when we have a short time left on our shift and they have the whole night, constantly giving out overtime that hasn't been asked for instead of hiring new staff (my contract is 21.5 hours a week yet I always get given nearly double this and am expected to be fine with this) due to my department  (produce) being understaffed this causes alot of strain to be put onto evening colleagues as this tends to be the busiest part of the day and often we are expected to have everything ready for the morning colleagues when there are often times either 1 or 2 people working.

headline: excellent place to work
pros:
strong sence of community
excellent benefits
chance for progression
cons:
some unsoicable hours
have to work bank holidays

headline: Colleague
pros:
Simple work
Overtime is available
Some flexibility
cons:
Hypocrisy is rife
Management care more about breaks than managing
Section leaders paid only one pound more for doing the managers job

headline: Security Manager
pros: New Challenge new passion and goals & aims
cons: Not enough challenges and progression

headline: Only as a last desperate resort
pros: Overtime was sometimes available if you required it, flexible work, discount card.
cons: Our Department had a high turnover of new drivers quitting on the basis paid poorly for the amount of tasks they expected, trying to implement rules that were just not practical such as 29 minute early only so if an hour ahead you had to waste 31 minutes sitting around instead of being able to get on with and finish earlier, management was badly managed and any complaint to Section Leaders usually went unheeded meaning had to go above them all the time to get results which resulted in petty behaviour from one certain Section Leader, shifts changed on a dimes notice or if you were meant to finish by a certain time rarely did they actually assign a delivery run that finished at that time and was usually an hour over which had you been allowed to deliver earlier wouldn’t be a problem but again the 29 minute rule came into play, £7.50 wage for what should be a specialised highly paid job especially when it’s our driving license on the line not to mention having to load our own vans when (usually) loading staff were not available due to them not being in/not enough of them or picking orders off the shop floor.

headline: Work

headline: Not the best
pros:
Fairly decent pay £8.50
Discount card for you and a nominated user (has to be someone that you live with)  
Opportunity for overtime
cons:
Unfair unsociable hours - ‘older’ members off staff always finish between 2-5pm younger staff always get 10/11pm finishes. 

Management definitely favour the older colleagues and make it very obvious. Don’t take into consideration other commitments outside the job and still put you in for shifts they know you can’t do and then say there is nothing they can do about it. Speak to you like a piece of dirt sometimes. Genuinely not a nice place to work at times.

headline: The worst place you could possibly work -- i.e I'd rather be on the dole
pros: #NAME?
cons:
- It's an Orwellian nightmare! I was constantly threatened with the sack for "not pulling my weight" when there was no other people around. 
- Rude and ignorant customers, more annoyed because of the wait as there is no staff
- You're just a number to management
- Unsociable hours for not even a living wage (don't even think about paying off those debts!)
- No progression
- Serious injury to eye and the management where falling over themselves "to make sure I was okay" (the claim is still valid by the way ;-) )
- Very depressing environment
- No values or culture
- Poor pay
- Insulting bonus scheme
- CEO keeps going on how he was mentored from a cleaner to CEO (real rags to riches stuff), but it is all lies. Really shows a meritocratic workplace when you hire your cousin as the next CEO by the way(!)
- Would't wish this job on my worst enemy
- No business outlook/ expansion plan

headline: Worst job in my life!
pros: U get a uniform so u dont dirty your clothes
cons: I was constantly singled out, bullied, given unrealistic work loads and departments to work that I wasnt contracted to do and still expected to finish my own department. Followed around the store by management and told I was imagining it when I complained. Forced to complete my shift with a broken finger dat happened in store.  Confidential information was shared around the store and the union reps work  in house so they are biased and share your personal information with management. The stress of that company almost caused me to have a nervous breakdown! Leaving was the best thing I ever did!
