headline: Enjoyable place to work
pros: Paid every 4 weeks (13x a yr) and you don’t load your own van it’s ready waiting for you. Reasonable basic training.
cons:
You cannot choose your own days or hours. These are given to you on you induction. You can at that point say they don’t suite and they will usually offer alternatives. Once you agree to days and hours they cannot be changed.
The maps on the PDA’s are at least 2 yrs out of date so a lot of times you have to use your own phone or sat nav. The routes are pre installed in job order and you can’t change them.
You only get paid for the hours you do (paid up to the minute). If you’re start time is 08.00 to 14.00 but you clock out say 13.41 then that’s when you’re paid to not 14.00.
If you don’t take a break 15mins or 30mins depending on route length then this is deducted from your time even though you worked on to meet customers time windows.

headline: More cons than pros at the moment
pros:
Working from home is more accepted and as a whole business we've now been told we can continue to work from home a few days a week for the foreseeable future. 
More time at home means less of a commute.
Really passionate about diversity
cons:
Across all the head offices, everyone's pay is different everyone is asked to keep it a secret. You could be working there for years and get paid less than someone just coming in. It's also not clear if there is a difference between men and women. No consistency.
In Sept 2020 there was a restructure and it's the worst thing they ever did. Complete shambles. Different structure to Asda which is ridiculous.
No development opportunities anymore and no promoting based on performance.
Bonus is terrible.
Share benefits now cancelled.
Claim to care about mental health but continue to apply the pressure on you.
Levels of progression are hazy.
No fight to keep good staff, most leave to competitors.

headline: bad overall managment, clueless supervisors, if you are a good honest worker: don't go there.
pros: £11/h above most picker similar roles, plenty of overtime, Vocollect makes things easier, discount card, because Vocollect (Honeywell interface dictating tasks) updates performance on real time crook supervisors cannot tamper with your performance. Jungheinrich MHE equipment good, and kept in good shape by in-house maintenance. work gear all supplied, if worn quick replacement.
cons: bad supervisors keep some pickers on odd orders that sometimes difficult or impossible to achieve hourly targets, while biassing easy orders to their lazy friends. GMB reps useless, they just do all that managers tell them, workers are the excuse to grab rep perks. The entrance hall had 5 PCs for public use, then managers started replacing computers upstairs with those allocated to all arguing excuses. Canteen food, no good, don't taste it or you may be putting your health at risk. Kept me 2 years through agency because some good manager allocating interviews for chance to apply to permanent, but 2 years my interviews going to foreign candidates just off their flight. When I caught one of them eating fruit in container bound for loading to store, then my luck changed.

headline: Good company to work at
pros:
Managers are kind, informative, and helpful. They take the time needed to familiarise you with your job duties, catering primarily to student workers. They train you from the beginning and work with you until the end, ensuring you are equipped with valuable skills by the end of your journey with them. 
It is a great environment to work in, challenging yet exciting, and I thoroughly enjoyed my time there.
cons: Sometimes tasks were not explained properly, leading to a few mistakes when I was a new employee, but it was resolved.

headline: Awful place to work
pros: The colleagues are amazing and work really hard.
cons: Lack of colleagues on departments mean the task is impossible unless you kill yourself to do it. Usually received around 20 pallets of stock a day and only had the hours for me and another colleague to work through this on a daily basis. No recognition of hard work as all the recognition goes to managers that talk the talk and sit in the office with the GSM all day. Regional managers haven't got a clue when they come and visit as they are so far out of touch with how to run a store. Ecommerce has become the focal point of asda but no investment into this therefore means they take the only colleagues you have and send them onto there to pick all day no questions asked without been able to transfer wages so therefore cannot get another colleague in. Every manager that I know that currently works there wants to leave and that says it all! Don't work here. I got another job in retail and they don't treat you like a number which they do here.

headline: Enjoyable driving and helping but most management are ignorant and hypocritical
pros: Being out on open road is great. Most colleagues and customers are very decent people and its a rewarding job once away from most management. 10% discount is nice. Talking to interesting customers, seeing the countryside and wildlife, helping elderly and disabled people is rewarding. Drivers especially are mainly a really decent bunch and they help each other. Also, you dont have to think much- its easy! So its a great job for a student-easy money and rest your brain.
cons: Wages low and frequently under correct amount. No apologies. By 5th request they often act to rectify. Overloading. Often no time for breaks though deducted from salary. The equipment is terrible: vans breakdown constantly, palm things to scan stuff badly designed. Advice to any new staff: keep an assiduous log of your hours- there will be mistakes and interestingly never in your favour... Dont engage with management as its not worth it....1984...Just keep records, cover your back and enjoy your job

headline: Stay Away
pros:
The customers
Ten percent discount card? The vending machines?
cons:
During my time at asda I was viciously bullied by a cliquey staff group which included section leaders and management. 
This was my second ever job, starting there when I was only 20yrs old but very early on it started to show how poorly I and a few other younger staff members were thought about. I witnessed this also happen to other members of 'outcast' staff who would quickly leave and find another job. 

I unfortunately stayed around for 2.5yrs, trying to move sections away from the older, nastier ladies (easy 40,50,60yrs old) who when I complained about the bullying were simply 'set in their ways'. It was like school all over again. Nothing was ever done about it, not even when investigations were held into awful situations I was subject too. I cannot remember a week going by without leaving work upset because of some awful remark, snide comment or being laughed at. It wasn't just me, I saw it happen to others too. 

I was given awful jobs no one else wanted to do. Two of my set shifts were finishing at 8pm and starting the next day at 6am (which isn't legal), this was uncontracted overtime that had somehow become permanent. When I tried to drop this, I was told the hours couldn't be moved so I would loose 4hrs a week. I was only on 20hrs do to loose 4 is a big chunk. 

I stayed there for so long due to my confidence being absolutely destroyed and feeling like I had no where else to go. I'd not long moved to the area and I was unfamiliar with my surroundings still, also trying to pay rent and bills at the same time. I was eventually helped move on by a friend. My notice was 1 week and I said bye to the people I worked with, my manager however gave me one last stare and left. No goodbye, nothing. 

I cannot say everyone was bad at asda, I met a few amazing people there who were all there for short periods of time. My notice was 1 week and I literally walked out those doors and never stepped foot back in that horrible, toxic environment. The best thing I ever did was leave. Its definitely left me with a few scars, I was never bullied that badly luckily throughout school, nevermind in a supposed adult environment.

If you're reading this, maybe Tescos hiring instead.

headline: AWFUL.
pros: A fun and quirky atmosphere to work in, its a lovely clean and tidy environment, excellent facilities and provisions (staff room, vending/coffee machines etc), very good training and support is provided, involvement of fun activities/days (best dressed day, beer and pizza day etc), 40% discount IF you are permanent, staff sales are good!
cons: You start off temping through an agency which is just AWFUL. I was there for 2 weeks, was told on the last day in the afternoon not to come back for the third week as I was no longer needed but when more vacancies opened I was asked to go back for a different department and unfortunately had an asthma attack when I was half way overcoming bad flu and ended up in A&E one morning, when I rang in explaining I was told not to go back!!! Extremely unfair and I have never heard of such an unfair dismissal in all my working life, even with my A&E documents they wouldn't give me a chance!

headline: fast paced, reasonable staff perks but retail function undervalued/overworked
pros:
summer fridays - the option to finish at 3pm from june-sept is amazing. sometimes hard to get away if you work in certain functions.

summer social was good fun - free flowing drink and great food and entertainment

great discount - 40% off clothing, 20% off beauty and pretty much next day delivery to HQ - it's pretty great!

approachable and easy to talk to retail management - open to new ideas which is positive and refreshing
cons:
retail function seems undervalued - product/buying aren't overly valued - lack of representation of product at brand strategy. we could be selling credit cards the way the business strategy was presented. it's disappointing coming from Arcadia (TS) where product is king.

remuneration is merely ok - in line with competition but feel the pace of work is much faster and there's a lot more pressure

lack of bonus despite making 45m PROFIT due to not making forecasts set by EXEC BOARD. sales are up double digits on the year so most of the functions have more than over performed

not very inspirational location - morning ton crescent has nothing really going on other than sainsburys/pret for lunch.

headline: No room for progression
pros: 3pm finish on Fridays in summer, great people, 40% discount which is great
cons: No room for progression, management in the production department are just scared of the production director so all decisions are made based on her mood. Also there are politics from working with all young girls

location: Barnsley, Yorkshire and the Humber, England, England
headline: Good people, tough nut to crack
pros: If you work hard you can stay under the radar, nice discount if you manage to nag enough to get one, a good sense of being a team
cons: HR are mostly unresponsive about important issues, hours can get ridiculous, in 2013 we were working 10 hours every flex day for 3 months, wage is low compared to the amount of hard work you have to put in to keep your job....bonus incentives are only for pick/pack/sort despite them not being the most difficult roles. Not enough training programs to help step up to a higher job from low-end despatch, health and safety is often overlooked.

headline: Soul sucking.
pros: The pay was good, but that was only because I was on nights which meant I was getting just above minimum wage, woohoo.
cons: When I was working there we had strict line leaders and shift managers, with pretty unreasonable KPIs to achieve. Accidents and mishaps usually resulted in disciplinary action. The night shift (m ine) was left to handle the leftover NDDs next day deliveries) as well as our own shift load, so naturally with less people we were expected to actually do more, which was unfair.

location: Barnsley, Yorkshire and the Humber, England, England
headline: I didn't enjoy my experience working here.
pros: Some of the team leaders were approachable and it was guaranteed 37.5 hours per week. Music was decent
cons: The rest of the team leaders were underminding and abusive, when there was no list to pick they "made you run up and down 5 floors" instead of taking you to the pod when clearly there were none available on their screen. they never gave you any sort of job satisfaction, I have worked in similar workforces and this had too be the worst. "no talking" I suffered depression working here, walking around, in the dark, alone.

headline: Racist, Sexist Boys Club
pros: Some great people working hard even though all the bonuses have been cancelled and two profit warnings
cons: Nick and his cronies think they are still in their 20's when they are now just dirty old men.  They constantly flirt with all the B&M team and you only get on if you flirt back.

headline: Very unsupportive, unorganised and unhappy company
pros: The office environment is good with perks such as a sample sale.
cons: There is no support from management or hr. Employees from outside the company are ignored and criticised for not knowing the systems, yet almost no training is offered. There are a number of unsupportive managers. Employees, particularly senior employees disappear regularly, for "new opportunities". By disappear I mean they will be there on a Friday and fine on the following Monday. The merchandising processes are not yet equipped to deal with the expansion of the company. There are constant issues and mistakes to deal with and be blamed for daily. This means that the workload becomes overwhelming.  I worked there for six months and saw someone cry every week. It is just not worth it.

headline: Heading downhill for a while
pros:
Good benefits
40% discount
Generally nice people
cons:
1. Political IT managers interested in maintaining their empires
2. Good practice is encouraged but not enforced
3. Poor programme and project management that overrides all concerns on architecture
4. High turnover of new quality staff - they aren't able to effect any change because of point 1.
5. Dysfunctional structure that stops work getting done effectively
6. See the share price and it's still too high

headline: Disgracefully poor executive leadership
pros: The people are generally great, ASOS is a place where you can make lifelong friends, as are the benefits and perks.  Pleasant working spaces and a good location.
cons: We have an Executive team who are in the main ineffective leaders at a time when the business needs strong leadership the most.  They do not have the right experience, a proper strategy or indeed, any clue on what ASOS needs to do as priority in the face of increased competition and declining growth.  They consistently make the wrong decisions and are not listening to their senior teams who know better.  As a consequence, they are rapidly losing credibility (some would say they have already lost it) and the respect of their teams.

headline: If you care about technology, don't work at ASOS
pros:
Good benefits and perks
Relaxed enviornment
cons:
Terrible IT senior management who have no clue about how to deliver software
So many politics going on and people get away with anything
Plenty of untalented staff

headline: Poor leadership
pros: Nice offices with good facilities, great benefits and perks such as 40% staff discount, and a strong training and development programme.
cons: Exceptionally poor leadership in the board room.  It would not be unfair to describe the execs as a team of lost wandering souls who are directionless, out of touch with their employees, business and customers, and with no proper strategy for how they're going to turn the business around.  They are clutching at straws and their only saviour are their employees who they're choosing to ignore.  The execs are only interested in their own egos, the size of their pay packet, and one-upmanship over each other.

headline: ASOS brand deteriorating
pros: Staff discount, good people, fun social life
cons: Not a pleasant working environment if you're ambitious and smart.  There is too much emphasis on editorial and not enough on growing the brand properly.  I don't have much confidence that the senior marketing team really know what they're doing and I'm not the only one who feels this way.  Generally, it's political and gossipy here.  I'm just getting my head down whilst I look for another job.

headline: An awful place to work
pros: The discount was fine. Summer hours. The bonus, when it happened, was nice.
cons: No room for progression. Politics matters moreso than being good at your job. Higher ups don't know what they want, are obsessed with a slither of the department  - to the detriment of the rest of the department. Bosses are hired on their ability to say the right things rather than their ability in general, leading to teams having to essentially manage themselves. Unrealistic targets and expectations. Work is underpaid and management take the view that you should be happy you have a job at all. Any attempts to achieve a work/life balance are noted as 'not caring about the job'. The general culture is a bullying, sniping atmosphere.

headline: Needs a total overhaul of leadership/strategy
pros: People, salary, perks, sphere of influence, social. Passionate employees despite the setbacks. Interesting work.
cons: Very poor exec leadership, long hours, politics, backstabbing, poor and inefficient structure. Sexist language common.

headline: Excellent Fast Pace Company
pros: Friendly, fun, sample sales, discount codes, summer party, Christmas party, Friday beers, 5 hours Fridays during summer, casual smart dress code, lots of benefits, wonderful C level exec
cons: Could do with training the LOB managers to be more proactive as opposed to reactive! Poor knowledge management!

headline: Chaotic, individualistic, hardworking
pros: Great brand, opportunity to trial new innovative tech or strategies, great staff discount on all products. Many motivated smart colleagues. Fairly funky office.
cons: In a word politics. It happens in every office but in my experience it's particularly disruptive here where it's combined with the egos, individualistic attitude and the insecurity that  breeds in this environment. It also doesn't help that around two or three people are employed to do broadly the same role without boundaries. The motto is collaboration. The reality is kill or be killed.

cons: Politics are brutal - you need to be in with the in crowd and drink with the right guys to get ahead. Aggressive approach from the top sadly filters down in many places.

cons:
No personal career development at all. 

Once you're in you're on your own when it comes to learning something new, promotion or salary increase.

Lots of politics. One needs to be friends with the right people in order to succeed.

Team structure very rigid. Almost impossible to switch teams or roles.

headline: Very interesting technology environment, fast being swallowed up management incompetence and personality cult
pros:
Generally very good life balance and hours. Fridays finish at 5 instead of 5.30 and for three months of the year you get to finish at 3pm and enjoy the summer. Last Friday of the month the company puts on free beers for staff. Also a good thing.

Generally a very good, close IT development department with many highly skilled and clever people pushing each other to expand their knowledge.

The company covers some really interesting technologies and there were opportunities to learn lots about emergent tech trends which could shape the site and various tech products in the company further. This "give it a go" attitude is something they should be proud of.

Fortnightly sample sales are good but over the years less good stuff was in them - I think the buyers themselves started to take anything they want home for themselves.
cons:
For a company where it's shop window and everything behind it relies totally on IT, the directors seem to know soo little about IT and as a result have gone through a chain of hiring sociopath to sociopath to be in charge of large parts of or all of IT over the years. They want a new, interesting company like ASOS to be linked to their career and use big names of other (often much more stuffy) business to get in through the door, then pull the IT department back into the 20th century. 

The worst one was a recent CIO hire who started with a statement of intent of who they are and what they want to and don't want to do. Very quickly each of these promises was broken. Even worse, heads under them were replaced by people they had worked with in every company from the past 6-10 years of their career. These people were not brought in on merit. The result was a very strong cult of personality driving people out of the company, a swelling contract budget (more mates brought in) and importantly very little credible, long term value to the business. Having worked at the company for a long time it made me sick to see such a sought after and popular company get taken in by these people.

Not unusual I know but HR really are the pits, smiling assassins but dressed up to the nines.

headline: Senior Business Analyst in Mobile / Digital domain
pros: Friendly environment. Opportunities to learn and develop new skills
cons: IT projects lack speed and agility sometimes.

headline: Very chaotic, no direction, incompetent.
pros:
- Youthful staff - if you are in your 20s or 30s you'll be a good fit
- Staff discount - it can save you a lot of money if buy lots of clothes
- Colleagues - you can meet many decent people
cons:
- Management - they had no idea what they were doing - it was a real mess and they didn't listen
- Career development - the performance review process is really bad and not based on merit. Also, you can expect to be boxed into a job and not being allowed to get involved in anything else at all
- Technology - messy, old, things barely work and frequently break

headline: International business is a joke -- beware!
pros:
Generous salary
Nice benefits (including 40% off discount for employees)
Annual bonus
401K
Company still viewed as "cool" by outsiders (despite being run by a team of clueless middle managers)
cons:
First time in my professional career I've ever seen this sort of back stabbing and cattiness 
People who get rewarded aren't the ones working hard or coming up with great ideas
Company's shaky financial reports led to a lot of internal speculation and paranoia 
Great job for younger people who don't mind the workload, stress and hours (especially during "peak")
If you're working in an international office then forget about job stability or having a budget to work with

headline: Too much work with not enough pay
pros: Working day is 9-5pm, goes quickly and an opportunity to be somewhat creative
cons: Tense atmosphere, newcomers are more or less ignored and not showed around properly. Far too much work to get through in one day, with low freelance rates - you're expected to work like a machine, and made to feel inadequate if there is a mistake. People seem uninterested, fake and cliquey.

headline: Disorganised, unfriendly and over-confident
pros:
Looks good on cv 
Great discount
cons:
Unfriendly colleagues - cliquey atmosphere
Disorganised chaos of clothing in the buying department - barely enough space to get desk
Managers are too wrapped up in themselves with no real idea of what is going on in their team

headline: It was fun experience where I was challenged and gain a lot in insight in communications, marketing, and fashion.
pros: Creative atmosphere, fun co workers. Well established leadership, and well insight into the field and industry.
cons: Challenging benefits, difficult bureaucracy.

headline: really good environment
pros: good team and great culture in the company
cons: begins to be more corporate and more difficult to interact

headline: Lack of progression
pros: Discount, Summer hours, Good Socials, Inspring strategy days from exec team
cons: Absolutely no progression when you start from the bottom, expect you to work flat out for nothing, rather take in people externally than progressing people who devote years to the company

headline: asos needs a direction!
pros: staff discount and sample sale
cons: bureaucracy, hierarchy, low salary, NO DIRECTION, politics, inefficiency, hr department disastrous

headline: Amazing job, laid back friendly atmosphere
pros: All employees are treated well and respected at every level, great social environment, work-hard play-hard ethos
cons: Some of the internal systems are frustrating to use, often required to work long hours but rewarded for hard work in other ways and always appreciated!

headline: Vibrant, fast-paced environment building massive-scale solutions on leading edge tech
pros:
Despite having been around for 15 years, the atmosphere is young and vibrant and ASOS actively and successfully maintains its small-company feel.

As a technologist, working at such a huge scale is really rewarding. ASOS handles over 2 billion page hits per month and delivers more than a parcel a second to 240+ countries around the world, so the technology is vital to the success of the business. 

Good people who are dedicated, motivated and work together.

Good benefits, 40% staff discount, sample sales

Summer hours - 3pm finish on Fridays from June-August! Friday beers and lots of other events.
cons:
No BYOD policy. 

Still some cumbersome systems and processes in place but getting better all the time. 

It's in a listed building so the plumbing can be a bit flaky and getting a lift to the 6th floor can be a long business.

headline: Fast Paced, Focus and Effeciency Improvements Needed
pros:
Some really great people work for ASOS and some brilliant ideas are available to generally help improve the working environment.
They want to be a family type business that looks after their employees, supported by excellent benefits.
cons:
So much is going on it's a struggle for team and programmes to keep track and on top of things.
Changing direction quickly and context switching is hard.
IT is seen as a burden on the business.

headline: I love working for ASOS
pros: Great culture, fast paced, creative environment, chance to get your ideas heard and to make a difference
cons: Rapid change is great but it's hard for the resources and systems to keep ahead of what's needed

headline: Asos
pros: good 40% discount and parties
cons: Cattiness, lots of clueless middle management

location: Barnsley, Yorkshire and the Humber, England, England
headline: picker,packer plus feeder
pros: got paid weekly most of the people where friendly and helpfull
cons: if no work got sent home or not to come in and did not get paid for this if you had any holidays you had to use them to make your pay up

headline: Great place to work
pros:
Brand is super strong and customers and sales keep growing incredibly fast. 
Great environment with lots of young people and friendly management. 
Working in the Mobile team is a great experience as it is where all the company focus is now and the whole team is very skilled and motivated.
cons: As any business growing very fast there are some challenges to deal with such as not very helpful processes or some legacy technologies to improve

headline: sweat shop
pros: 25% discount on clothes and 20% on other items, meeting new people and thats all the pros there is
cons: Not family friendly as i got a shift i could work round my son then our shift was told they were not doing the 16 hour shifts anymore and we had to pick a different shift and if we didnt pick a shift we could do then the team leader would pick it for you, we were given the options of what shifts were avaliable and told to pick one there and then, without consulting our partners or seeing if we could get child care, it was only when we told the teamlearder we need more time to make arrangments that he caved in and gave us till our next shift to decide, it has been over a month since we put our shift change in and still have not heard when we will be changing shifts

headline: Great atmosphere and support
pros: Lots of support both personally and for ideas. innovative attitude
cons: Salaries are mid to low, unless you're in sales

location: Barnsley, Yorkshire and the Humber, England, England
headline: Warehouse Operative
pros: regular work for full time employees, free WiFi in canteen.
cons: you may have to walk 10 miles in a shift, power hungry lower management, very high temperatures in summer 30 degrees+ , no allowed to settle in one environment constantly moved around to where workers required either receiving,put away,returns,hygiene,pick, pack, dispatch etc each with its own kpi that you have to achieve or face a disciplinary even if you have an accident you face a full investigation, alcohol and drug tests then another disciplinary, if you have time off due to genuine sickness they do not believe you and you face the occupational safety nurse to find out what you can do! If you suffer from asthma or any other lung/respiratory complaint don't bother as the dust and heat will put you in hospital.Poor Health and Safety every week there is a new regulation that you have to adhere to now we have to ware glove's for all "dangerous" conditions.The local doctors have two common ailments the ASOS cough (caused by the dust0 and the ASOS bad back (caused by the heavy work). Not that I can't do it I'm an ex miner but it is punishing running up and down five flights of stairs constantly!!

headline: Asos
pros: Good working environment.  Decent benefits
cons: Can be political and cliquey

headline: Good if you want to retire or just want to be nice and comfy
pros: People are nice. Good work /life balance. One can do what you want.
cons:
People have the "I don't really care " attitude to work
No training whatsoever
Outdated tools
Cold office
Salaries rises are given based on favouritism. One may get thousands the other pity pennies.(fact)
Middle management has no management skills
No room for progression
Full of people bored who can't really bother hence nothing ever gets done
Rules are not same for all
Performance at work is an utter joke. One may get an above and beyond by doing little, though that doesn't translate into more money so why should one bother?

headline: If you want to succeed in life, look elsewhere
pros:
Free tea and coffee
Small selection of free fruit
Ample parking
cons:
No real career progression and you sense the company prefers employees with no ambition so they don't complain about the poor pay and lack of opportunities.
Staff are treated much like children.

headline: Good benefits
pros: Good staff discount, work life balance and opportunity to work on new technologies in a good team.
cons: Too many layers of middle management that don't fully understand what the team they are managing actually does.

headline: Thick skinned only!
pros: Good discount, lots of little perks like 3pm finish in summer on Friday. Friendly casual environment. Sample Sales. Very good Christmas and summer parties (if you like that sort of thing)
cons: Although they have some good ideas for their website and offer hundreds of products, undercover IT is a mess and at risk of falling apart. The culture is very immature and you are more likely to get on well if you stand outside the office smoking or go drinking lots.  there is  a real lack of structure and process which means they do things quickly but end up doing it twice or doing it wrong because there's a lack of clear strategic planning. the top guys are well though of, the bottom rung work hard, but those in the middle - no one seems to know what they are doing. There's a big bullying culture here. And you need to be very thick skinned to survive. There's a very high turnover for a reason. people leave without even having jobs to go to, just to get out. ASOS wants to keep the young start up mentality, but they really could benefit from growing up a little.

headline: Fashion Assistant
pros: Great discount and laid back working environment.
cons:
Progression and development. 
Impossible processes & systems.

headline: QA Engineer
pros: Bonus, Good Benefits,Work hard play hard culture
cons: Team/Department Politics, Lack of knowledge sharing across domains

headline: Technology department operation
pros: Very flexible with regards to being able to release software in production environments with very little lead time required, therefore supports the agile framework of shipping software more frequently.
cons: The environment in the IT department seems to be that anything goes with regards to how things get done - resources poached from other teams to help get things done, last minute releases/fixes etc

headline: Great office, good vibe
pros:
Office recently refurbished - fresh and buzzing
lots of hip creative types
friendly IT team
Forward thinking
Onside canteen, coffee shop
free tea/coffee/milk/fruit
Sample sales great
onsite showers
onsite fitness classes and lockers
cons:
Canteen really expensive
Coffee shop should be subsidised

headline: Amazing place to work but senior management is dis functional.
pros: The people.  The office is a beautiful layout. Lots of employee perks such as personal trainer, spa packages and employee sales.
cons: Senior management was a real challenge to engage with.  They need to do more to integrate sustainability into their core business model.

headline: So refreshing to be in a company like ASOS!
pros:
Collaborative company where you feel truly cared about. I was so surprised when I joined ASOS at just how different the environment was to other places I'd worked. I already knew a few people that worked at ASOS and asked them what they thought of the company before I made my decision to join. The feedback from them was a resounding 'they really look after you' and that's exactly what I've experienced.

Opportunity to grow  quickly within the company, flexible hours and just trusting employees in general, good basic salary for the retail industry, great package, from flexi cash and bonus all the way to more niche things like bicycle scheme and holiday vouchers and having your birthday off work.

Amazing like-minded people who don't treat you as competition but as colleagues and friends, a company and brand to feel proud of, exciting things happening within the business and being able to feel proud of it.

Cool company feel and office space, awesome canteen, really buzzing and exciting atmosphere to be in. 

Strong feeling that the Exec really care about the company which in return makes you really care. The CEO is in the office every day working like everyone else. He doesn't even have his own office, but sits in an open-plan amongst the rest of the employees.

The work ASOS are doing in CSR- the fact we have our own foundation and do tons of charity work is a massive plus for me. Working in a fashion company you can sometimes feel that what you're doing might not, in fact, 'really matter'. ASOS has such a focus on its charity work and every year sends its employees out to help build schools for homeless children in India, and wells in villages in Africa. They also encourage people to raise money all-year round, and are constantly organising fundraising events. It makes you feel really proud to be part of a company that focuses so much on doing good.
cons: Can sometimes feel like there is so much we want to do and talk about doing, yet don't physically have the time to do it because of how fast-paced the environment is. I guess that's just down to prioritising workload.

location: Barnsley, Yorkshire and the Humber, England, England
headline: Worker in warehouse
pros: not to sign on at job centre
cons:
This is my experience. If your pay is wrong there is little comeback. As regards flex hours you may be expected to begin shift two hours early at a moments notice and in spite of accumulating hours many employees' were asked to pay back hours! Ironically some were told to give back a week in overtime despite never being involved in any flex. When questioned HR would say they had access to information unavailable to Team Leaders rendering the Team Leader function a tad pointless. I feel HR didnt have control of the hours since being taken over twice.
Oh and the handscanners are faulty so even though you can arrive in the car park 15mins early, by the time you use the clock in system inside it can reset and then go past the time expected in by a few seconds. Then the company charge you 15mins of pay for lateness.
Targets are so high you can only achieve them by nearly breaking your neck, and if you have an accident you jeapordise employment. Good employees are treated like something on the bottom of your shoe, the lazy ones do well amazingly. Shift Managers waltz around like the second coming but I had no respect for the ones on despatch pick or pack. A Team Leader on Nights was the only one I respected but he's gone. Shame as now he has gone we have no one who takes us seriously, or treats us with dignity. Poor employer to work for.

headline: Dynamic and exciting
pros: Great benefits, nice people, constantly growing, sample sales and parties.
cons: Sometimes monotonous work, not much room for progression, everybody is very young.

headline: IT
pros:
Sample sale. 
Staff discount. 
Summer Fridays. 
Monthly Beers. 
Really good people working in IT and the business!
cons:
Middle management politics! Too many contractors in IT for a very long time.
Too many people trying to protect their own programs instead of looking at the bigger picture. 
PMO could be utilise a lot more. Less politics and more direction leaders is needed.

headline: IT
pros: Great company and great benefits. One of best places I worked in before certain appointments were made. Done great talent in middle and lower management.
cons: CTO has issues. Either your part of his inner circle or he has no time for you. He knows best. Breaks the rules according to what suits him ( some very unethical ones) .Everyone else seems scared to disagree. Lost a lot of good people and will keep losing at this rate. Very political environment and rather cut throat. To survive basically dont challenge and query.

headline: ASOS
pros: Great company but it feels like its lost its sparkle in the last two years - its getting too corporate. Its a shame.
cons: Too many Heads of Dept and too many getting promoted for who they know not what they know. Feels like you need to be a member of the good old boys club to further your career.

headline: Excellent employer.
pros:
Great people 
Exposure to senior management/board
High growth business
Innovation
Excellent benefits
Well remunerated
Staff discount
Ownership of ideas
Constantly evolving
cons:
High growth business
Constant pressure
Changing properties

headline: Want to see what else is out there
pros: The office had a Relaxed atmosphere. Get to work with Friendly and interesting people. Good progression structure. Good parties! Great discount.
cons: Cost and time of commuting. Systems can make work a bit manual and frustrating. Communication from management could be improved

headline: senior manager
pros: Great environment to work. Very vibrant and ambiguous
cons: Who likes you matters alot. Some people get away easily with no talent

headline: A job you dread
pros:
Staff perks are great; discount, sample sales, great canteen. 
Some nice people.
cons: The lack of management direction has staff frigtened. Genuinely dread coming into work every day because of the blame game. Everyone is just out to cover their back and hope the finger gets pointed at someone else. Your manager doesn't have your back because they're too busy defending themselves to their boss then the problems flow downwards.

headline: great place to work
pros:
benefits are the best I have ever received. Flex bens allowance, pension etc and then the extras like the 40% discount, stall sample sales, summer hours, beauty rooms in house, fitness classes in the basement. I think staff  can sometimes take all that for granted. 

social place. 
Allows you to be individual and contribute ideas. 

Informal work space and open environment - maybe not for everyone
cons: some silly behaviors - immaturity at management level but think they need some training in how to deal with certain situations.

headline: PA & Senior Buyers Assistant
pros:
Fashion leader
Fashion leader
Online Company
No Shop Front
cons:
Clicky environment
Poor Salary
Long Hours
Slow Progression

headline: Software Engineer
pros: Buy clothes at bargain prices.
cons: Open plan offices are too noisy.

headline: Great discount and colleagues, shame about a few members of management
pros:
40% discount 
Amazing Christmas and Summer parties
You'll make friends for life
cons:
Management not listening to staff 
Management thinking they are better than staff and having "favourites"

headline: Pathetic IT work culture
pros: I don't see any good reasons to work in the IT department
cons: Amazingly immature management. Whole IT team has talent in playing blamegames. Unethical behvaiour

headline: Lack of direction
pros: Asos creates a fun environment which is full of passionate people. Most people are really behind the great brand and the discount! the socials are great and the company has great ambitions. It provides a great culture for young first jobbers.
cons: Has a lack of direction, the company has many good ideas but due to high turnover at the top the plan is constantly changing. This can be frustrating for those wanting to see projects through to the end. It also means that you will work long hours. Whilst there are some great people there is also a lot of politics at the top.

headline: good for a start
pros: Not the worst wage ever
cons: They offer contact after 1 year, bad management

headline: Progressive
pros: Rapidly growing organisation which is on the up, tech in particular is evolving and improving, good atmosphere, perks (staff discount!), good location.
cons: The fact that its rapidly growing and evolving means it's a fast paced environment which may not suit everyone.

headline: If your face fits you'll do just fine
pros:
At ASOS it's all about who you get on with and not neccessarily about the quality of your work. 
Pro's are the parties.
The atmosphere is quite fake nice - as in they say they're generating lots of fun but it's all a bit of a guise
The office is nice and the discount is very generous.
cons:
You're expected to put in very long hours and be on call 24/7. 
The senior teams are very particular about who they favour and if you're not one of them, then you wont progress. 
Other people in the business would go behind your back if it means they can get ahead.  
Promotions are not based on value add to the business or quality of work.
Flirting is seen as an acceptable way to win promotion.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Great environment, there is clear team work and everyone really helps each other
cons: Short breaks, lack of communication from SM

headline: Exciting British success story
pros:
- A dynamic company built from the ground up
- Very nice offices in an Art Deco building in Camden; great area to have lunch in
- Excellent discounts for staff: you become the most popular person in your friend group!
cons:
- Back when I worked there, management could be pretty inconsistent (perhaps because the CEO still had a wheeler-dealer mentality)
- Lots of middle-manager empire-building
- Notoriously bad at handling maternity leave: virtually no-one found their job intact on return
- No career opportunities at all: internal promotion about as rare as a Yeti's dodo

headline: Customer Care Advisor - Hemel
pros: Easy. Well paid. Good overtime opportunities.
cons: Poorly managed. Lack of respect. 'Kids managing kids', team leaders upwards seem to be on a power trip. It's not what you know, it's who you know.

headline: Inconsistent - can be heaven or hell, depends where you fell
pros:
Great offices, good benefits package, being part of constantly evolving young and successful company.
Young people, relaxed atmosphere.
cons:
Young people, inexperienced management. No clear progression plan, favouritism and lack of HR'S support when needed. Constantly understaffed people are stretched to their limits, long hours are a standard, especially on retail floor. 
Bullying goes unnoticed as long as brings results

headline: ASOS is a great company- but Customer Care was hell
pros: Perfect Company  all you can wish for, Canteen,, shower facilities, regents park not far and paid overtime !! basically free access to the building 24/7 if you wish to work - whenever you like to-love that
cons: I worked in the Customer Care team in London which was consisting out of 12-15 people from 5 different countries. We were the special advisors. My country team consisted of 3 people. One colleague was always listened to but us other 2 we were treated very special-. Throughout the whole team information was given only to the people who were good with the manager. we had 2 swaps within one year- the first leader really convinced me to speak about  if i would have a problem with my colleague. i said no cause I think these things need to resolve themselves -but he asked me in every one to one about it so that i thought he is interested and then I said what i do not like. Then the whole thing started. it broke up our team- instead of resolving it was always belived this one apparently only one knowledgeable member of the team and I feel betrayed for having said anything. Kept quiet went on working, Teamleader swap - became worse- the whole situation evolved again and that special person in our team got attention and everything and even in meetings with i higher perosn from the department the problem was not solved! It intoxicated my whole last months at ASOS becuase u felt like 2nd class people. Also in my reviews silly excuses were found that I do not reach the WELL DONE you need in order to be acknowledged or move to a different department whcih was my goal. I was not well done because I did a gap between a hiven and a capital letter and stuff like like this . I was always punctual or even over punctual at ASOS but even that meant nothing. The special person could be late 4 times a week ( yes we started counting and noted stuff) and they had always more cigarette breaks than others. Even behaving acc to the rules the next comment in my review was: You are better but still not welll done. No comment why on how instead poking on being sick one day! Was really not fair- felt useless with my colleague after a while and why they need us if the other person is so GREAT! This person btw was reluctant to show us stuff and always with a sigh and when I complained about it.they made a fuss ! Sorry for all these comments but I had a hell of 8 months there ( 3 were ok) and I seeked help but there was no support. and I want to make clear that this happened for Customer Care Specialists only! I love ASOS and what they offer to their employees really- by far the best I have seen. I left with a helpless sad and positive eye! I did not really want to leave but I needed to get out it affected my personal life and confidence.

headline: ASOS culture
pros: fabulous young face environment...for those who love, fashion, technology and media...plus many more
cons: can be all consuming...manage your time well and you will get the rewards

headline: Great
pros: Benefits are fantastic. 40% off website
cons: Too many leaders. Desks are too small

headline: Terrible culture
pros: The discount is good at 40%. The products are high fashion. The location is good at Camden. The parties are fun if you stay away from the disgusting behaviour
cons:
Who you know, the length of your skirt and how much time you spend drinking at the pub is a factor in your career progression. 

Egotistical CEO and technology management suck.

Why did all the technology women leaders leave - simply a boys club !

headline: Great, Young, Vibrant, Fun, ASOS Culture
pros:
- Amazing work culture, very laid back they just let you get on with it.
- Loads of benefits, 40% off items on the website, sample sale every Friday.
- Summer/Winter work parties which are the best I've ever seen. 
- Great location, unique building which they are upgrading.
- The teams I work within are really good, everyone helps each other 
- Friday end of month beers, which usually has a theme and added extras.
- Great place to work if your young as there is a strong social atmosphere. 
- some managers are really approachable and like to get involved.
- CEO seems really fun, and everyone has a desk in an open plan working environment even senior management.
- work from home at times depending on which teams you work in
- loads of ASOS incentives to get involved with, has a strong start up feel even though were quite large.
- On site canteen, even though I'm not a fan of it I know some people are
- Some really good people work in I.T. 
- Seen as a really cool company to work for
cons:
- Politics at senior management level
- IT Changes are sometimes rushed through without proper testing
- Turnover in I.T., there are some really good people who left.
- Some teams/people can be quite clicky. team building activities could help with that.

headline: Don't get too comfortable...
pros:
40% Discount
Weekly Sample Sale
Really good team atmosphere
cons:
Feedback not accurate
Consistently criticised and not praised for what is done right
Just a head's up, they will say "can we have a chat?" Take you off the floor for a couple minutes in front of everyone then tell you you're fired and have someone collect your things and literally show you the door. Happend to 20 people in the same day from different teams. The job is not secure considering most people who were being "let go" were only there for 1 or 2 months. Even being 1 minute late 3 times can cause you to be fired. You've been warned.

headline: Busy but amazing!
pros:
- Always busy, never a dull moment
- so much fun!
- amazing leadership and exec team, always up for a laugh, so down to earth
- great team
- relaxed atmosphere
- so much room for creativity
- ASOS really harness and love individuality
- great career movements and career paths
- London canteen food is amazing!
cons:
- not global thinking enough sometimes
- sometimes fun comes before business!
- workload is mad not giving you much time to think or be strategic on occassions

headline: ASOS
pros: fun, good work perks, opportunity to progress
cons: catty, negative towards assistant levels, a lot of overtime, lazy assistant buyers

headline: Great company with growing pains...
pros:
I work on the IT side of things which I believe has matured and developed greatly over the last 18 months or so. ASOS is growing it's internal capabilities and investing in its people which is always nice to see.

The people are great - almost everyone is extremely competent and has a collaborative, can-do attitude. The social side of things is also quite impressive.

I find the work varied and interesting - there is opportunity to grow and move teams (Not everyday obviously! But if you are keen to be involved in something else they will make every effort to accommodate you)
 
Location is good - Camden for food, pubs and shops. Regents park for lunch time walk / run. Tube and bus stops directly outside of the office.

The whole place buzzes and feels like an organisation on the up - which is great!
cons:
Asos has been growing rapidly for the last few years and the London office is starting to run out of space - they have plans to address this, but they're a few months away at best so things are a bit cramped at the moment.

The business can be a bit woolly in what it wants to achieve - there is clarity from the exec board about their vision, but it gets a bit muddled at the next layer down when it comes to implementing that strategy. They get there eventually but possibly not in the most efficient way. There are signs that the new CEO recognizes this and is making some people changes

Food - Some people rave about the canteen and its food, I find it often to be overly complex and 'lah-di-dah' for the money. Still you're only 5 mins walk from a whole bunch of great places to eat or buy a sandwich so ...

headline: Great place to work!
pros: What I love most about ASOS is the culture. Its a fun environment to work in and everyone is really supportive. ASOS activly encourage your development and if you are willing to work hard the opportunities are there for you to grab. Staff parties are amazing! There are lots of little incentives and rewards that make staff feel appreciated. Very blessed to work for such a great company!
cons: It can be very fast paced at times and some struggle to keep up! It is really busy which isn't for all, but I enjoy the constant buzz around the office!

headline: ASOS is an amazing place to work
pros:
- Ample opportunity to add value and have impact in your role
- Ideas are welcomed and encouraged
- Very collaborative culture
- The leadership team is very accessible and friendly
- Flexible working environment
- Total ownership over your work, you're not micromanaged or told you cannot do something
- Fantastic benefits - summer hours where we can finish at 3pm, weekly staff sample sales, 40% discount off the website
cons:
- There's not enough space - desks are small and meeting rooms are always booked out
- Things change...A LOT. I wouldn't recommend ASOS to someone who is not flexible or someone who doesn't like change
- It can get very intense, it's busy all the time but mainly because people are really passionate about what they do

Over worked and under paid. Expected to work 12 hour days without  recognition or reward.
I faced bullying from my manager, who made my life a misery by constantly putting me down and funnelling  her stress onto me and basically made my life hell. I reported her to HR but they didn't resolve anything.  Basically.. if you get on with your manger and he/she gets on with their manger you will be fine. if not you will have a tough time.

cons: Bad press which is a shame as the company seems to want the best for all it's employees and if there is a problem there are plenty of people that would love to get involved to change that.

headline: Heading Off from ASOS but enjoyed it....
pros:
The culture still keeps aspects of when it was a smaller company - summer working hours, bringing forward pay dates for holiday, usually good work life balance. 

In the last couple of years especially in technology seen a lot of positive improvements in both the consistent priorities, platform teams being introduced and an introduction of more experienced middle managers

People are generally fun to work with

Think they pay well
cons: Some areas still need a bit of improvement - such as in the QA leadership and some areas of the PMO. However I believe these are being addressed

headline: Great Employeer
pros: ASOS has to be one of the most amazing Employers i have ever worked for they are very fair and everyone who works there is extremely friendly and the benefits are amazing! not including the parties which by the way are the wildest company parties i have ever been to. ASOS is nothing short of amazing!
cons: Honestly i cannot think of any cons to working for ASOS that i have had even under the most stressful of times such as the site being down everything is handled amazingly and there is no real blame just learning experiences.

headline: Challenging and exciting
pros: Probably the best company I've ever worked for and for such a massive organisation it somehow manages to feel like a really (really) big family. Everyone is very open and you quickly start to feel like you belong. Ethically, ASOS feels like a company that cares about the world and the impact it makes which makes you feel good working there.  There's a general positive attitude, a feeling that the company is always on the up and innovating.  I'm never bored, always challenged and excited about what's coming next but in between working hard, everyone has a really good laugh and knows how to let their hair down.
cons: There's not quite enough space for all the new people but they're working on it. Also, sometimes being a big company makes it hard to get things done as quickly as they could be.

headline: ASOS
pros: Some friendly people who are willing to help. Discount. Not stressful job if you learn fast.

headline: Positive on the whole
pros: I worked in the Hemel customer service office for around 18 months. It was a nice office, straight forward job and had, generally, a nice friendly atmosphere.
cons: Questionable appointments to team leader roles, to say the least. This side of the company was expanding fast, so I can appreciate the need to fill the roles quickly, but it really was a case of whoever applied for such a role were either given it or asked to fill the role in probation form. It's great that they tried to promote from within, but some of the people were just not suitable for managerial type roles. It's as simple as that. Also towards the end of my time, they began to start taking privileges away from staff, in the name of efficiency. Not the way to motivate your staff or get them on side.

I know that this may come across as sour grapes, but I am fairly certain that this rot will be there for many more years to come, which is why I had to leave.

headline: Poor
pros: I really can't think of any. Management are a joke, health and safety is a joke, the job is monotonous, targets are unrealistic, pay is dire, conditions are worse.
cons: As above. Specifically, a lack of easily available drinking water, broken toilets, staff treated as machines, no progression opportunities, extreme micro management.

headline: Working in Tech
pros: Projects are interesting and using the latest technology is not frowned up.  The innovation and enthusiasm is there and the projected growth is ambitious.
cons:
Working in Tech from a management/employee perspective is awful. There are a handful of really good managers who care about their staff. However, the others are simply greasy pole climbers who want to dine at the CEO's table and will do what it takes to get there. 

There is no clear direction regards where is Tech is going. A likeable CIO has been unluky to have inherited a group of children to guide him. Am not going to mention names but avoid and Enterprise Architecture like the plague as it has caused more problems than solutions and if you want to commit career suicide, join Service Operations. A truly rank function that wouldn't know its backside from its elbow.

headline: Horrendous Ordeal!
pros:
Sample Sales
The Summer and Christmas parties if you're a permanent staff member - You're not invited if you're a temp
cons: Myself and several others I know, have had a terrible experience with bullying here! The name calling, nasty remarks, rumours and career progression sabotage doesn't just stop with other customer advisors, some of the team leaders and senior staff also enjoy getting involved! During my ordeal here, I suffered with workplace depression, this was just labelled as attention seeking or drama. If I, or others tried to confide in management about the bullying it would just result in victim blaming and you'd be seen as the problem! An older team leader would often send inappropriate messages to young advisors, I too received these and was later pestered for a date. I was treated badly and humiliated here right up to the end of my last day. It really was awful! After leaving, I needed counselling for depression and anxiety. I am still affected by the experience now. I have heard from remaining employees that the bullies have found new victims and so it continues.

headline: Best Company I've Ever worked for

- Amazing staff perks and benefits, you feel truly looked after and cared about.

- investment in staff progression, you feel like you're further building your career 
- Treat us like humans which is really refreshing- you have the ability to manage your own time and no micro-managing. Definitely a feeling of trust
- Everyone genuinely treats each other with respect, there's a lack of hierarchy so you can literally talk to anyone fromentry level to the CEO

headline: Not perfect, but it's one of the best companies I've worked for
pros: ASOS is a very good company. They use some of the latest technologies and provide training courses when required. A lot of very talented people and very good benefits, including a great discount on their website and sample sales. Nicely located near Camden with tons of restaurants, pubs and with a tube station across the street. Great to have ASOS on your cv as well. Leads and Principals are great individuals that aim to make our jobs easier and more rewarding.
cons:
Salary is not great, although it's adequate if we consider the benefits.
Sometimes there are a lot of bureaucracies and a bit of disparity between teams in the technology department. Deadlines are sometimes not realistic and quality can suffer because of that.

headline: Great company to work for
pros:
- Great collaborative and creative culture
- People are motivated
- The product being sold is great
- Training, learning and development opportunities are great. Great investment in people
- People managers are very relatable
- Amazing support is extended to you if your work life balance is not optimal
cons:
- Rapidly expanding company so culture shift is happening, but that means more responsibility on people to self manage themselves and their careers (so not really a con but still watch out)
- Not much governance and processes in place so larger projects tend to be frustrating to work on

headline: Fun place to work in a rapidly expanding the business with loads of potential!
pros:
Great culture and fun and challenging place to work that looks after you, gives lots of opportunities to develop  yourself, if you take them, and promotes from within. Loads of opportunities to get involved in voluntary or other initiatives out side of your normal day job. 

Rapidly expanding business so any team you join is likely to keep on growing giving you loads of potential to grow. 

Rapidly improving tech stack , that gives lots of you a chances to work on the latest technologies. 

Great parties, for summer and Xmas, and reduced hours on Fridays in the summer so you can leave at 3pm!
cons: At the moment there is quite a bit of building works on the office to cater for the expanding workforce, so it maybe noisy at times.

headline: Awesome, with its Challenges...
pros:
- Great energy across the business.
- The best concentration of technical people I have seen in one place.
- Big on cloud-first - everything is going blue, I mean Azure.
- Really good technical challenges, high volume and an overall drive to do the right thing.
- Loads of  investment on Tech.
cons:
- Not as agile as it could be, although continuously improving on that front.
- Teams still lack autonomy.

headline: Worst working experience I've had
pros: The discount and sample sales were amazing and the social aspect to the company was great
cons: You are expected to work well beyond your contracted hours and made to feel bad if you leave work on time- I was asked on several occasions so come in on the weekend to work for no extra money/time in lieu!! It is extremely fast paced and as the company is 24/7, you are expected to work non-stop without any flexibility. The pay generally is also very poor considering the size of the company and competitors out there. Recruitment process was also poor- people got hired because of WHO they know, not how good or qualified they are.

location: Watford, East of England, England, England
headline: Customer care advisor (day shift)
pros: Young and cool environment. Drinks Friday. 40% off ASOS. Free fruit. Good toilet access. Good food. Games are provided there which I think is a good idea. Ample parking. Has shops nearby. Located in a good place I feel. Office is lovely - nice people to work with, friendly. Couldn't had asked for a better team of people to work with.
cons: Constant monitoring, system is like school. The targets they set are unrealistic, you should do a certain amount of emails/live chats/social an hour and it just isn't possible some days. One to ones you have every week with your team leader are very hard - if you make one mistake you are made to feel guilty about it and as if you are failing every aspect in life - almost a bullying tactic. The company offer no support if you are struggling or having problems outside of work. Team leaders would go missing for hours on end and therefore my team had no one to help us except the odd team leader you could find.  Most team leaders didn't have a clue about half of the policies and I feel that does not set a good example at all for new people. One last thing is keep an eye on what you say to anyone there, there are always people higher up than you watching you and monitoring you. Never discuss anything personal with your team leader or share any opinions on anything with them, they claim your conversations with them are "confidential" and make you feel like you're their friend, they're not. They write down everything you say and relay it all back to their management, even private things - which a company is not strictly allowed to do. All in all - would avoid working for this company.

location: Watford, East of England, England, England
headline: This company needs shutting down
pros: None; your mental stability can't be bought!
cons:
Where do I start? BULLYING, this place is a playground for sociopathic morons who if they see you as a threat will 'investigate' you for stirring your coffee too 
many times. They will dumb you down, you can't use 'big' words their banned because they don't understand them. They treat you like rats in cages; they have colour codes for your productivity- it will start reasonable; 3 an hour and then it will get ridiculous; 10+ customers so that's live chats, emails, social the works you'll be expected to diagnose, read through the chain and notes in 2 minutes with a cherry on top, they also monitor your 'quality' so expect to complete the feats of a robot for 11000 a month after tax. They lure you in with a 700 pound bonus if you pass probation, but the jokes on you because you only get  it  6 months after passing probation! This company will have you jumping through hoop after hoop and will exploit your desire to do well. You're under constant surveillance; expect  a battleaxe to be walking around sniffing out for a DPA  breach which is just being on your phone around the computers. Once you pass your probation though you can work from home? If they let you go you will be humiliated and escorted out of the building by security.

headline: Awful Support System

cons:

headline: Great Stepping Stone
pros: ASOS is a great company to work for, it'll give you many great opportunities and you'll learn a lot. Working in the production department will also give you an insight of how the company works.
cons:
- HUGE hierarchy from the managers
- Although the ASOS vision is to listen to ideas and take them on board (even if it's your first day), that's now always the case. Your ideas will not be listened to if you're a new starter at the bottom of the employee pyramid
- Unrealistic expectations
- Long wait time for an interview

headline: Finance
pros: Discounts for their clothes, of course, that is if you like such kind of clothes
cons: This is a cliquey place and cliques are kings. From day one you will understand, if the clique accepts you, and then they will set the pace for you. You won't have much choice, you will eventually succumb to what the clique dictates. If the clique doesn't like you, the backstabbing will start almost immediately and it will be ferocious and merciless. You will find no friendly soul, no person to confess your thoughts, no friend. Everybody 100% will do their best to bring you down to your knees. If you don't leave by your own accord, they will eject you.

location: Watford, East of England, England, England
headline: Horrible place
pros:
Free coffee and tea
Sample sale
cons:
This place is absolutely horrible. Please ASOS do not reply to this message with an automatic response saying that this is not the case. I worked there long enough to see what kind of place it is. 

The advisors are constantly monitored, if you don't log in on time you will be told off even if it was a work related conversation. The weekly one to one  feedback is even worse, according to them it is our moment to shine but the truth is far from that.  They will just tak about how to improve the quality score of your response and the productivity report. 

Management is really underqualified, half the advisors working there have more qualifications than them. 

They didn't even let me quit in peace, management was constantly gossiping about me until the day I left. I couldn't even say goodbye to colleagues properly.

headline: Terrible
pros: Night shift, the holidays were better than where I am working now. Name recognition on my Cv with led to getting another job quickly.
cons: Pointless one 2 ones each week.  New inexperienced team managers, who where out to save their own skin rather than help, didn’t know the processes, so couldn’t turn to them for help, when stuck in 3 live chats and need advice quickly.turnover of staff a joke. The disperance in pay between team leaders and customer service advisor, when they didn’t seem to know what they where doing. if they paid them a reasonable wage, maybe everyone will get paid a reasonable wage. 3 live chats at a time. It was like being on the phone with 3 people at a time.  Awful.

location: Watford, East of England, England, England
headline: Great Company
pros: ASOS really go above and beyond to make their employees feel appreciated. They have 'Friday Drinks' at the end of each month where each employee is given a free alcoholic or soft drink. The sample sales, the discount and the summer/Christmas parties are all massive perks to the job. ASOS as a workplace has a lovely feel to it, a lot of people in customer care are on personal development plans to help them progress and get to the next level. The support system that ASOS provides is a great help, whether it be from your team leaders, performance managers or your team mates. ASOS is a good start to a career as there are so many differant job roles that are available to work your way towards. The people at ASOS are definitely what make it for me, I have made some great friends not only with my team mates but also with my team leaders.
cons: ASOS have policies put in place for a reason, like most work places. There have been a few reviews about productivity/quality and what people are expected to do... ASOS expect you to try your best. Some people cant and won't understand the policies but if you have a good work ethic then you would have no problem with this as you would be doing the right thing and following the guidelines.

location: Watford, East of England, England, England

The culture of ASOS is unique and they truly care about their staff. Staff development is a real passion of ASOS and we love to watch our staff climb the ladder and celebrate in their success.
cons: Not a single thing  !! - I honestly cant think of anything

location: Watford, East of England, England, England
headline: Customer Care Advisor
pros:
40% discount 
Free Parking - Can always get a space as the car park is big 
Pay is OK
Free fruit
Alright music
Gym
Nice building 
Friendly security staff
cons:
Worse place I have ever worked in my life. They treat you like a child in primary school, the Team Leaders are absolutely useless have no idea what they are doing all they do is walk around looking for answers as they are clueless. If you want to work in a company where you want to progress DO NOT apply for ASOS as 90% off the Team Leaders have come from other companies and have not been a Customer Care Advisor before. They watch everything you do like Big Brother there will give you stupid one to one meeting which is completely pointless and irrelevant. They FORCE you to call customers even though you have told them you ain’t comfortable doing them as you not familiar with all the processes yet, when in actual fact it’s the Team Leaders job to do it. When a member of staff has been sacked or had there probation extended everyone knows about it. The Team Leader I had was a BULLY he use to shout at us when we are not hitting our targets we couldn’t even book a holiday with out being questioned he wants to know why we are taking the holiday and we have to ask him for a holiday even though it has been authorised already. Also was told to kiss the top managers bum to keep my job. When you have made a minor mistake they bring you into a room in front of everyone and tell you off like a child couldn’t wait to leave this company.

AVOID ASOS

location: Watford, East of England, England, England
headline: Racist and ridiculous
pros: 40%  discount on their products, occasional sample sale, free parking
cons: I was sacked for literally being 3 minutes late when another girl on my team (white) came in late 25 minutes and was regularly late. No one said a thing to her. Manager was obviously bias and much friendlier with the white people on the team. I had been performing very well in all other areas but being one of the only ones on the team who lived a little further away I had had a few lates (max 8 mins) which I was always happy to make up at the end of the day. Shifts were terrible, your social life is non-existent with the crazy shifts you're given and they still have the cheek to constantly ask you to do more overtime.  I failed probation because of being 5 minutes late and even though the manager knew this she wouldn't tell me when I asked her at the beginning of my shift. I told her I felt sick and just wanted to know. She made me continue doing the work and said that there was nothing to worry about. My uncle had passed away the night before and by the time they finally arranged a probation review meeting to dismiss me and end my contract I was feeling very sick and I burst out into tears. They are honestly so harsh and they don't pay their employees much and try to make up for it in 'benefits'. Not acceptable.

headline: Avoid at all costs
pros: Discount & office location
cons:
Terrible Managers who are underqualified and insecure.
HR without morals.

headline: Great place to prove yourself or stagnate
pros: Good place to get opportunities as it’s growing fast.
cons: Unfortunately people take advantage and don’t pull their weight

headline: Worst place to work
pros: #NAME?
cons:
Location 
- Shuttle bus runs every 1hour
- Warehouse is 10 - 15 mins drive from Watford Junction. If you drive thats perfect, or else catch an Uber every morning into work. Buses and trains do not pass the Asos Warehouse, so your f'd either way.

Work
- Your responsibility is to respond to customer emails for 7.5 hours. Thats it!!
- If is tedious and unfulfilling 

Management
- Team leaders, and other supervisors are for the most part okay. 
- They are young and inexperienced, lack knowledge and awareness of self and everything else in life. So do not expect them to be in position to help. 
- Help yourself fool!

Environment
- The atmosphere and energy of the place seemed okay, but when you really look at the situation regarding the location of the job, the work you are doing, the petty games management play, everyone looks like they are slowly dying inside. Nobody really seems fulfilled in their job. No one is happy. No one is having a good time. In fact, people are waiting for the end of the day. That is 7.5 hours of feeling drained and unhappy with your current job. 

Experience this place if you want, you won't need much experience or qualifications to work in this environment.

headline: Beware of mid level management (Heads of and Directors of).
pros: People are very creative and smart. The pace is fierceless and incredibly fast. The parties are epic. Great company benefits and the pay is good.  Most importantly, Asos is inspiring to work for because of their focus on diversity and inclusion in fashion. They do loads of charity work and aim for sustainability.
cons: That being said, it is the people who you work with and who you report to that will make it or break it.  Mid level management is very volatile and cliquey. If you do well, the manager will make your achievement as their own (and sometimes credit you for it). Do poorly, and the finger will definitely be pointed at you, you will be micromanaged and you will be reprimanded. If you want to progress in your career you will have to belong to the clique which is a boys club. There has been considerable proof that the manager is a very poor one (people officially complaining, loosing a number of good colleagues in the past year for the same reasons, no career progression, favouritism, etc.) to which senior management and HR completely ignore.

headline: Probably a Great First Company for Graduates
pros:
* Most of the people were nice
* Casual dress code
* Free fruit, tea etc.
* Company events (xmas party, ASOS Assembles) were fantastic
* HR responded fantastically to the complaint I raised; their follow-up process was an absolute credit to the org
* Work / life balance was good
* Sample sales, discounts
cons:
* Was not placed in the division that I interviewed for, which is absurd (and hence i did not stay long at this org)
* My initial line manager was a condescending bully with numerous complaints against him
* Some of the people were awful - dismissive, belittling etc.
* "Just do it" attitude held by many managers
* BIG boozing culture
* Flexible working initiative not consistently implemented
* The criteria for BA career progression was extremely opaque. The process was not explained during the interview process even though I very specifically asked about it
* The division seemed obsessed with the process of delivery and not delivery itself; suffice to say our team delivered very little and I left because I felt this was going to look very bad on my CV
* The staff turnover in tech was laughable (so high)

headline: Unprofessional to a tee.....
pros:

cons:
-Politics.
-Undermining and backstabbing.
-Complete lack of professionalism (especially some Directors and their Mini Me Wannabes)
-Heavy drinking and drugs culture (inc within the office).
-Do as I say culture (don’t do as I do, as I am superior)- hypocrites galore! 
-Some vindictive personalities, especially within Tech
-Bullying and Discrimination- discriminatory subculture exists (language and actions permeate directly from the CEO) 
-Presents a holier than thou facade, everything from ethical trade to working conditions and equal ops- none of which is backed up.

headline: Good

headline: A good place to work at
pros:
