'the client is always right' mentality often leavers employees as cannon fodder because its something deemed better for employees to take the hit even when client demands are unreasonable

headline: Great place to start your career
pros: As a graduate, ACN provides all the necessary tools and resources to learn and build basic management consulting skills. You are given the freedom to drive your own career taking the direction you want. The scope of work and opportunities to learn a huge, in a day to day job as well as from the people in the company.
cons: As great as freedom to drive own career may be, it is also its own downside as there might be lack of support or direction for those unsure of their own strengths of career path to take. Performance rating system is quite tough, but fair. A lot of traveling is great but also can be overwhelming.

headline: Good salary - above average.
pros:
Good salary
Good working hours and i really believe the job pushed me to succeed and led me to greater oppurtunities due to th experience gained.
cons: Possibly the conditions of the office as the offices may need renovating maybe to somthing more presitigous

headline: Best of the big consultants. loads of chance to self improve and develop yourself over projects.
pros: strict business discipline. respects what you are doing and your efforts. demands a lot so you can extend beyond your boundaries. possibility to move across organisation
cons: long project delivery times may impact your motivation. based on project, you may require to work extended hours or sometimes across continental time zones.

headline: Great place to work, excellent diversity of clients and projects
pros: Excellent benefits and flexibility of work. Amazing range of clients to work work and roles for every single levels
cons: Promotions are slow, peer comparisons can feel irrelevant

headline: Different projects so lots to learn and take in during you time with Accenture.
pros: The different types of work on offer
cons: Big company with a good name.

headline: Excellent grounding in all aspects of business with opportunities for travel and personal development
pros:
Good quality of colleagues
Opportunity for variety of work (type / location)
Ability to craft your own career direction
cons:
Poor work life balance
Less clear value proposition for career beyond Senior Manager level
Compensation not as competitive as other peer organisations

headline: Good place to start, but leave soon
pros: Easy to get in as a graduate, big clients
cons: Old technologies, too corporate, bad management

headline: A good start
pros:
Advanced work
Good travel
Excellent training
Flexible lifestyle
Good network
cons:
Working above level
Uncompetitive salary
Slow
Inconsistent work
Chaotic

headline: Challenging and competitive environment surrounded by bright people.
pros:
Good benefits
Diversity of work and projects
Opportunities to work in new areas and get new challenges
cons:
potential to get lost if you don't network 
huge amount of administration

headline: good to work for short term
pros: flexibility, learning, better pay, benefits.
cons: work life balance, higher management

headline: Corporate and may not understand individuals
pros:
Large company that makes plenty of money.
Good benefits
cons:
Need to apply for jobs within the company. Sometimes there is not much work.
Pay slightly below average.
Very corporate and people can get lost in the crowd.

headline: Reasonable for a consulting company
pros: Broad variety of work across a wide range of industries, salaries are competitive
cons: Very political environment; poor work life balance - high expectation of working all hours of every day

headline: Good company overall
pros:
Provides solid consulting experience
International network and perspective
Thought leadership
cons:
Average salary 
Too much workload
Can be quite political
Not always meritocratic

headline: Top consultancy firm but comes at a price
pros:
• Excellent career choice for graduates but beyond those early years it becomes a hard slog
• Great opportunities to work across projects and industries picking up different skill sets
• You are always given opportunities to step up to the next role/grade.
• Working with some very talented people
cons:
• No work/life balance!!! - very long working hours are the norm
• Performance management system is unclear and often comes across unfair
• Project timelines are often unrealistic and poorly managed

headline: Great company but saps the life out of you
pros: fantastic people - clever and intelligent. Good benefits, great technology and innovation. you can work from home in most roles.
cons:
not paid well enough for the job you do - ie sign over your life.
told that if you are not happy with pay - you can live, because we want people that work for the brand.
promotions opportunities are just not there anymore - used to be a great place to advance your career, now it's a fight to the top - everybody wants it. Training is mostly in house, cut back on costs massively. not a selling point anymore.

headline: Associate Manager
pros: Access to top notch clients
cons:
Poor work life balance 
Poor salary

headline: Friendly and straightforward recruitment process
pros: Good money and varied work as expected at a consultancy
cons: Can be a political environment and net always a meritocracy

headline: Great place to start off
pros: Learn a huge amount, meet some great people, chance to move around if you make the most out of it, great training, the company name will put you in good stead for when you move on.
cons: You have to play the game, the hours can be long, you can travel lots, promotion process is quite brutal but as long as you are aware of it and play the game from the start thats great. If you go in for three years, learn as much as you can and then move on you can 100% guaranteed you will be snapped up by another company.

headline: Not sure why the are rated so highly, possibly because they employ lots of grads who don't know any better.
pros: They do great work and have some great clients. They are producing work on the cusp of the future and have a global network.
cons: Internal functions haven't been overhauled for decades, a lot of internal functions are outsourced, they are still thinking like an accountancy firm in the 80's when it comes to Hr, Recruitment and Talent management. .

headline: OK, but far from Great
pros:
- Accenture has a good reputation, some of it perhaps a little unwarranted, but looks good on a CV.

- 15% discount on company shares which  are ever increasing (at the time of writing) in value (although you are taxed on the market value difference, as HMRC see this as a perk)
cons:
We talk a lot about different client experiences at Accenture (which I think is why a lot of people hire us) however we have very few SME's because promotion and progression power is all within the specific client account's. Those that do well often seem to have joined Accenture and then only ever worked on one (or maybe two at most) client's. This means that often general consultants are passed off as being SME's or as being experts in their industry/that technology, just to keep the individuals on the account because it will ruin their promotion chances / bonus etc. In the same way, leadership for most who work at Accenture is from the accounts and not whichever group they are attached to. I sometimes wonder why client's don't ask the individuals to explain where THEY have done whatever it is they are been hired for before, as in most cases I think we would fail to answer this without embellishing the truth.

Recruitment here generally seems to be flawed, you often come across individuals who you wonder how they got through the door, but most managers and team's tolerate this as Accenture's forced bell curve performance model forces X % of any team to be under performing so these people are used to protect the rest of the team.

IT here is terrible, most of us have 3-4 year old laptops, which are replaced on a four year cycle. Worst still is IT keep forcing updates like Office 2013 onto us which makes the machines even slower and more recently an agent which tracks everything we do (supposedly to help reduce data loss). If you do have a problem, no-one rings the offshore IT helpdesk as it's understaffed (technically and physically) so most people just use Google or let the problem remain.

Generally, if you 'brown-nose' and play the game, which most people figure out pretty quickly, then it's easy to do well here, just don't expect any support from anyone, including HR and in most cases the Senior Managers and Executives, as they are often too busy playing the game themselves!

headline: Management Consultant working on large business transformation programmes.
pros: Lots of great experience and varied projects across multiple industries. Also the opportunity to work with in a professional environment, with established methodologies and frameworks.
cons: Extremely long working hours as with any management consultancy firms. Be prepared to work all day every day. The  branding is 'high performance. delivered." This means client is king (as it should be) but you will work 24/7 in order to achieve this.

headline: It was amazing working with great minds. Accenture gives you the opportunity to flourish in your respective careers.
pros: There are so many things to learn from your peers and seniors in the organization. Scope of growth is very high.
cons: Salary is the only thing which gives you little low in the company. HR is not very helping in the company.

headline: 50/50 split between the good and bad points about working as a software engineer for Accenture.
pros:
No blame culture - Nobody points a finger at you. I was never "told off" during my time at the company. If something goes wrong, everybody just pitches in and helps out till it's fixed.
Social - Lots of nice people, always something to take part in, great if you're single.
Build your own reputation - On your first day, if you dive right in head first you will get recognised and rewarded but you will be expected to keep up that level of hard-work. If you prefer a bit more balance, you can have that, and the expectations will drop, but the rewards won't be as forthcoming either.
Networks - Support networks are great and something I highly compliment but a little confusing. Between your buddy, HR Rep, career councillor, line manager, etc, it's hard to know who to speak to sometimes.
cons:
Terrible rewards - The pay for a software engineer is about £2-3k less than what I consider a "good" salary. The overtime system is awful, you get "half-pay" for any hours of overtime. Not time-and-a-half, but half-time. And the first 37.5 hours of that get added on to your holiday which most consider a negative.
Promotions - The promotions system is awful, pretty much coming down to how much your manager likes you at a single point during the year.
Flexible working - Never happens. If you have children, you can work flexibly, otherwise, you do whatever hours you're told to do.
Working hours - 10 hour days were common. Longest day I think I did was about 15 hours. Usually you get the next day off after a long stint like that but having software engineers working all hours of the day... there gets a point where your productivity just drops to nothing but the management never seemed to notice; so long as you're there.
Offshoring - I'd estimate that around 60-80% of the code developed offshore was of such poor quality that it needed to be overhauled/redone onshore before being deployed.
Work, work, work.... - A final note. I consider myself to be a hard working individual, but Accenture takes it to a whole new level. You pretty much have to dedicate yourself to the company/project and, if you don't, there will always be somebody who will, and they'll get a promotion, and you won't, despite the fact your quality of work is twice as good.

headline: A company to be proud of working for, due to its high performing and highly ethical culture. Only for high performers.
pros: Availabiltiy for flexible working and moving according to your interests and personal needs -  great projects, a lot of very good training. Very good people to work with - senior leaders that will sit and work by your side till midnight if necessary - and analysts that are so bright you think they could do your job better than you. Always an open door to discuss a new idea or project. Strong emphasis on ethical behaviours, diversity and people.
cons: Very demanding on personal life - exposure to clients that many times are not exactly bright, educated or respectful. Cultural fit determines everything, the yearly performance management process is exhausting but keeps us on our toes!

headline: well supported for work I didn't want to continue
pros: good pay, motivated company, occasionally stimulating work, chance to get promoted quickly
cons: long hours and often pretty boring work

headline: Breadth of company means that no two projects are the same. Reasonable work life balance although this varies
pros:
- Quick progression / meritocracy
- Good comp
- Other benefits satisfactory
- Interesting mix of clients and work
- Useful training
cons:
- Vendor agnostic means that we do not have preferences where technology is concerned
- High rates of attrition mean that SMEs and other 'good people' are easily lost to competitors
- Company can feel somewhat bloated with 330K+ employees worldwide

headline: Best place to start your career. They take everything from you if you give it though.
pros:
salary and benefits (salary less so above Manager level)
opportunity to travel, work abroad, work on global projects
steep learning curve
cons:
poor work life balance
you are a number, and you go where there are roles available. Have you manage your own career VERY proactively.

headline: Business Analyst
pros:
- great fun
-Good interviewer
-easy questions
cons:
-Needed more time
-Nothing else really

headline: good working environment. help you gain knowledge of industries
pros:
salary and benefits (salary less so above Manager level).opportunity to travel, work abroad, work on global projects
steep learning curve
cons: poor work life balance, too much travel

headline: Generally positive, but be prepared to play the game
pros: Salary, great people, good opportunities
cons: Got to be prepared to play the game of networking, generally telling everyone how good you are etc in order to be promoted. Work live balance was sometimes hard to maintain especially near the end of the project.

headline: Internal IT Outsourcing
pros: Great atmosphere, dedicated towards excellence great structure.
cons: Salaries are not what everyone made out

headline: Senior Manager
pros: Lots of opportunities for career growth.
cons: You will be expected to push yourself to the limits.

headline: Great learning opportunity and exciting opportunities
pros:
Established and structured approach to work. 
Large clients with exciting briefs. 
Opportunity to act above your own level and engage with client stakeholders. 
Great team culture and collaborative environment.
cons:
Long working hours. 
Recognition system is quite rigid. 
Little management support.

headline: Too varied for one sentence - changes with each project
pros: Working with excellent, knowledgeable people is exciting and worthwhile. Forever having to learn new ideas, & concepts. Very interesting working in teams of up to 250 people.
cons: Having to pull together in such large teams can be frustrating and appear time-consuming.  In order to perform effectively, it is essential to understand the mores of the environment.

headline: Challenging, dynamic consulting
pros: Working with great people. Real collaborative environment. People help each other. Can create your own career and find opportunities. Have fun too
cons: Long hours at times. Internal structures can be divisive. Seem to keep restructuring and renaming things which can be confusing

headline: Great operational/management consulting company
pros:
Great for the career start, full of training and learning possibilities. Extensive knowledge database and opportunities to get deep understanding of operational consulting/back-office transformation/performance management. 
Absolutely amazing corporate culture and support for top performance employees.
cons:
Lack of possibilities for industry or topic specialization; could be rotated on the very different topics and projects all the time. On other hand, some projects are very long for consulting (1-2 years) and you don't get so much to learn. 
Organizational structure changes every year.

headline: Great experience
pros: Fantastic opportunity to learn and grow
cons: #NAME?

headline: Be prepared to work day and night to satisfy the tidal of unrealistic expectations and poorly managed projects
pros:
- I had 1 great year at Accenture. Interesting and challenging projects and inspiring leaders to learn from. Over the last 2 years, the company has changed dramatically.
-  The main pro was the people (senior executives to learn from and great peers to work with). However, extremely high attrition has resulted in many of them leaving the company.
cons:
How long have I got?
- Long hours - absolutely no work life balance
- Projects are poorly staffed and not scoped realistically, placing a huge amount of pressure on these left to deal with the mess 
- Lean business model has resulted in every person being stretched to breaking point to deliver to plans and costs which are completely unrealistic
- The company promotes itself as highly focussed on training and development. However, resources are so thinly stretched that you work in constant "fire fight mode" without any time for training or support from senior management to develop and deliver
- The complete abdication of responsibility from senior executives (at least 80% of those I have worked with do not support staff or provide adequate direction), but place huge pressure on all levels below to do their jobs for them
- Performance management and promotion system does not work. Like with every consultancy, playing the political game is key to success - but the ability to get promoted / pay is not commensurate with effort and ability

headline: Software Consultant
pros: Friendly  and relaxed working area, got to work with big projects.
cons: Nothing much bad to say but some politics within themselves.

headline: Associate software engineer
pros: Its people and work culture!
cons: Travel to client locations frequently.

headline: Great Place to Work
pros: Depending on the role or project you work on there is a great work/life balance. Love the colleagues I work with and with the diversity of the workforce globally there is great opportunity to share and gain knowledge. Given the varied type of projects and clients there is a scope for different kinds of work to do.
cons: Being such a large organisation you can get lost within the organisation. Performance management isnt always the fairest and sometimes he who shouts the loudest can get promoted.

headline: Accenture Management Consulting
pros:
Great people with a range of differing and market leading skills
Strong focus on collaboration and knowledge sharing
Best in class enabling technologies
Fantastic Clients
cons:
Performance management process is not always the fairest as seeks to compare differing roles
Reactivity to market place in Talent Development and benefits
Red tape - lots of policies and procedures required to do large size of organisation can SOMETIMES slow work progress down

headline: Best in technology consulting
pros: Best place to work for technology consulting
cons: Not very good in strategy consulting

headline: Positive experience - though you get what you put in
pros:
The sheer variety of work you get involved keeps the job interesting and you get involved with different levels of stakeholders
You can pretty much work on almost anything you want so long you have the knowledge and skillset to match
You can hone your skills pretty quickly and with ease if you have the will to do so
Though the firm is huge, it is relatively small and it's very easy to build connections and network if you are for it, though it may not be for everyone
It is consulting after all, and you either love it or hate it.  No two ways about it.  I love it as it gives me the flexibility to move from one project to another, from one client to another.
cons: It's a massive firm and you don't always get the smartest of people working on your team, and this has been hampered at times by M&As.

headline: Aggresive environment
pros:
- banter, at least with some of colleagues
- used to look impressive on a resume
cons:
- biased selection for projects
- long working hours

headline: Snr manager role in BPO "operations"
pros:
Huge variety, massive work load never quite which brings its own challenges 
Great place if early on in you career or if higher you join from outside on fair package
cons:
Career mgmt does not exist is same format for snr mgr as it does for levels below. you will need to "network!" first and perform second for your next career move.
Travel can make up a large part of your role so expect a lot if it does
Mixed variety of MD's some good

headline: Review
pros: Opportunity to work on different projects across different industries, good online training site, gym subsidy, private medical insurance
cons: Work-life balance depends on a project you're working on, performance review process

headline: Associate Manager
pros: Terrible place to work, especially if you want a work life balance, as it doesn’t exist here! Totally unfair place to work with real segregation issues between work forces in pay, training & opportunities, and it really does depend on who you know and not what you do that will get you promotion, and hard work and long hours doesn’t mean you’ll get pay rises or promotion at all!
cons: You can meet likeminded people here, who are smart and do become part of your professional network for your life outside of Accenture

headline: Good training but repetitive work
pros:
Overseas training - 2 weeks in Bangalore, KL or Chicago
Competitive salary and good benefits
Growing company
Culturally diverse workforce
Respected name on your CV
cons:
Very long projects (e.g. 1-1.5 years).
Lack of choice over projects
Repetitive work
Lots of out of town working
Lack of female leadership

headline: Analyst
pros:
Scope to travel
Broad scope
Wide variety of projects
cons:
Inflexible promotion model
Long hours
Noncompetitive salary

headline: Possibly the worst company to work for
pros: Really struggleing to to think of anything positive past a great christmas party
cons:
So many, All management where graduates straight from uni with no life experience or common sense.
Highly paid senior exec who didn't really know anything other than how to build and present fancy power point presentations.

headline: It is what you make of it
pros: flexibility, variety, great people, travel
cons: too much travel (if you are not keen), looooong hours when on the wrong project, expected to do many internal things, admin/policies

headline: A great place to learn your trade
pros: Extensive Opportunities and variety mean its a great place to gain experience and build your skills
cons: Can often become lost in the big machine

headline: Finance Specialist
pros:
diverse environment
work from home
exposure to senior stakeholders at the firm
cons:
long hours, unpredictable workload
management on projects sometime lack people skills or basic knowledge

headline: Acn
pros:
Good pay
Collaborative environment
Decent prospects post Acn
cons:
Politics around performance management
Sometimes can be a body shop

headline: Big organisation, with big opportunities
pros: There are numerous areas that you can specialise within, and opportunities across clients and geographies. Also, as you get higher up, there's a real willingness to push you into SME roles and to really help you to shape the next level of thought leadership within the organisation.
cons:
Don't go into management consulting as a profession if you aren't prepared to take a few knocks - thick skin is a pre-requisite. 

The more senior you get, the more you are focused on sales, rather than content.

You don't have as much control as you'd like all the time.

headline: Great company
pros: Exciting project work. Intelligent hardworking people. Young vibrant workforce. Market leading clients. Well positioned to help clients with digital transformations.
cons: Work life balance. Performance management system is by no means perfect. Promotions can be time bound to months at level.

headline: Management Consultant
pros:
Accenture has a clear process for assigning performance ratings to employees at a project and client level
Senior staff are down to earth and flexible and understand the need for a work/life balance
Staff staying away from home weekdays are looked after with a healthy expense budget
Project events are great.
cons:
Performance rating at a department level tend to get skewed and a lot on who you know
Work/Life balance can be a nightmare for short sprints - 3 to 4 months
No annual bonuses for consultants and below

headline: Good if you're happy to play the game
pros:
Lots of interesting projects going on
Great team environment
Good benefits with things like shared paternity leave
cons:
Little to no salary increases at Analyst and junior Consultant levels
No bonus
You have to be on a project with a line manager that invests in your career progression to have a chance at a good performance rating/promotional prospect
Have to work crazy hours to get to Manager level

headline: Awesome company
pros:
Good work culture.
Support to grow in organization is provided.
Good salary.
Option to work from home.
Paid vacations and other benefits.
cons:
Sometimes promotion is difficult.
Need to work overtime to show your  capabilities and devotion to work.
HR department is not very good.

headline: Title
pros: Interesting mission lot's of opportunities to work on a variety of mission with a wide range of client
cons: Corporate spirit, compensation, career opportunity. Not fair with experienced hire

headline: Good Start for Graduates
pros: Great training opportunities, Good range of benefits and well recognised name to have on CV
cons: Performance management could be better, progression depends a lot on your reviewer which in some cases is not the best representation. The view within the firm between employees of services and technology as the "rubbish" part of the business is not encouraging for those in these business areas

headline: Accenture Strategy
pros:
1. We have to solve really difficult client problems across all industries, typically in short projects. 
2. The people are very smart and there is an entrepreneurial, challenging feel. 
3. The company is different to other strategy houses because it's at an interesting intersection between strategy and technology (including digital); and also because Accenture can provide an 'end to end' service meaning once the strategy is developed, another part of the organisation can implement it for our clients.
cons:
1. Work life balance can be very tough. 
2. Sometimes working in such a huge organisation (336,000 people) means decisions take a long time to get made.

headline: Pick your projects carefully - its more important than you think
pros:
Amazing people - you work with the best (in most cases!)
Great benefits
Varied work
Great training resources
cons:
Pot-luck with projects - some are better than others.  
Existing staff attitude to experienced hires - can be problematic.

headline: Work
pros: chance to learn with lots of activities.
cons: workload can be daunting. no work life balance.

headline: Reasonable opportunities, great benefits but very poor performance management
pros:
Wide range of industries and operations to work in ensures there is something to suit everyone's skills and interests.
Forward thinking strategy of company ensures interesting technology projects.
Intelligent and friendly colleagues make work pleasant.
Very good non-monetary benefits (pensions, leave, maternity)
cons: Very poor performance management system, which rates individuals directly against their team members. This promotes unhealthy competition within small teams, and penalises individuals in high performing teams due to the imposition of a forced distribution so that a certain percentage must be ranked as poor performers even if this is not the case.

headline: Nice place
pros:
Lots of things to learn
Ideal for junior engineers
cons: People have an unfair competition for the performance evaluation, etc

headline: Tech Arch Manager
pros: Really good company to grow and learn
cons: Challenging life balance but not new for Consulting

headline: Good for career start
pros:
- Good reputation and great to have on CV
- Training abroad is unique and fun with like minded people
- Work with a range of leading clients
cons:
- Projects can be slow and you can be stuck in them
- Promotion doesn't depend on quality of work but rather having a manager who really supports you

headline: Good place to work
pros: Lots of opportunities to learn about cutting edge technologies across multiple industries.
cons: Not necessarily always a good work/life balance. Often consultants are pigeon holed into one industry and end up working on projects there for several years.

headline: Senior Analyst
pros: Great company, great ambition. They look after their workforce
cons: As far as I can tell after 3 years of working here, there are no cons

headline: Only work for Accenture if you can't do better
pros: You will be given opportunities often more senior than what is reasonably expected of your career level and management will try and sell you as a more senior resource if they can, which means higher expectations and demands on your time without adequate recognition or remuneration for your hard work.
cons: Very outdated social Darwinian management style - ie survival of the fittest, or sink or swim. Managers are often under qualified or lack sufficient maturity and experience to make the difficult decisions that need to be made on projects. Thus many managers are unable to provide analysts and consultants with sufficient coaching.

headline: Working with Accenture was a nightmare.
pros: Nothing great to talk about . Of my 10 years of career this was the "only " bad experience.
cons: Least  recognition for expertise . Full of politics.People who can keep managers happy without doing any actual work stays in the business.

headline: Great for all new starters
pros: Training, people, internal opportunities, clients, experience, social, benefits, healthcare, market compensation, networking opportunities, lots of responsibility.
cons: Long hours, lost in the shelves mentality, poor people recognition with senior management

headline: Experienced Hires need not apply here
pros: Salary and benefits - that's it
cons:
Thoroughly dreadful place to work...

As an experienced hire I kept hearing about the wonderful people I would work with and for..I didn't meet any of these people...

It is an awful place to work... filled with traditional thinking that just makes service worse, drives in cost and demoralizes employees.

The worst place I have have  ever worked - avoid at all costs.

headline: good experience, expect to get spat out the moment they can't make money out of you
pros: Its good experience when your young and some good stuff for the CV.
cons: Often sent to work on something you have little knowledge off, but sold to the client as an expert so lots of free time taken up learning stuff. Stressful work. Lots of travel in own time. Large amounts of overtime unpaid. Brown nosing is essential to get ahead, often people that aren't great get promoted as they go drinking with their manager. People often taking credit for your work. After 10 years there I was sacked when I had some mental health problems, probably due to work, with a few weeks notice.

headline: Sales Manager
pros: People; training; Network; opportunities; reputation
cons: Long hours; large corporate

headline: Good  experience  when you are young!
pros:
Great  experience 
Exposure to  senior  management 
Lots of  travel
cons:
Lots of  travel 
Long hours

headline: Accenture
pros: Some great colleagues, there are supportive and clever people around.  Possible exposure to high-profile clients and programs although that is very much down to chance, with some assignments being less interesting or conducive to development.
cons: Accenture does not know how to integrate experienced hires, and seemingly doesn't care to put any effort into improving the company's performance in that area. There is no recognition  that people need to be put into assignments that keep them interested and help them develop, or at least cycled out of assignments where they are significantly underutilised. Essentially, to the company a consultant is just an asset that is not generating revenue when 'on the bench'.  Make sure you don't take the first assignment that comes along and that you find something that works for you - worth taking a little heat from planners for a week or so while you look around.

headline: Great Oppurtunties, you are in the drivers seat
pros:
- Great opportunities
- Great for right of a school
- In charge of your own career
- Work with Smart Motivated coworkers
- Travel
cons:
- Work/Life Balance 
- Travel (can get tiresome)
- Projects (some are good, some can be hell)

headline: Great experience
pros:
You can develop rapidly with good training opportunities available
Travelling, expenses lifestyle
Working with intelligent people from all backgrounds
Great chance to get experience in different areas in your industry quickly
cons:
Projects can be very hit and miss - luck of the draw if you get on a good project or a bad one
The life can be demanding but again work/life balance all depends on the project your on
For experienced hires it can be hard to adapt for the first few months - not a great on boarding process

headline: Your network in the company is all important!
pros: There were interesting projects to work on and the majority of people there were great people to work with. The projects were the world over so it was good to work on a variety of different things.
cons: Without a strong network in this company you'll never get anywhere. The projects tend to get layered up with so many contingencies and 'just in case' costs that winning a bid becomes difficult. You'll have to work hard to keep up.

headline: Good place to start your career
pros:
Great like-minded people.
Above average salary.
cons: You may get stuck on a project you don't want to be for years..

headline: Consultant
pros: Accenture has a wide and diverse network available and a large variety of projects and roles available.  This leads to having a number of projects available when deciding where you want to be in the organisation.
cons: The work / life balance is not great and I have worked more weekends and late evenings than I would like.  In addition, after the initial training there is not in the way of development in terms of industry standards (Prince2, ITIL, etc).

headline: Experienced hire
pros: Broad client base different and varied projects at scale and opportunity. Pay is competitive as well as compensation package over all it seems.
cons: Travel and time away from family. Difficult to integrate as experience hire at this level.  People will help but only with sound bites

headline: Strategy Consultant
pros: varied work, challenging and good people
cons: long hours, bureaucracy, hard to travel internationally

headline: Good variety of work but a bit soulless and horrible hours
pros: You can learn a lot in a limited amount of time, as you're usually joining a project halfway through, and you need to pick up enough on the job as possible to make yourself useful. A good skill to learn!
cons: On too many projects, a 60-80 hour work-week is entirely normal. This is systematic, and probably an industry-wide problem - I've seen the same happen at IBM.

headline: Senior Consultant
pros:
Great company, diverse people with a great attitude. The quality of work is great and opportunities for training, learning as well as networking, giving back to the community are plenty. 
Large organisation covering across industries gives lot of opportunities to get involved in the different kinds of projects. Recommend!! ++
cons: Hiring is more demand based and can be a length process but worth it.

headline: Lovely place to start a career
pros: One of the best place to work in.
cons: A lot of travelling, which is nice when you are single and young but as you get older you want to be settled in a place

headline: Diverse
pros: You get opportunity to work on different industries and with multi-national colleagues. It is 3 years now since I joined and I feel the environment is very diverse and have been a good experience for me. Working for a consulting firm like Accenture means it gives a good opportunity to travel to different locations and experience different work-cultures.
cons: Recognition/Performance management is not accurate in my opinion. I personally had encountered bad ratings even if the feedback is good from the project managers. However, I think Accenture realized this and taking steps to change the performance management process from 2015.

headline: Really nice atmosphere, everyone is incredibly friendly and willing to help you out when needed.
pros: The people, perks, the salary, there are really good career prospects and you have the potential to work across different areas of the company if you are able to network well. Also the Accenture name, working for such a reputable organisation will most definitely open doors in the future.
cons: The recruitment process was slightly unorganised and when questions were asked the staff didn't really have answers.

headline: Plain terrible
pros:
good variety of work
diverse workplace
cons:
pretentious colleagues
poor work life balance

headline: Outsourcing BPO
pros: Great company to work for; plenty of opportunities for career advancement; great mentoring scheme;
cons: can be long hours; despite pushing for work/life balance it's not quite there; can get stuck at your level;

headline: Good for learning consulting
pros: Great projects conducive atmosphere to learn and grow..easy to make your way around using network
cons: Not good at integrating experiences hires.

headline: BPO Procurement: not as good as they say
pros: Well above any other competitor in BPO Procurement; a lot of training, standard and role focused, plus opportunity to request budget for external certifications; flexible working (although depends a lot on project and manager)
cons: Salary increase and bonuses are very small and are totally discretionary (both you and the company may have exceeded the performance target and you may still get less than 100%, for no reason); you are considered just a number and totally replaceable; there are rules and bureaucracy for ever small thing, but then if you know the right person, those rules do not apply to you

headline: Management Consulting Analyst
pros:
Very stimulating organisation to work in, lots going on and to get involved with.

Excellent benefits (health insurance, gym subsidy etc).

Good training opportunities, international travel.
cons:
Very little choice as to which project you are staffed on - you can end up being marooned on projects for 1 year+ which you had no desire to work on. 

Roles aren't necessarily aligned to your skills/interests (i.e. you can end up on very techy projects even if you are aligned to Management Consulting).

Work/life balance can be very poor with long hours and extensive travel (sometimes 5 days a week away from home). 'No' is not tolerated.

Extremely hierarchical organisation.

headline: Accenture
pros: Lots of really good training
cons: Quite a rigid management structure

headline: Great way to start in management consultancy
pros: Great teams to work with and good pay, working with smart people most of them are workaholics
cons: Very driven by changeability, and very political like other big organisations

headline: Pros and cons
pros: Work with some of the brightest people around
cons: Work life balance can be a challenge

headline: Accenture Strategy
pros:
- Great company to work for, especially if you are at the beginning of your career
- Amazing learning opportunity from such a diverse set of people (Strategy, Technology, Outsourcing, Digital)
- Growing Strategy practice, with increasing focus on proper strategy work and advising the C-level, and less on chargeability
- High client exposure, even at the lower level of the pyramid
cons:
- Travel requirements can be overwhelming sometimes, with years spent in out-of-town projects
- Strategy work and salary are not at the MBB level (McKinsey, BCG, Bain)
- Politics may take an important role in promotions

headline: Good work life balance
pros: Good atmosphere - healthy relationships between colleagues - possibility to work from home - access to market data and analysis
cons: limitations due to number of employees for training, job opportunities and overall capabilities

headline: Accenture
pros:
great environment for women 
fab maternity leave benefit with full pay for 9 months
cons:
long queues for promotion at senior level with challenging network to navigate
challenging to find a sense of community at time with the constant reorg and the company growth and acquisitions.

headline: Good company to get into the workforce
pros:
Great exposure to very good clients. 
Good for leadership training.
cons: Promotion strategy is not transparent at all. Even if you follow the politics it is very hard to tell if you will become eligible. At junior levels you do not get pay rises unless you get promoted, and you get promoted if your manager likes you at one point in time during the year. Great for management consultants who are good at socialising and self promoting, but bad for software engineers who want to do a good job.

headline: Great place to be
pros: great people and management who support you
cons: roles available and ability to move around the company

headline: Management Consulting Manager
pros: Career opportunities, varied work, fantastic colleagues above all. Great support for parents, I used the mat leave (9 months full paid) and worked flexibly and part time (4 days a week) upon return from maternity
cons: Travel and hours. One needs to learn pretty quickly to negotiate to maintain work/life balance

headline: Great Place
pros:
Very supportive and inspiring people were surrounding me from day 1. 
You will get promoted if you are great at your work, at networking and at playing politics games
cons:
Politics, very complicated structure and performance evaluation criteria is not very clear
If you sign the contract agreeing to 100% of travel - be ready to travel wherever (in the UK) and whenever; I have seen many people complaining about it for no reason.

headline: Marketing Manager
pros: The people are fantastic and the work is constantly changing. Great work life balance.
cons: Not that I can think of.

headline: UK Review - Oct 2015
pros: Investment in career development and training. Diversity of roles - industry, technology and function. Calibre of people. Breadth of clients - work with majority of global top 500. Great extended benefits package.
cons: Very competitive culture can drive heavy focus on performance management and knock-on Impact to life-work balance. Hope the new performance management process will address this.

headline: Great place to work if you are outgoing and into tech or not
pros:
- You will consistently hear that what makes Accenture a great place to work is 'the people.' Most colleagues are, on the whole, outgoing, intelligent and driven people. This can make it a great place to work and feel challenged. 
- If you are driven and have a sensible head on your shoulders you will be able to make a proper stab at being successful.
- Your ongoing learning and development is taken seriously and there are opportunities available to learn a vast range of skills.
- There are lots of opportunities outside of your working day that being a part of Accenture allows you access. This could be industry events or extracurricular sports. If you make the most of these opportunities it can greatly improve your experience at Accenture.
cons: #NAME?

headline: A great place to start your career in consulting
pros: Excellent training opportunities, great clients and learning environment, you work alongside the best.
cons: Difficult to navigate such a huge company, it can often feel impersonal and internal change is poorly communicated. Salaries are not competitive enough below MD level.

headline: First rate
pros: Top notch colleagues so you get to learn from the best. Good emphasis on development, and while people are competitive, they will always help you or point you in the right direction if you need help or info.
cons: If you're on an out of town assignment you will spend time away from home - but this is not a negative for everyone and comes with the territory.

headline: IT Consultant
pros: They are a large organisation that are well known, and probably good to have on your resume. Opportunities for learning & education are good.
cons: Being large, its easy to feel lost in the organisation, and sometimes difficult to establish who to contact when you are looking outside your immediate team.

headline: Good company to work for but low salary
pros:
Very good experience in a CV
Interesting and challenging projects
cons:
The salaries are quite low compare to the market
7.5 hours a day

headline: Good variety of work
pros:
Work with highly skilled intelligent people
Hands on management
cons:
Struggle to get work life balance
Movement through the career levels feels like based on tenure rather than merit

headline: Manager
pros:
-Global company with great opportunities all around the world. 
-The vision and direction of company makes employees be proud of their company. 
-Flexible arrangements are possible.
-Good reputation.
cons: Sometimes it is easy to be lost in such a big, complex organisation. On-boarding process for experienced hires is not good enough; so, many people find it difficult to adjust to the way of working in the organisation.

headline: Great way to start a career
pros:
- Amazing learning opportunities
- Good access to senior leaders
- Great travel opportunity
cons: #NAME?

headline: New Joiner - 2 months in
pros:
> Given immediate responsibility. Entrusted with work that is genuinely important to the company and consequently you are able to see how your efforts contribute to Accenture's success
> Managed effectively. There is a culture of collaboration which means that if you are struggling with your workload then you feel comfortable to ask colleagues for advice and support. Conversely, if you are working effectively then you are not hassled by managers and they respect your choice to work independent of instruction.
> Working with smart and personable people. Accenture place a great emphasis on recruiting people who work well in teams and who are interested in seeing others succeed and progress in their career. This creates a culture that is supportive and beneficial for each and every employee and you feel you have the confidence and backing to perform at your very best.
cons:
> You are expected to learn very quickly. Not necessarily a con as it translates to a pro as you quickly become competent, but it can be hard to adjust. If you don't know the answer, then don't look to ask for help, look to find the answer on your own.
> Occasional need to work longer hours. If you have a project that needs to be finished, then you've got to put your head down and finish it. Sometimes it's not an easy ride, but it's the culture that has be adhered to sometimes if the company as a whole wants to continue performing at its peak.

headline: Military Hire
pros: Accenture is active in acquiring the best talent that is leaving the Armed Forces. They have realised there is a huge knowledge base to be utilised from hiring Military Leavers. As a company Accenture is second to none, good level of wage, amazing employee benefits and the feeling of being a big family.
cons: Because of the nature of work conducted by Accenture there does feel as though there is a sink or swim mentality...They want you to succeed as it is in the best interests of the company and its clients, however if you don't cut the mustard so to say, you may find yourself out of the door.

headline: Manager
pros:
Great people
Wide range of experience  will be offered to you
Great Mentors
cons: Need to ensure you have a proactive careers councillor

location: Slough, Berkshire, South East England, England, England

- Process Oriented
- Employee Friendly
- Flexible Working Hours
- Good Brand Image
cons:
- At times can act like a typical Indian IT company
- should be more transparent with processes
- should have better compensation

headline: Great place to work, excellent for career development
pros:
Top industry standard training
Career progression with great networking opportunities
Great incentives
Can't complain about salary

unless you are highly motivated, you will struggle
Hard work and regular long hours

headline: Accenture Strategy review
pros:
Breadth of clients and challenging project work 
Level of collaboration between individuals and teams 
Benefits
cons:
Large organisation can make navigating a career path harder
Can feel like a number  
Frequently quite long / unpredictable hours, making it difficult to commit to activities outside work

headline: Great company to work for.
pros: Smart minds as peers.  Interesting work.
cons: Working long hours to deliver on commitments to clients.

headline: Consultant
pros: #NAME?
cons:
- Long hours
- Performance Management is often not a fair representation of talent, effort or actual performance

headline: Good, can be better, but its learning and does make efforts to improve as a company
pros: Wide variety of projects and roles you can be part of, almost anything in the world of business and business technology is done by Accenture.
cons: Too large, can feel lost in the organisation, while efforts and processes are in place to ensure this is avoided, it can still happen. Ironically while the company delivers new technology to its clients, some internal systems are still quite dated and are due a refresh.

headline: Good foundation for professional development - challenging and steep learning curve but with required support
pros:
- Surrounded by bright and driven colleagues who you can learn from
- Build solid foundation of transferable skills
- Opportunities to travel
- Variety of projects
- Work hard/ Play hard environment
cons:
- Work/life balance can be challenging
- Can be challenging / receive push-back if you choose a 'non-traditional' career path
- Corporate and sometimes bureaucratic environment

headline: Business Development Consultant
pros: Wined and dined in some of the best places, early responsibility, very intelligent and driven colleagues, opportunities to travel, benefit package
cons: Sexism is rife in some areas, dominance of old partner attitude, often doing pieces of work that never get used or appreciated, lack of troughs - too many peaks, often pay lip service to care for employees, very stressful environment, pressure to beat your peers

headline: Accenture is a good place to work with smart and nice colleagues
pros: Good clients and projects, quality of people
cons: work life balance and Overloaded performance management process, which doesn't deliver value to candidates and organisation

headline: Analyst
pros: Great environment working with people that will support and develop you. Projects are all interesting and varied, and you can create your own career path.
cons: Work life balance fluctuates depending on project delivery stage - makes making certain plans difficult outside of work

headline: ACG Graduate Recruitment Process
pros: Fast turnover, total time from application to offer was about a month. Fairly simple assessment centre, friendly and welcoming recruiters
cons: Lack of choice between management consulting and technology consulting, you are given whichever aligns best with the company's needs and current situation

location: Swindon, Wiltshire, South West England, England, England
headline: Great place, not for the faint-hearted!
pros: Great benefits, focus on teamwork, training, everyone is encouraged as an individual despite the size of the organisation. A good proportion of functional leadership remains very accessible, with a surprising number of genuinely inspiring individuals. Massively diverse organisation without being contrived. Genuinely a role for everyone, as long as you are good and willing to work hard.
cons: Self-discipline is a necessity - they will let you work every hour in the day if you show willing, but are respectful of boundaries as long as you set them and keep to them. They invest a lot in enabling you with tools, training etc BUT nothing is done for you - you have to be confident to take ownership of your role and your career and not be afraid of networking, asking questions, reaching out. This is not a company for shirkers, wallflowers or those not afraid to ask the dumb question, there is so much going on you will never know everything. You need to be able to deal with pressure and keep self-aware.

headline: Interesting work, good people
pros:
Motivated by the people you work with
Every day is a new challenge
Get to work on interesting and exciting clients and technologies
cons:
You need to manage your own work Life balance, no one else will do that for you

Can be very stressful during certain project phases

headline: Great company to work for if you are not very concerned about pay
pros:
Accenture cares for its employees and within the teams there is generally a great culture.
There is a healthy competition within teams as everyone has a chance to show their skill and talents and be recognised. It is up to the employee to ensure he/she is getting the best out of their roles. Lots of help and support is available to improve your career.
You can get a good work and life balance, but need to ensure you clarify your requirement with your supervisor and agree on your work pattern.
Lots of communities and clubs to join and enjoy free/discounted activities
cons: Pay is not as great as some other companies offer but in comparison you get something more valuable to my opinion and that is respect.

headline: It's great if you end up in a good team
pros: I was lucky enough to work in the most interesting areas of the business, and did not have to travel too much. So I was surrounded by really bright people and exposed to a huge variety of skills, industries and clients.
cons: Many people end up working on dull projects in boring locations. Often a giant consulting firm struggles to be dynamic and we're constantly compromising to meet client price demands which means many teams are constantly understaffed.

headline: Great people to work with
pros: People, good pay and generous 10k sign on bonus. Lots of motivated and interesting people to work with and a very nice culture of collaboration
cons: Can be placed in a sector you're not interested in, some can work long hours, HR are terrible and very disorganised - makes on boarding process v stressful - no direct contact in the UK for recruitment questions - only a hotline based offshore.

headline: Successfactors Manager
pros: Good clients exposure, good assets and methodology, helpful colleagues, 30 days annual vacation with 5 days carry forward, good pension.
cons: No recognition and promotion for lateral hires, mediocre colleagues who survive due to internal SME help, glass ceiling and very subtle racism. Promotion is dependent on likes and dislikes of manager.

headline: Worked for 18 years - reason why I've stayed
pros:
Good people to work with - slackers are found out and don't stay
Supportive leadership team
Good experience
Good strong culture
cons:
Can be hard work - We don't do the easy stuff our clients can do themselves
No bench in outsourcing. Once your role finishes you have to find another one or get made redundant

headline: Great choice if you can be flexible with your time
pros:
-Challenging and interesting strategy work with leading global businesses.
-Lots of career prospects if you self-manage your path.
-Curious, intelligent, ambitious colleagues that aim to deliver a high level of quality and sophistication in Strategy projects.
-Generally speaking, big egos are rare.
-Less process and admin than expected coming in as an experienced hire.
-Brand recognition second to none and the work (at least in Strategy) lives up to the reputation.
-Burning out teams with continuous excessive workload is good for no one; smart managers realize this.
-If you're staffed with a fair manager on a supportive team, you'll need to be flexible and work hard during demanding project times but will get a good work-life balance most of the time.
-Work-life balance is your responsibility and no one else's -- manage it appropriately and things will go well most of the time.
-Compensation is competitive.
-Extremely supportive of flexible working and work-from-home -- treated as completely normal way of working in most teams.
cons:
-Work-life balance suffers on projects which are poorly scoped or run by managers that a.) can't scope work properly or b.) don't care about balance. Don't get stuck on repeat engagements with these people.
-Huge consulting projects with endless deliverables can be a grind if staffed long-term, but this is less of an issue in Strategy.
-Not enough training for business development process and tools.
-Endless PPT even for senior staff; over-reliant when other communication methods are a lot simpler and make a lot more sense.
-Deep collaboration tools are primitive (beyond IM -- e.g. realtime document collaboration, etc) given the solutions the company sells.
-Many levels of seniority within very few job titles a bit strange compared to the market.

headline: Graduates only
pros: Great for grads.  Some very interested clients and technologies.
cons: Not great for non grads

headline: Nice company to realise your long term career plans
pros:
- Project based and there is an abundance of projects to do in various sectors, practices etc.
- Diverse networking opportunities
- Chance to receive training at areas you want to improve yourself in
cons: - Too project-dependant, if you enroll in a project, there is a good chance you will be stuck with it until the project reaches its natural end - so there is always the risk of enrolling in one that you realise you don't like the down the line.

headline: Manager
pros: Good opportunities to travel with the job
cons: Very impersonal working environment due to size

headline: SuccessFactors Consultant UK
pros: Good employee benefits, Good customers to work with, people are generally helpful and respond quickly. There are a few projects currently in SuccessFactors. Good for short term employment if you are an experienced professional.
cons: Salary is very low compared to market rate.Do not expect promotions if you are an experienced hire. There is a culture to promote the analysts and fresh graduates. This do not bring in fresh air and thought leadership into the company. Appraisal process is based on favouritism and so complicated that you never have a chance if you are not on personal good book of the manager. Long working hours and no work-life balance. Long hours are appreciated and not the quality of work. In SuccessFactors there has been no successful projects so far in UK. Not many qualified resources in UK and neither the training plans are supportive. The new appraisal system introduced by the CEO is so ambiguous that even the board of directors and HR managers have no clue how this will be implemented. The new appraisal system is even more reliant on managers to rate employees, just another way to promote favouritism.Career opportunities are low. You neither get exposure to grow up not a hands on configuration experience as everything is offshored. The consultants in UK are mere coordinators and lack any consulting or successfactors skills. None is experienced in SuccessFactors delivery unless just freshly hired as an experienced hire.

headline: Tough, but largely rewarding place to work
pros: Roles are challenging and good exposure to client and senior management
cons: 'Need' to undertake extra-curricular activities to give you the edge over your colleagues; lots of talk about ability to move industries intra-Accenture but actually very difficult.

headline: Overall great place
pros: Great working learning environment, focus on people, great culture
cons: Very hierarchical, too oriented to IT systems and big programmes

headline: Great place to work
pros:
Working away from home, long term, is amazing. Really well looked after.
Great people to work with.
cons:
Wage is a little low.
A lot promised as benefits, very little available at the lower levels.

headline: Consultant
pros: Hard-working, intelligent colleagues, travel (depending where)
cons: Travel (depending where), better paid elsewhere

headline: Mr

headline: Great company to work with

cons: India centre middle Mgmt not that great. Typical reserved mindset not promoting the younger generation who are excellent at their tasks.

- Challenging environment

headline: Good start ooint
pros: People and exposure, opportunities to work on a diverse client base and really own a piece of work end to end
cons: Performance management process is appalling and favours spending time with partners over quality of work and client feedback. Company is lost when it comes to people management

headline: Great place to start and for ambitious outgoing people
pros:
- Generally very high calibre of colleagues
- If you are naturally outgoing you will quickly develop your own network and can essentially direct your own career. You'll find you get the best projects if you actively go out looking for them.
- You won't have to do regular 70 hour weeks like some consulting places. I'm regularly out the door by 6pm and still get all my work done. 
- Lots of opportunities for overseas work and transfers if you want.
- Famous training facility in the USA which everyone can go to for additional training and drinking opportunities.
cons:
- Pay is OK but not market leading
- Performance review process is a bit antiquated and is seen as a bit of a 'game'
- The structure of the business means you don't often feel like you've got a close team you regularly work with. You will be lucky to regularly work with people in your 'home' team. The business is more ordered around client accounts and projects. If you want to feel part of a small team it's not the place for you.

headline: Great opportunities, poor performance management
pros: Great opportunities, smart hard-working people
cons: Poor performance management, bad work/life balance

pros:
Treat you like a member of the team

headline: Just another employer.
pros: 'Be Positive' and 'Be helpful' mentality. Great place to start your career.
cons: Somewhat politically bureaucratic. You can prosper if you 'network' (with the right people). This means that if you work good and hard but do not have good contacts in the right places, you go nowhere. Not very 'family' friendly and rarely has any family meets or events. Seems to be a 'first company' for the young ones.

headline: Senior Consultant - Experienced hire
pros: Good brand, opportunity for training & development, lots of events, opportunity to work on a vast number of projects with high calibre individuals
cons: Very bureaucratic, poor work/life balance, very poor performance management, difficult for experienced hires to succeed which is why there is such a high attrition, some of the worst managers I have worked with, below average pay, it's like a cool kids club....if you're not one then you'll either leave due to the lack of opportunity or get managed out

headline: Managing Director
pros:
Diverse clients facing challenging problems.
Opportunity to work at the intersection of technology and business.
Organisation tries to lead by example and constantly reinvent itself.
Exemplary track record in terms of walking the diversity talk.
cons:
Rigidly attached to people based growth model and has struggled to break free for years.
All employees measured in exactly the same way independent of role or context.
Huge expectation of travel and mobility.

headline: Technology Consultant
pros: Variety of projects and clients
cons: Not always aligned or in control of career growth opportunities

headline: Experienced Hire
pros: Diversity of work, People, Opportunities, working environment, Culture are all key things that I have found Accenture do really well
cons: The experienced hire induction process is not as fluid as it potentially could be especially for those that are coming from an industry background and do not have previous consulting experience

headline: Has pros and cons, does not fit all people
pros: Recognition of people, positive can-do work culture, training and development, integrity of leadership
cons: Demanding on personal life with long hours, suitable for people who can cope with the stress

headline: People love the people but management should pay attention to them
pros: People, variety of work, less focus on hierachy, outcome focus, travel, fast assumption of responsibility.
cons: Pigeonholing people incorrectly or before their career has really taken off. Occasionally you feel as just a small part in a big machine- HR should focus at client level rather than business level.

headline: A behemoth consulting company where networking pays off
pros: Excellent training opportunities, and good growth opportunities, if you are on the right project or know the right people
cons: You can be pigeon holed very quickly in to one line of work, and it can be very hard to get re-assigned

headline: So far So Good
pros: Fantastic career opportunities, Great people, Ability to manage work life balance
cons: Hard to make significant changes fast

headline: Manager / Principal
pros: Buzz, energy, smart people with loads of ideas. You'll meet a load of very clever, very ambitious hard-working people. Loads of training. Incredible execution machine - hang onto your hat. You'll learn loads about business and about yourself.
cons: Terrible internal communication, can be very stovepiped. The appraisal and employee rating system set people against each other, though it's supposedly being replaced. Everything needs a charge code, and everyone with budget just funds immediate stuff, so more intelligent planning stuff often doesn't  happen because people won't fund it. There's sometimes a lack of team spirit, as everyone does their own thing and competes with everyone else.

headline: Mixed bag.
pros: Provides the opportunity to work in various industries within a short space of time. Great place for fresh graduates to progress.
cons: Many not be suitable for experience hires as the company is geared towards recruitment straight from University. Experience hires must make sure they go in at the right level and be-aware of what they are getting into. As many of the employees have worked only for Accenture, they have limited experience and therefore are not as adaptable as they could be or open to new ideas. Parts of the company are a little backwards in valuing programme/project managers with specific technical knowledge above those with proven programme/project management skills, to the detriment of successfully delivering projects. Technical knowledge can be acquired, it is more important that programme/project managers are able to adapt to the environment and apply their experience and knowledge to successfully deliver.

headline: Poor management
pros:
Offers plenty of opportunities for networking and moving sideways within the company
Comfortable working culture - depending on which team
cons:
No guarantee of full-time position after six months and very inconvenient notice period 
Poor communication between management and staff; feedback rarely or poorly given for performance
Poor career advice for new joiners 
Too process-oriented and not result-oriented

headline: Great to some, hated by others
pros:
Interesting and exciting project

Great offices
Prestige
cons:
You are expected to travel a lot so not a great choice for people with kids
You won't enjoy it if corporate culture is not your cup of tea
Pay could be better
Stress, pressure and long hours

headline: Ok
pros: Big company, strong brand name (everyone knows who they are) with exposure to large and interesting projects. Good to progress your career.

headline: A good company to work for, the company is very keen on self development so encourage employees to take annual training.

job_title: Computer and Information Systems Manager II

cons: Can work long hours - but I find this also intresting.

headline: Industrial Placement Review
pros: Great people, everyone is friendly and welcoming from the beginning. You get to work on interesting projects that are changing the way many industries work ranging from health to finance.
cons: There can be times when it is required to work overtime to complete deliverables on time. But this is the same across most companies if not all.

headline: Great Company
pros: I loved the people I worked with unfortunately left as my husband got a wonderful job abroad and I wanted us to move as a family.

you can get involved if you ask

away from technology, the projects are mostly operational related
very often get stuffed on projects not fitting to the skills
salary is not as competitive as other consultancies

value focused

headline: Working at Accenture
pros: Global company, great reputation, access to large projects and cutting edge software
cons:
Accenture use ADM (Accenture Delivery Methods) which must work or they wouldn't be where they are as a business.  BUT, you aren't encouraged to think outside the ADMs and I felt that experience previous to Accenture is not valued.

If you just do a great job you won't get promotion, you need ot do a lot of extra activities and make sure your managers are aware.  Managers can tent to be very patronizing.

headline: Will learn much more elsewhere (boring)

headline: Autonomy to manage your work
pros:
We don't put our job title on the email signatures to avoid the grade game.

cons: Induction is pretty slim. You can be left all alone to produce results and help may take some time to arrive.

headline: Brilliant
pros: Great place. Got the sense that everyone was behind you to help you deliver. Culture definitely combines the best of everyone.
cons: Must actively manage your own career. Important not to get lost in such a vast organisation.

headline: A great experience
pros:
I have been part of the UX team in the UK (prior Mobility then Interactive).
Really skilled people.
Lots of opportunities.
Facilities are great.
Management is transparent and comprehensive to some levels.
Many benefits.
cons:
Can sometimes be boxed in a role doing the same task, competency.
Sometimes long hours.
Travelling is frequent all over the world can be frequent.

headline: Consultant
pros: Great culture. Flexible working. Good internal communities
cons: non competitive salary. especially in non MC consulting workforce

headline: Good starter company
pros: Good brand on your CV straight out of university but the work given to analysts is dull and there is little thought given to your industry preferences
cons: You have no choice over your first project and there is little choice even after you are promoted.  However the pool of talent is so large that they can afford to lose you.

headline: Sets you up for bigger things
pros: Great people, teaches you the fundamentals well, good salary, transparent career progression, recognised market leader, opportunities for international travel, massive breadth of work.
cons: Can be long(er) hours than one might expect, limited career control when junior, may not meet graduate expectations, can be male dominated towards the top, transparent promotion process can also be a cause of stress.

headline: Recommended - you can impact business.
pros: The People. Time flexibility. Project variety. Great impact into clients and the world of business.
cons: As most consulting companies, feels less cohesive than working in industry. You don't get all the project choice you'd like. Peaks are tiring but you survive. Coming as an experienced hire is difficult, since you don't get the same training as for university graduates - and you need to compete with them for promotions. It is a kind competition though - not negative or antagonistic.

headline: Yep that was itn
pros: Helpful good on cv and makes you look better with it on it so it can be better with the formula.
cons: Annoying work people and just so bad like I want to squeeze them like oranges. That's how bad they are right.

headline: Current Employee
pros: Good training and people development
cons: MBA sponsorship is very hard to get

headline: Hard but rewarding, ideally would have liked wider breadth of industry experience
pros: Benefits, security and the high quality reputation of the company which is backed up everyday by the people you work with
cons: Standard issues with working for a big company, sometimes the experience feels impersonal and senior management efforts to change this have sometimes seem forced

headline: Corporate Culture
pros: Good opportunities to travel, good salary and clear path for advancement
cons: Everyone living for work breeds an unpleasant, overly competitive culture. Also try to pigeon hole you into a certain area

headline: Associate Software Engineer
pros: Fantastic people, great fleibility for work, great leadership and varied work
cons: Sometimes tricky to balance work and life, but this does average out often. Training isn't as easy to get as advertised

headline: Great Company
pros: Great people, great training, great clients
cons: Process can get you down at times

headline: Great company, Great people
pros:
- Feel like the employer really looks after you 
- People are all very friendly, very intelligent and capable
- "Family" culture
cons:
- Need to take control of your own career path
- Can get stuck on a project you don't like for long periods of time

headline: Great benefits for hard work
pros: Company pays well and has excellent benefits for its employees but expects hard work in return.
cons: Working away from home for long hours can limit social life

headline: Senior Manager
pros: Strong culture and people are great, many training opportunities
cons: Poor performance management and thus career progression can be hampered

headline: Micromanage and Inexperienced Management
pros:
Hardworking individuals across the company.
Good Brand
cons:
Inexperienced Middle management and applies fear management to control individuals.
Middle managers takes the credit of their team members and they kept the team in the dark

headline: Senior Manager
pros: Used to be pretty autonomous work
cons: now too much oversight by executives

headline: The worst company I ever worked for
pros: Work / life balance was good, pay was fair.
cons:
The real issue with Accenture is that nobody cares and regardless of all the lies and dreams you will be sold through their 'culture', you are unimportant to them. Management (particularly those one or two levels above you) will happy throw you under the bus quick as look at you, HR will ignore you unless they believe that their job is at risk. 
to top it off, if you are signed off with a serious mental health condition expect to receive a performance review in your absence and be criticised for symptoms of your condition, one they have been aware of for 24 months. 
I wouldn't recommend Accenture to my worst enemy.

headline: Good if you fit in
pros: Great social events at the London office, really make an effort to have something planned every week
cons: If you don't find someone to help you navigate, hard to get great roles

headline: Lagging behind competitors
pros: Exposure to different clients, industries
cons: Lack of innovation, culture hinders everything due to recent restructure. Too much focus now on industry group due to P&L and less in developing functional skills.

headline: Manager
pros: Plenty of opportunities across the company
cons: Politics and networking need to be actively addressed

headline: Impersonal corporate behemoth
pros: Remuneration at the company is probably around average for the roles they have. The company performs well financially. There are a lot of benefits such as generous pensions.
cons: Management is impersonal if existent at all (I have met my manager once in two and a half years). There is no team culture, rather people are interested in how you can help them and their careers. Because of this real friendships are rare. Internal politics is rife at all levels as people push for promotions or bonuses. Senior leadership are not held to account for performance of the company, rather more junior employees will feel the brunt. There are few training or development opportunities. High performers are not identified due to talent rather because of hours put in - dedication is rewarded rather than competence. There is little to no innovation done within the company or ability to identify innovation in industry until after the fact.

headline: Great company to work for
pros:
- A large number of well established clients (almost any major company is a client of some sort).
- Working with bright hard working people
- Great brand in the marketplace so easier to find work afterwards if have it on your CV
- Good alumni network
cons: #NAME?

headline: Very under paid and overworked.
pros: All staff are in the same boat and understand each other's position. Artificially creates a social company with everybody supporting each other.
cons: Overworked, understaffed on customer sites, pushing near shoring and off shoring, very low paid compares to other tier 1 and tier 2 service integrators.

headline: A good base but needs a rethink
pros: working with like-minded and talented people, leave of absence program, the salary is fine but should increase at level with time, so much to get involved with
cons: lack of control of career, lack of clear career path - people can get lost in the crowd if they allow their career to be dictated by others, scheduling is a nightmare, training could be alot better as could flexibility on the part of management and infrastructure

headline: Team Lead
pros: Great team culture - work hard and play hard
cons: No downtime - you have to be always plugged-in.

headline: Choose any career path you like
pros:
Work within any industry and any business /technology field
Fantastic real people that know how to get things done
Build whatever consulting path you want (particularly if starting as an Analyst)
Lots of holidays and lots of training opportunities as well as great charity days
cons:
