The strict HR related processes that come with a large company. Pre-start date communications particularly bad, promotions are very structured. Remote IT services for employee equipment is bad (although local is very good)
Being so big it takes time to understand how to the whole thing fits together, where you sit and what the possibilities are for you - once you do it is a hard place to fault.

headline: Good company to start your professional career
pros:
Good place to develop your analytical skills
Global company gives you lots of international exposure
cons: Salary does not stay competitive after a few promotions

headline: My almost 2 years at Accenture
pros:
- Exposure to different client and industries.
- Expenses are quite generous dependent on project
- Get to travel and visit places
- Develop your presentation and communication skills
- Makes you more of a brutal person generally (career wise)
cons:
- A nightmare if you end up on the worong career track i.e In siolutions the renumeration is frankly a disgrace.
- Gaining promotion is an exhaustive process 
- Have to maintain a close relationship with the right people to progress.
- Also an unethical culture exist were individuals are brought from offshore to carry out work in th the UK at a pittance and certain element of exploitation exist.

headline: Great company to work for!
pros:
I joined as an Analyst straight from University.  I joined right onto Accenture's Graduate program which was made up of two weeks London based training and then two weeks international training where I went to Chicago (there is an alternative option of going to India).  This whole process was amazing and I was put with around 70 others within my start group.  The training was excellent and now I have been working within the company for a longer period of time I can confirm that the training was very comprehensive and really did prepare us for the type of work and scenarios that we have been placed in.  And some of the friends and experiences and events within the company have been amazing.  It is both organised and well structured for everything you can ask for.  

The people within Accenture really do make it special I would like to think that I have made some amazing friends for life from within the company.  The work is also interesting and varied and even if you do not like the project to which you are first placed upon you can leave at around 8 months to something new.  Within Accenture networking and going to events is key to getting onto an exciting and dynamic project.  I myself made friends with a consultant whilst in Chicago and was placed into a project within my first week at Accenture.  

Also the opportunities to network and meet people from different areas of the company are ample and all you need do is seek them out and its as easy as that and due to the vast nature of the company it is easy to talk to people with a lifetimes experience spanning a breadth of different industries.  The networks and societies also are fantastic, I joined the LGBT in week one and they are fantastic and provide ample events, charities to get involved in, friends and an amazing insight into London.  Any one looking to join Accenture need only look up what they are most interested in and I can tell you there will be a network or society to sign up to. 

Ohh and the benefits are pretty great, basis salary of £31,5000 and a bonus of £10,000.  Generous share plan, health insurance, amazing pension plan, expense account and expense card which racks me up on BA air miles and the amount of hotel reward points I now have is amazing.  There are loads of other benefits but these can be looked up.
cons: The cons I would say come with the territory, longer than average working hours, although not horrific.  A lack of time spent at home due to living in hotels for 3-4 days a week depending on the project to which you are placed and the ramifications this does have on ones social life.  I myself have had to turn down some amazing events in London and night with my friends due to being places on my project at the moment outside of London.  However if I did want to move to a role based in London there is the opportunity to do this at some point if I find I am no longer happy being away from home for so long.

headline: 6 years in...
pros: Client base, competitive, opportunities, access to new tech
cons: Rigid career progression. Politics.

headline: Set your expectations - it's an IT company
pros: Decent pay and perks, opportunity to travel, professional support, excellent technical training opportunities, great colleagues.
cons: Long hours, regular travel expectations, work can be highly technical.

headline: Good Place to work, long hours
pros: Training investment into employees, wide range of work
cons: Hierarchical. work life balance

headline: Great Opportunities
pros:
- Great training opportunities available
- Excellent support given to graduates, slowly easing graduates into the working environment but some may argue the pace is too slow
- Wide range of roles available 
_ a lot of interest groups available so there is something for everyone
- Excellent work life balance
cons:
- Difficulty to access these training facilities provided
- Salary and benefits are a bit less than competitors
- Analysts and associates sometimes are not taken on-board projects they like rather they are forced to work on projects they've had previous experience in. We are analysis because we don't have a wealth of experience and would like to get some experience in a range of industries and in a range of roles

headline: Good Company for gaining experience
pros:
Lots of opportunities to learn new technologies and network with people.
Relaxed Environment
25 days annual vacation.
HR support is also good.
cons:
They offer less pay to a software engineering intern as compared to other companies. 
sometimes it is hard to maintain work life balance as there is always a lot of work.

headline: Work-life imbalance
pros: Bright people, access to opportunities, training, continuous learning, looks good on CV. You will learn to deliver outcomes. You will learn to work hard and assimilate large quantities of information quickly. You will have fun and feel a sense of achievement.
cons: It's a political machine; if you don't know what you want to do and don't set up the right network you will get lost in the system; promotions are hard-won battles; performance management is not transparent and subject to favouritism; people are resources to be trained and deployed; work-life balance is a challenge and persistent long hours are expected; working away from home makes it difficult to maintain a normal social life with non-work interests which takes an increasing toll over the years.

headline: Inclusive great place to work
pros:
- large global network of genuinely engaged people
- great company benefits
- huge variety of roles and industries
cons: #NAME?

headline: Great Company, Great People
pros: The people are some of the most intelligent you will work with. Great benefits
cons: Long hours and poor work life balance

headline: Manager
pros:
Excellent opportunities to learn
Fantastic training
Great clients
Plenty of community events to get involved in, enjoy and learn
cons: The importance of a strong network through the promotion process is crucial. However, comparing to usual 'closed door' performance management, transparency is as good as it can be for a global company with 360k employees.

headline: Great People
pros: Great people. Good starting salary. Good networking opportunities
cons: It can be very difficult to move off projects if the client is happy with you. There has been a cut back in training opportunities for analysts and within Financial Services.

headline: Not for everyone
pros: Big clients to work ; lots of exposure
cons: "Notice me" attitude of the average employee just to get promoted

headline: General Review
pros: The most prominent thing you will notice after joining Accenture is the code of conduct and work life balance.
cons: Salary is not competitive to market rates thus pushing attrition. internal growth/ promotions can sometimes be a challenge

headline: Analyst
pros:
Broad range of opportunities
Great training schemes
cons:
Terrible corporate culture - Up or Out
Promotion does equal effort/performance

headline: Good
pros: Massive company, great location with good people to work with. Progression really good. Work is exciting and engaging. Excelled opportunities.
cons: Not many as of yet, compensation progression not to good. Levels not too good, long hours apart from that all good

headline: Senior Manager
pros: Great Colleagues and great company to work if you want to grow in your career and learn new things.
cons: Work Life balance is not great as you move up the career [i.e. senior manager and above].. You promotion after Senior manager is based on how many directors can vouch for you and support you rather than your hard work and your capability in deliver or client relationships.

headline: Graduate Software Engineer
pros: Amazing place to start a new career. Nice opportunities and perfect organisation for people who love to travel. Work life balance is perfect.
cons: Hard to find the exact role you want due to massive competition. Sometimes travelling gets hectic.

headline: Mixed experience in Strategy
pros: Good benefits, pay is equivalent to Big 4 in general, and you get some exposure to disruptive/ highly relevant topics of today
cons: Very difficult coming in as an experienced hire, or from an MBA (very few top MBAs stick it out for long here), little coaching or guidance or training is given for that matter. Highly political environment and performance is not assessed on how well you deliver but how well you face time/ connect with the MDs. Lots of internal politics between management consulting and strategy as well. Alignment outside of the main competencies of digital or technology strategy, is difficult as you end up on random projects to keep your chargeability acceptable, even if it does not fit with your career aspirations. Mixed bag of skills and abilities within the firm as well.

headline: Good
pros: good learning opportunities and big overseas projects
cons: salary is not according to its brand

headline: Excellent .. Truly High Performance Delivery
pros:
Great place to work
Immense Knowledge Repository
Great people and processes
Highly motivating environment 
Opportunities to work across geographies
cons: Except the new performance achievement have to watch how it works after moving out of the bell curve

headline: Good Company Overall but you may get lost inside
pros: Good Company to work for, loads of training opportunities, very talented people, many opportunities and projects to work for across different industries which gives a great exposure
cons:
- Very difficult to gain visibility or to get promoted , depends on lots of relationship and to be lucky in good project
- Experienced hires are not placed at their right level, they are placed in almost two level below their real experience which is demotivating to a great extent 
- You may end up doing lots of  admin work if you did not choose the right role.
- Very low pay scale for experienced hired
- Your senior manager can be younger and less experienced that you !!

headline: Nice
pros: good money, educated people, nice people, interesting projects. They provide free fruit in the mornings. They have helpful performace reviews. They want you to get prometed. They help you develop your skills.
cons: travel and expenses can make you unhealthy. You need to join a gym., IIf you had kids being away from home might be less enjoyable. When working in another country the expenses are not good.

headline: A whole ecosystem
pros: Mind blowingly huge and does everything. Excellent people and management. Strong vision and visible implementation of this means the company is always changing.
cons: Lots of compliance and process arising from the need to control such a large ecosystem. Up side: they make it as painless as possible with great tools, but still needs doing.

headline: Overview
pros: Great benefits, smart people, good opportuinities
cons: Potential to get lost in a big organisation, at times long hours

headline: EA
pros: Great colleagues and Working from home option
cons: low salary and not much room for progression

headline: Internship review
pros: Really interesting and cool work... And the variety of work is immense. You get to learn a lot, very quickly!
cons: Amount of work varies from project to project. But you will always have fantastic line manager to support you!

headline: Challenging and interesting work - surrounded by clever and motivated people and there are a wealth of opportunities
pros:
Interesting work across a breadth of topics
Diverse clients and project types
Opportunities to learn and develop
Good salary
cons:
Projects available can sometimes not align to skill set
Relies on proactivity to feel part of the culture; can feel a bit overwhelming initially if an experienced hire used to more welcoming environments

headline: accenture is the best
pros: A company that allows it employees to grow and develop
cons: nothing really. a great company to work for.

headline: Great firm
pros: Great firm to work for - goo dlearning opportunities
cons: Can be hard work - long hours

headline: Great company
pros: Great company, great travel opportunities to work on different projects across the world
cons: Very minimal - if you want to learn this is the place to be. Be prepared to work hard, and fight for what project you want and align your career to.

headline: Good Company with excellent people
pros:
Opportunities to work on large transformation programs.
Smart colleagues and opportunities to learn from them.
Excellent people policies and up-skilling programs
cons: Promotions at senior level depend a lot on networks. This puts experienced hires at a severe disadvantage as some networks are groups of people who have spent their lives at Accenture

headline: Good or bad depends on your account and yourself
pros: Depends on the account you are in, but if your account allows then flexible working hours, work from home option, 9 month full maternity pay, 15% discount on shares, life insurance, pensions
cons:
Depends on the account you are in, but your account may need you to travel. 

There is constant pressure to be in an account and this means you need to take up the next opportunity even if may not be right for yourself. 

Work is always taxing and high pressure.

headline: Great wokring environment
pros: The mix of clients allows you to speacialise in more industries despite the technology centric name Accenture has gained. Benefits allow you to weigh the work/life balance well, such as gym subscriptions.
cons: Long working hours, can get stressful underdeadlines.

headline: Overly positive
pros:
Ethical
Invests in it's people, plenty of opportunities to develop a career
Lot's of talented people to work with
cons:
Leadership "heavy"

Difficult Work/Life balance for Consultants/ Analysts if you want to get on

headline: Good but Ruthless
pros:
Great people in a central location in London
Work is hard and busy but rewarding
Defined processes and reporting structure
cons:
Not much room for movement unless you are a consultant
Low pay comapred to other simolar jobs in the market.

headline: Great place to start your career
pros: Structured training, clear career path, able to work on multiple projects and clients, great introduction to business and consulting.
cons: Difficult to work cross-vertical, company wants you to specialise quickly, tough performance management process, very corporate, a huge amount of effort required to stand out from other analysts and consultants

headline: Great employer - if you have the balls for the job
pros:
* Opportunities for greater responsibility available if you push for them
* Potentially good career progression
* Competitive pay
* Excellent brand for your CV
* Some extremely bright talent
cons:
* You have to play the 'game' to excel. Contacts are key to the laddering process
* You will not be pushed and people are seldom supported. Its more that stick, than the carrot approach
* Dog-eat-dog environment
* Career developments and personal needs are put well below the needs of the firm - more than usaul

headline: Good company, excellent for professional development
pros: Good benefits, loads of smart people to learn from, if you enjoy travelling for work this is the best company as they put you in good hotels plus you get to travel first class train tickets.
cons: Sometimes the scope of the project is not clear so the whole team waste many hours working on something unnecessary.

headline: Good company overall
pros:
Good place to grow your skils, but I can only speak for the UK projects where I have worked on.
It's the typical huge consulting company but I think (very subjective) is one of the best out there.
cons: Career path is subject to what they need rather on what you deserve. Huge turnover of resources, so for them is always a challenge to keep a decent and skilled workforce. It's common in projects to spend lots time and money in training your colleague how to do the job.

headline: Promise the world....
pros: Big company with fingers in many pies
cons: Poor management, hugely varied work projects but haphazardly managed and little flexibility towards staff.

headline: Ok for the beginners in consulting
pros: Experience gained will be very useful for future
cons: Non transparent performance management methods, poor behaviour/attitude of management and seniors

headline: consultant
pros: nice company to work for. good training
cons: small cog in a big machine.

headline: Storage Administrator
pros: Good alliances with strong partners which makes you take advantage of a continuous tech learning and trainings. Good core values. Good place to plan a career.
cons: Same cons as any big company (salaries slightly below the market, not big bonuses)

headline: Great company
pros: Great company with Los of opportunities
cons: More of a lifestyle than a job.

headline: Senior Consultant
pros: A lot of business travels, constant learning, interesting projects, big community
cons: low earnings, no bonus for consultants, high people turnover, mass approach

headline: Accenture review from an intern
pros: Accenture work with a large number of clients across multiple industries which allows you to work in an area of interest and change throughout your career.
cons: You are not always guaranteed a place on a client project which means you will be 'on the bench' doing nothing. Its as if you are constantly applying for jobs.

headline: Good Pay
pros: Variety of work and great people
cons: Too big and a lot of internal politics

headline: Sales Manager
pros:
Excellent Work Culture
Great career opportunities
cons:
If you're not pro-active, chances are you will be stuck
Lack of women at senior leadership and sales roles

headline: Hard work for good prospects
pros:
Great exposure to work with powerful clients. 
Extremely talented colleagues. 
Great 'thought leadership' and research pieces produced. 
Lots of great training available. 
Opportunities to move and work in any business area. 
Locations throughout the world.
cons:
Often long hours, typical of consulting. 
Demanding lifestyle - the travel is not for everyone!

headline: Accenture analyst
pros: great training for newly graduates and many social events for people moving to a new place. you are given a lot of responsibility quickly
cons: They advertise the job as being able to work on many projects and clients but realistically they will try to keep you on the same client as long as possible

headline: Horrible
pros: Very friendly people, lots of support, people really qualified and good perks. Lots of team building and you will definitely make lots of friends.
cons: HR are very very bad. I got an offer for Analyst and then they decided I would be better suited to Technology and put me there. When I voiced my ambition to move to Strategy with support from Strategy staff, I was let go because Technology leadership did not like it. HR during the recruitment process inform you that you are going for a general Analyst role with flexibility to move around business areas. It was the deciding factor that I rejected other offers for Accenture

headline: Accenture
pros: People are great, client are big. Work life balance varies by project, good annual pay rises
cons: lack to relevant on boarding training for experienced hire people who have technical skills but no consulting skills. Should devise a 1-week crash course

headline: Good place to start
pros: Variety, opportunities for fast progression, broad stakeholder exposure, trust to get the job done, experience across industries, innovation
cons: Long hours, luck of the draw on good projects, getting on the 'wrong side' of the performance process.

headline: Great opportunities, if you can tolerate the travel and politics
pros:
• Fantastic group of people – bright, motivated, ambitious and proactive.
• Unrivalled opportunities to work with and learn from genuine global experts in your discipline.
• Industry-leading benefits package including shared parental leave and many ancillary benefits.
• Excellent technology and systems – you always have the tools you need to do your job, with modern IT tools and admin systems, and things ‘just work’.
• Strong brand and instant credibility.
• Great training and development.
cons:
• Politics between different areas of the company can adversely affect impartiality in year-end performance management process. Performance management has historically also been extremely bureaucratic, although this did appear to be improving as I left in 2016.
• Aligning people by industry rather than by functional skill-set makes it harder to develop deep functional skills and build a network amongst like-minded individuals, while increasing exposure to boom-and-bust cycles in individual industries (e.g. 2008 credit crunch in Financial Services and 2014 oil price crash in Energy).
• Strong likelihood of travel to unglamorous locations for extended periods – with little flexibility for personal circumstances if demand dictates.

headline: Good on a CV - but very variable management
pros: Decent pay, good opportunities to work with big names, looks great on a cv
cons: very variable management, extremely long hours.

headline: Accenture Analyst
pros:
Many opportunities to learn
Great Knowledge Management
Great Client Portfolio and level of expertise
Great Employees
Great Extra-Curricular Activities
cons:
Bureaucratic creating a lack of flexibility if you want to explore different areas of the business
Low salary for work provided at A-level

headline: Fanastic Company!
pros: I worked at Accenture for 4 years and it was an amazing experience. Fantastic management and mentor support, worked alongside super smart people and lovely people, high promotion opportunities and clear career progression.
cons: Everyone is smart so can be difficult at times to get promoted!

headline: Great Company
pros:
They care very deeply for ensuring you are happy in the location you are working at.
They want to ensure you have something to do.
Offers of training and constantly looking for new opportunities for their people.
Senior Management like to connect with people of all career levels on a constant basis.
Great chances of travel, with benefits like Hilton stays and such.
Making sure you get your weekends.
You will be recognized for your work.
For the most part a very good work-life balance.
Their culture and attitudes to open-minded environments are incredibly true to heart.
cons:
Senior management sometimes think that meetings are more important than getting things done.
You have to be prepared to take the good with the bad.
You have to meet deadlines no matter what, and it can interfere with work-life balance.
Bringing on off-shore resources that aren't always the best for the situation.

headline: Intern
pros: Great benefits and perks such as hospitality football tickets
cons: HR do not show any interest in interns at all

headline: Security Consultant
pros: personal development, clients, projects, innovation, benefits.
cons: base salary, causes staff churn.

headline: na
pros: I have nothing specific to share on pros apart from a diverse culture that they have and they encourage it openly.
cons: No soecifc advise on cons as well as I am new to the firma nd do not have enough exposure now

headline: Great career builder
pros: Fantastic opportunities to move around the organisation and accelerate your career and experience.  Roles in HR can rotate as often as annually with high potential people continually stretched.  Lots of global opportunities and working with a very diverse workforce, which is exciting
cons: Its a large organisation and you need to be self sufficient in terms of your ability to network effectively to make sure you get the most out of your career with the business.

headline: Strong overall package tricky promotions
pros: Great overall package, particularly parental leave which is great and a whole range of other perks that are useful.
cons: Performance Management and alignment constantly shifting, can be frustrating for getting promotions.

headline: Getting too big...
pros: Benefits, home working, networking opportunities
cons: not being able to see/meet the team i work with, lots of red tape, too big

headline: Very happy employee
pros:
Large client set,
Huge career oportunities
cons: Too large organization, struggles to become more inclusive

headline: DevOps Engineer
pros: Enjoyable day-to-day work, Agile working (this will be project specific of course)
cons:
Better pay elsewhere, a lot of outsourced resources from other countries make the work very inpersonal and difficult to feel involved.

Within days of joining Accenture you're likely to be shipped off one of their clients, and therefore receive no benefits like you would in an Accenture office. In fact, in my entirety of working for Accenture, it doesn't really feel like i've worked for them at all, they just paid the wage.

You receive a HR Manager, Manager, Career councilor, who you will probably speak to once and then never again. Very little ongoing support for staff.

headline: Not a bad place to work if flexible travel is not an issue
pros: Flexible working, good training opportunities, good benefits, well known global brands to work for
cons: Too much travel, have to look for work, find your own project, often a mismatch between a skill set and available work, no bonus below manager level

headline: Great people
pros: good teams, interesting work, strong research
cons: some work can be mindnumbing, sometimes progression is down to luck

headline: Same old school mentality
pros: Relaxed management style, no hairdryer treatment.  Add resources if raised that gaps are missing, good name to work for,
cons: Alot of offshoring of varying ability. Old school mentality of a lot of shutting away in meeting rooms and spreadsheet proliferation.  Don't really understand agile development.  Very PC. Contractors are 2nd class citizens. Non existence IT support, rigid outdated global rules. Long hours

headline: Consultant
pros: Good environment to work. Very friendly
cons: salary not competitive with respect to market

headline: Associate Manager Review
pros: Brand, Experience, exposure, Learn the Acenture Delivery and Sales Methods, Get to manage teams
cons: Low pay, Long Hours (50hours is a standard expectation)

headline: Management Consultant
pros: Good career progression and company benefits, such as charity days, six weeks holiday, gym subsidies etc.  Good quality of people to work with and range of work, if you are lucky enough to meet the right people.  Training and rigour, both classroom and on-the-job is excellent and it is easy to see when working with a client.
cons: The work can be not as exciting as it is sold to you.  Success has a lot to do with luck and opportunity, but there is plenty to make the most of.

headline: Good start for those who want to be customer-facing. Not so good for more technically-minded people
pros:
- Great for those who enjoy networking 
- Lots of customer-facing roles
- Perks and support
- Opportunities to travel
- Variety of roles
cons:
- Pretty poor for anyone who wants to do more technical work (e.g. programming)
- Long hours
- Salaries are pretty low compared to rival consultancies
- Your technical skills will most likely be under-utilised as the firm will rely on offshore resources
- You will be oversold and underutilized to clients.
- Laddering/Promotional structure relies less on skill and more on 'who you know'/politicking

headline: Interesting work, but you feel like you're just a number
pros: High learning curve, well-known company that stands out in your CV, several employee discounts everywhere
cons:
Promotions depends 90% on how much you flatter the right Senior people and I have just recently seen 2 colleagues been "demoted" from a Sr Manager level to just Manager. First time I experience this in a company! 
Zero margin for negotiation of salary/bonus/conditions: you're just a number.
I suggest you to join Accenture only as a Fresh Graduate for maybe 2 years or enter already as Sr Manager. Everything in-between is not worth.

headline: Caricature of a corporate nightmare
pros: Structured if you like that kind of thing, okay pay, access to training, good quality co-workers, opportunity to work across a lot of different industries, semi-recognisable name on CV.
cons: Accenture doesn't help clients, it only wants to make clients dependent on them. You better like staying in hotels for the most precious and important years of your 20s.  New employees are just a safe pair of hands to do the work that nobody more senior wants to do. Long hours. Low morale. Dress code. Wrecks your CV for some employers. Join Accenture if you want to be a meaningless cog in a pointless machine. I deeply regret my time there.

headline: Dynamic, challenging roles that stretch an individual
pros:
- Inclusive & diverse teams: Accenture's biggest quality is how deeply it cares about inclusion & diversity, with strong focus given on LGBT, disability, mental health etc networks.
- Gives a chance to young people starting out their careers
cons:
- Long working hours: this is not necessarily the case with some public sector clients, which mandate no overtime. Nevertheless, in the lower / junior levels of the company it's standard to work double-digit hours every day.
- Formal job training varies: A lot of the philosophy is to throw people into the deep-end, and see whether they pick up the skills in their own time.

headline: Experienced Strategy Manager
pros: Learning and development, international experience, top-rated experience
cons: Not a meritocracy, highly politicised.

headline: Great company - highly recommended
pros: From day one a great start.  The interview process is tough, but once you are recruited, you understand why.  Plenty of development, resources and opportunities to network.  Policies and processes are easy to get hold of.  Flexibility is encouraged.  Work hard and the company works with you.
cons: If you are not self-motivated this will not be the place for you.  I am - so love it here.

headline: Strategy Analyst
pros: Travel, exposure, interesting work, personal development, progression opportunities
cons: Long days, occasional placements on projects in smaller, rural locations.

headline: Great experience
pros: Great company to work for with co-workers that are smart and motivated.  Really interesting projects and clients that deal with top level business issues.
cons: When joining as an experienced hire, it takes a lot of networking to get onto good projects.  Hence, difficult environment if you not an extrovert.

headline: Takes a lot, doesn't give a lot back
pros:
Great colleagues, they make all the difference and make the long hours bearable
Excellent exposure to client senior management
Lots of learning opportunities, particularly in technical skills
cons:
Compensation could be better
Very little flexibility in choosing roles at analyst level
Playing politics is key to progressing

headline: Good place to work
pros: Massive range of clients and industries, reasonable benefits, not too hard to get in, great people to work with and an amazing office in London.
cons: Compared to industry average, some positions aligned to certain divisions are paid less than others from different operating groups/divisions for doing exactly the same job.

headline: Good starting point
pros:
- Great people to work with.
- Variety of roles within virtually all industries.
- High capacity for training.
- Competitive benefits.
- Brilliant for network-growth/career establishment.
cons:
- Inherits all cons of a global organisation.
- Unreasonable pay disparity between business units.
- No guarantee of interesting work; lower levels can be thrust into any role regardless of skills or interest.
- Incredibly political organisation; you will not succeed if you do not socialise and make connections.

headline: Global Sales Director
pros: Interesting work to do, great job opportunities, great people, lot's of different options to develop a career in many different areas.
cons: Very rigid organisation, almost impossible to jump from one to another Business Unit,  slow to react and take the proper decision a the right timing (often too late) and lack of common sense in management decision  - should take more informed decision.

headline: Excellent Place to Work
pros:
good salary
28 Days paid vacations
cons:
Travelling 
project based
late promotions
overall good
lovely Office

headline: Great learning experience in many different areas.
pros:
- Get to travel a lot
- Work directly with people who are experts in there trade
- Great benefits such and Gym and cycling
cons:
- Traveling (If you don't like it)
- Can sometimes be long hours but was not often for me.

headline: Your job satisification is only as good as your last project
pros:
Good training opportunities
Great to work with different technologies
Sometimes you  get to work with great clients
cons:
Long hours
No bonus at consultant level - starts at Manager and above

headline: Dynamic environment and healthy growth path
pros: Accenture has a great consulting career model, which provides ample opportunities for growth, they have some very high profile projects and clients generally engage Accenture to deliver best in-class new technologies to gain competitive advantage in the markets. There is a lot of focus within the organisation on trainings and generate next gen leaders. Great organisation for someone looking to build their career in consulting for an overall rounded growth.
cons: Some projects could be stressful and high pressure, but generally the management is very understanding and supportive in stressful scenarios.

headline: Team lead
pros: Good career opportunities & nice work culture.
cons: Long hours might be an issue if you are not familiar to consulting type of jobs

headline: Good place to work
pros: Good compensation, fun place to work!
cons: Career growth can become stagnated after some time

headline: Technology Consultant
pros: THE PEOPLE I work with, salary, benefits, the range of work and training
cons: Still male heavy, not enough inspiring women.

headline: Great company, still here after 6 years and 2 kids!
pros:
- Work for amazing clients, building creative things
- Mostly lovely, hardworking people
- Supportive benefits package, particularly for parents
- Flexible
cons:
- Can be stressful
- Internal overhead

headline: A varied and interesting career
pros: Huge diversity in roles and opportunities for the consulting business.  I have literally traveled the world and experienced a varied work experience that i dont think is possible in other companies.
cons: Its a big company so at the end of the day you are a number.  Can be brutal when it comes to 'managed attrition'

headline: Overall excellent with room for improvement!
pros:
Intelligent, motivated people
Great rewards
Interesting work, often market leading
Reasonably accommodating of part time workers
Great training
cons:
Lack of mentoring and nurturing talent. You fight your own battles and find your own path.
Feels like there is often a disconnect between the work we say we do and the work we often do. (Although this is improving)

headline: Accenture senior manager
pros: Bright people, high profile clients and projects. Large company with many opportunities in terms of roles, locations. Good company for an ambitious person
cons: Travelling can be tough if you don't live in London as many banking projects are based in London

headline: Service Management Analyst
pros: Cutting edge technology, good relationships with external project collaborators.
cons: Didn't feel at all valued, taken for granted, was a huge surprise to them when I left

location: Swindon, Wiltshire, South West England, England, England
headline: Good place to work
pros: Good work culture, a truly global organisation.
cons: Pay definitely needs proper revision. Way too out of league.

headline: Senior consultant
pros: network and access to colleagues expertise
cons: mainly focused on tech projects

headline: Great company and good colleagues
pros: Great place to work, good environment and people. Amazing benefits
cons: It is quite difficult to join a project related to your background. You would be assigned to a project based on the immediate need

headline: From good to great
pros: There are many positive aspects of working at Accenture, such as the access to a global community of experts in any area, the client base (including a majority of the world's largest organisations), and career opportunities.
cons: Despite the substantial progress in how performance is managed, I think performance, promotion, and reward processes are still very much influenced by perceptions about an employee's talent (rather than their real performance each year). This makes it impossible for anyone to be fairly evaluated unless they actively manage the internal politics.

location: Cambridge, East of England, England, England
headline: Senior Manager
pros:
Employs some very capable and forward thinking people..
Has access to and implements state of the art technology.
cons:
No sense of team
Estimates completely unrealistic and then expect offshore assignees to perform miracles.
No appreciation for the miracles that are performed.
Promotes peoples capabilities  beyond what they actually are.

headline: Amazing
pros: Great benefits, people, opportunities and innovation.  Constantly pushing boundaries and driving thought leadership across a variety of sectors
cons: No real cons worth noting, genuinely positive experience through out my time working for the firm.  Some people may not like the hours but not dissimilar to other consultancy organisations

headline: Great employer
pros: Variety of work, opportunity, treated well
cons: Out of town working, so stay away from home during Mon, Tues, Wed nights

headline: Analyst
pros: Great people, good community, very supportive
cons: Need to be able to fight hard for the project you want, can get stuck in a dull project if not outspoken.

headline: Work with the best and brightest
pros:
- Great colleagues and leadership
- Interesting clients and problem statements
- Good training and certification
- Manage your own career
- Clear career progression and levels
cons:
- Don't stick around if things aren't going well (general career advice tbh)
- Couple of confidence tricksters and people who love using jargon but lack substance
- Can feel like great company results and profits are not met with the same internal progression/ rewards

headline: Varied work
pros: Varied work, fantastic teams, ability to move across industries
cons: Long hours, difficulty to learn on the job when required to take work in area of lesser interest to ensure chargeability

headline: Senior Manager
pros: The people make this a great place to work in combination with great client opportunities. Would recommend to a friend.
cons: There can be a large demand to travel, which although initially appealing wears off after many years travelling.

headline: Good opportunities but you have to play the game
pros: Opportunities and the people you work with - amazing clients, work can be very interesting
cons: System is very rigid - the career development model can be a hard game to play.

headline: Manager, Management Consulting, London
pros:
- Great people
- Reasonable overall package incl. benefits
- Good rate of progression
- Varied work
- Reasonable work life balance
cons: - Base salary could be higher (you'll never get rich working here)

headline: Good to start carier
pros: Good to start carier , taking students and pay not much
cons: Management soso, Salory are small , so taking students, so quality of product is low

headline: Best place Ive ever worked
pros: Good working in teams with innovative ways. Excellent positive culture. Great vironment &  staff are well looked after. career development & opportunities. Mentoring & up skill courses. Happy environment with positive vibe.
cons: There are none. Shame there are only contracts.

headline: Growth is main concern
pros:
Goodwill of company.
People advisor and career counselor provided.
Growing in terms of business.
cons:
Has to stay away from family for client site projects
No growth as in promotion until you doesn't have good terms/networking.

headline: Great experience to develop your CV
pros:
- Breadth and quality of coworkers
- Varied client opportunities
- Respected organisation which looks good on your CV
- Pays well relative to market
cons:
- 'Who you know' important to progression to the higher levels 
- Client delivery commitments and need for internal contributions can conflict
- Easy to become lost within the huge network
- High attrition
- Can be difficult for experienced hires to fully integrate into the firm's politics
- Work/life balance often difficult to get right despite corporate messaging

headline: Accenture is a great place to work
pros: Accenture really cares about its permanent employees and makes sure that you are happy with what you do. If not, they ensure that they move you from there and put you in a place which might make you feel better
cons: More bonuses for the employees might keep them motivated, considering the revenue they generate for you day after day with the work and effort that they put in.

headline: One of the best employers in the UK
pros: A array of technology at your disposal, great benefits, great career paths and the ability to move departments, areas or countries. One of the best companies for career growth
cons: The long hours and the amount of travel on the consulting side can result in a very unbalance work/life situation

headline: Working at Accenture - a hype
pros: The firm has variety of work, is a thought leader in many aspects and has a very wide geographical spread.  The content at Accenture is very deep and most of the time, you are able to find the right resources you need to do the work.  The firm is collaborative, and continuously adapting to the new environment.
cons:
- Extremely competitive, and despite its claims, not necessarily applies meritocracy.  You now need to divide your work between your practice and your project.  
- Very large.  You have to work hard to get noticed.
- it's loosing much of the benefits of consulting.  E.g. you travel allot, but are asked to stay in Travel Lodge
- Pay is not hugely competitive.  Smaller, but good performing firms at time beat the salaries
- Opt and out model very much applied.  Four years at manager max and then you are out.  Sometime, it doesn't matter how well you have done at your project.  If it's not related to your practice and your practice lead doesn't like it, then you are gone.

headline: Senior consultant
pros: Just started so don't know much - attention to newly hires before signing the contract is extraordinary even when compared to other consulting firms
cons: Brand not as prestigious in strategy

headline: Great oppurtunities for career progression
pros: Fast career progression available for those who are motivated
cons: Out of town work, long hours for some roles

headline: Great experience to develop your CV
pros:
- Breadth and quality of coworkers
- Varied client opportunities
- Respected organisation which looks good on your CV
- Pays well relative to market
cons:
- 'Who you know' important to progression to the higher levels
- Client delivery commitments and need for internal contributions can conflict
- Easy to become lost within the huge network
- High attrition
- Can be difficult for experienced hires to fully integrate into the firm's politics
- Work/life balance often difficult to get right despite corporate messaging

headline: Functional Strategy Consultant
pros: People are very interesting and motivated, God training oppotunities
cons: We work very long hours

headline: Senior Manager
pros: great people, great challenges, great clients
cons: it is a huge company

headline: Just Don't
pros: Exposure to big clients and there are still some talented people to learn from
cons: Every year it gets a little worse working here.  Look at the share price,  it's exponential rise is not built on anything more than cutting employee benefits and working employees to the bone.  As a consultancy Accenture is in decline, most of its revenue growth  is now from outsourcing and attempts to rebound with a digital and strategic focus have been a miserable failure.  If you do join you are likely to see brown nosers promoted above talent (certainly at a senior level) and be a victim of a clear culture of positive discrimination.

headline: Chargeability, chargeability, chargeability
pros: Accenture is a great name to get on your CV, and I do not regret the time I have spent here. I have rotated on to a range of different projects, worked with a number of great people (and the people really are great), and developed a lot of new skills. There is a clear path to promotion and if you play the game well and figure out how to tick all the boxes, you can progress your career at a pace.
cons: The biggest problem for me having worked at Accenture is the constant pressure to be on a chargeable role - at all costs. There is such drive at the moment to become a practitioner / specialist in an area of interest, but it's often difficult to develop skills in said area if roles aren't available at exactly the right time. For me, I've found that working at Accenture has turned me into a bit of a generalist, not a specialist, for this reason.

headline: Accenture Review
pros: Great company to work for. Their structure, focus and methodology for end to end Project Management is fantastic and enables employees to development themselves fully. They provide good stakeholder management opportunities and working with the offshore model gives a competitive edge to cost and budget. If you have the right mind-set you can progress well.
cons: As they are delivery focussed, sometimes they lose sight of the individual and impacts on work/life balance.

headline: Manager
pros: great opportunities, clients, interesting work
cons: not always easy to make a transition for experienced hires and build relationships within the firm

headline: Excellent Employer
pros:
Work Life Balance
Opportunities
Ability to drive your own career
Network of People
Industry knowledge and expertise
Presence in the market
cons: People often become a number, especially if you don't fight for your place in the organisation.

headline: Senior Manager
pros:
Good opportunities for progression
Smart people
Good opportunities to travel
Global network
cons:
Salary increments are not what they used to be
Work life balance can be a challenge

headline: Supportive, caring; I'm very happy
pros:
- My MD (and the practice head MD) are both highly supportive of my career and progression with regular feedback made available.

- Our practice continues to defy Brexit with double digit growth

- It's very much a meritocracy environment - the most talented naturally rise to the top (We have MD's who are only 35 years old)

- Very strong support of LGBT community; one of the most senior finance directors in the UK is openly gay which fazes absolutely nobody

- Frequent refresher ethics training is a mandatory requirement; don't take it, kiss any chance of a bonus goodbye...

- One week off-site classroom training is mandatory for everyone each year to expand your skills and capabilities.

- Generous share purchase scheme
cons:
- Hours can be punishing at times but this is a management consultancy.  If you can't cope with the occasional 50-70 hour week from time to time through the year, you're probably in the wrong industry.

- If you're going to fly people long haul for client business, under senior manager level the policy is premium economy.  It's difficult to get any sleep and/or work in this class but it's nevertheless expected of you.

- Finding a seat in the London Fenchurch Street (everything is hot desk) is an absolute nightmare; desks get booked out 2 weeks in advance.

headline: Great Company to work for
pros:
Great Company to work
Opportunity to do interesting work
cons: None at the moment .

headline: Great company
pros: You make your own career path, choosing projects/roles to suit you. Good work/life balance and an opportunity to do things you enjoy or are passionate about e.g. sports/charity/LGBT support. Great support network
cons: Long hours depending on the role/project. Not too different from any other consulting company, really.

headline: Good place to start
pros: Lots of analysts - so good community right from the start. A supportive first job with a lot a room to explore (if you aren't fussed about fast promotion)
cons: Big place, little to no guidance on career, to get promoted befriend an MD

headline: Accenture experience for 1+ year
pros:
Large range of clients 
Some Nice people 
Opportunities to volunteer
Generous holiday allowance and overtime holiday (for client delivery and operations)
Very diverse. People from all over the world
cons:
Hard to get on good projects. They throw you into work no one wants to do. Especially at low levels
Horrible base pay for client delivery and little increase even with promotion
Annoying managers that tend to micromanage
Overwhelmingly large company. Can feel lost
Unclear progression path

headline: DECENT
pros: Something for everyone, opportunities to grow in areas you are interested in. Travel the world.
cons: Structure can be quite rigid at times

headline: The good, the bad
pros:
Progression can be quick
Continuous development mandatory
Work is interesting and high profile
cons:
Projects are often under resourced resulting in high stress and long hours
Quality of profiles is mixed - some very strong leaders supporting weaker profiles 
Hiring strategy needs to be reassessed, especially for analyst pool - those from good uni STEM background generally good, the others are pot luck

headline: MD Review
pros: quality of people and industry reputation
cons: long hours and very structured decision-making processes

headline: Great starter company
pros: Excellent exposure and opportunities to gain experience early in your career, Good Salary, Wide range of clients, a lot of good people
cons: Very large company can often be hard to make an impact, effort required on top of day-to-day role to make yourself visible to Accenture leadership

headline: Great place to work
pros:
Collaborative ethos and structured management process
Interesting work 
Really positive culture
cons: Sometimes it can be challenging to move projects forward because there are lots of people involved but I think that's the case in most companies.

headline: Good Time at Acceture
pros:
Great learning opportunities
Great network of smart people
cons: You need to be flexible with your work/life balance, depending on your personal commitments this may not be a problem. The flip side this provide the steep learning curve

headline: Politics over competence, poor work life balance
pros: Good benefits including a generous pension contribution. Heard the maternity / paternity leave is not too bad. Gym membership £30 per month, Bupa healthcare, Accenture shares and good pension (they were paying 14% per year)
cons: Lots of politics, not meritocratic at all. It's all about who you know and sell your 'personal brand'. You really need to spend a lot of time networking to get anywhere. It's not about how good your work is but being in touch with the right people. Don't get even near Accenture if you are introverted and just wanted to do a good job. It's all about show how wonderful you are at all times. I met a manager who gave me a spiel about M&A and all his industry experience but when we started talking about it he actually knew next to nothing (but very confidently, of course!)

headline: Good company, just not as great as it used to be.
pros: Multiple opportunities given its massive size, reach and range of services. On average very good and talented people as well.
cons: It became too Sales driven recently, with profitability coming ahead of outstanding delivery as it used to be. The recent changes on the organisation and performance management had the unintended consequence of adding a competition element between peers working on smaller practices. Now with a renewed focus on 'up or out', senior management is sharing less and focusing on their own career development.

headline: good place to work but to slow progress
pros:
-good place to work
-most colleagues are friendly. 
-They look after their employees by expensing food travel and accommodation for projects outside of your home area i.e outside of M25 (only if agreed with client)
-always got some sort of drinks event going on every other month
-you get several bonuses depending on your seniority and the death benefit (your next of kin gets approximately half a million if you die)
cons:
-some colleagues are too corporate and report you to HR for the smallest of things
-have to be geographically flexible (spent long periods of time in hotels away from loved ones)
-career progression is slow, most people get a 1% salary raise in promotion or in some cases no salary increase, i was offered more than this but not as high as most companies would usually give. Took me over 2 years to get the raise
-if project is sold at fixed price, you can be expected to work long hours for free as 'no budget' for over time even though it may seem as critical to stay and do the extra work. This is slowly changing but if the project manager is stubborn you dont have much choice

headline: Life at Accenture
pros: Very talented people, great client exposure and variety of work
cons: Too many processes and policies. It is very difficult to get promoted. Salary below market value

headline: Accenture Management Consulting
pros: Challenge, variety, experience, Brand, looks good on CV, will open lots of doors in the future.
cons: Extremely poor people management and training and development.

headline: New Branding - Same Ideas as 30 years ago
pros:
- Its reputation among Non-Consultants is still high (though some more Savvy clients have called it Tier 3 / 4 consulting to me)

- Few other Consultancies work with the same Major Clients

- Outside the UK's over-regulated markets, Accenture really does work on new technologies and frontiers....and you can read about it internally.

- Generally speaking, you can get lots of training / certifications

- Good place to go from Analyst => Consultant => Manager

- Its a IT and Project Management company trying to pose as a Business Consultancy. But you really do work with the Best Project managers I have ever come across.

- The Managing Directors (again for the most part) do seem to genuinely care for the people and do sort things out when an issue is bought to them. The Process for becoming an MD is far more stringent than the lower level promotions and definitely comes off more objective.
cons:
- It generally takes an experienced hire a year to learn the Accenture game, by which time they are usually on the back foot, have a bad rating and better off leaving 6 months later. After all - externally, you're Accenture stained by then anyway. For most people that adds value to their CV.

- Lack of transparency around staffing. The best roles get filled by network - and if you're new, you have no network. And if you're unlucky, you join and get sent to the middle of no where by yourself for a year and then really are screwed.

- Accenture career-lifers are ignorant to the outside world and new people entering into their cliques, which makes it difficult for the company to change or develop

- Real lack of ideas. The company is full of Sales people and blow-hards, but not much content

- Too much focus on doing internal Accenture work instead of actual client work. 

- People with the title Manager are a Rank and not actual Managers. It confers they are good at doing internal Accenture work more than they actually know how to Manage something.... especially people.

- Low pay rises to no pay rises despite the company saying it is doing well year on year (Accenture is not seen as advisory vs the Big 4 so gets squeezed on day rates and on the other side is now competing with the big 6 of India for the IT work who bring low day rates too). Limited pay increases within Rank.

- Focus on being a salesman first vs building actual expertise which Clients would pay more for

- Lots of snakes in suits - too much of an "I" culture and no real collaboration. The performance process focuses too much on individuals and so there is a culture of not wanting to share ideas or work together as you can't claim credit.

- The objectives / priorities system doesn't matter - all that matters is what is said about you in the laddering / talent discussions i.e. have some Snr Mgrs and MDs who like you and you'll go up easy enough, with or without talent

- Boring work - If you have come from outside, the work is really vanilla. It might be big in scale, but really, its basic work. 

- lots of internal processes which no one cares about - great fill out your internal profile, CV, blog etc - but no one actually cares. 

- Moving around Accounts is career limiting, unlike other places where you're bringing new ideas and expertise to clients

- Cost cutting on training in the past few years (no Chicago, less annual budget for real skills, no real quality training on industry topics)

headline: good company to start with
pros: very huge, vast network, good consulting, brand value,flexible ,highly process oriented
cons: work always, highly client oriented, no voice for juniors, no work-lif balance

headline: ACN
pros:
variety of roles
work from home (project dependant)
cons:
work load can be intense at times
can be hard to find your footing.

headline: Analyst
pros: Very good company to work for, very professional and they know how to look after their staff.  Lots of emphasis on well-being.  Good place to work if you are hard working as your work will be recognised and lots of opportunities to progress.  I only worked here on a short term contract but I was very impressed and wouldnt hesitate to work for them again.
cons: depending on what job you do the contractsare only temporary

headline: Finance - Great place to work
pros: Great organisation! I worked with inspiring people and was supported through development.
cons: In some area's career progression can be limited. This is ultimately what made me leave.

headline: Accenture experience
pros: The people, breadth of clients and the range of work we do makes Accenture an exciting company to work for
cons: No huge cons, but it can be tricky for experienced hires to understand the way Accenture works immediately - be prepared to spend time getting to grips with it!

headline: Flexible Employer
pros: In Strategy - great variety of projects, flexible working (for the most part), really nice team and many opportunities to build up a network of supporters and contacts
cons: More opportunities for promotion always welcome, especially from Manager to Senior Manager level

headline: Talent Development Associate Manager
pros: A lot of flexibility to work at home, lots of opportunities to move roles
cons: Constant changing programmes, under staffed

headline: Lots of opportunities
pros: Good people, interesting work, plenty of opportunities if you look for them
cons: Bureaucratic, very political culture, work life balance can get out of hand if you let it

headline: 12 months Industrial Experience Programme
pros:
- Very useful first week of training 
- Can choose an area of the business for first project
- Great contact with the client for my level
- I was able to meet and talk to several MD
- learned a lot about the world of consulting from intelligent and friendly colleagues
cons:
- Experience is extremely project specific, some of my fellow interns did not enjoy their time as much
- If you aren't able to build a network you are unlikely to end up working for interesting projects

headline: Experience was project dependent
pros: Good career opportunities with client-facing roles at an early stage. Good development opportunities with an emphasis on learning about the industry you're working in. A number of diversity initiatives to get involved with.
cons:
Culture varied between practices.

As a graduate, I found I had little control over which project I got allocated to at the start. It was then hard to move to another part of the business, even if it aligned more naturally with my skills & interests. 

There was a tendency towards a culture of always emphasising how busy you are and I know a number of people who burnt out.

headline: Associate
pros: Work type, technology access,
cons: incentives, technology application, working hours

headline: Get your foot into the consulting world then move out
pros: Benefits and training. Can work in a range of roles within software delivery lifecycle. Accenture's clients are numerous and extensive
cons: Promotion takes too long - it's why attrition is so high. Having to interview for projects is annoying. Your experience is really shaped by the projects you're on, if you hate your project you will hate Accenture

headline: Accenture Operations
pros: Forward thinking, Strong processes,
cons: Offshore model, Too many MDs

headline: Good career builder, learning opportunity and pay
pros: Excellent career prospects.  Good variety of projects as long as you are proactive in building your internal network.  Robust training opportunities albeit mostly internal accreditation. Competitive salaries for the industry.
cons:
-Natural politics as any work environment.  Not always a pure meritocracy. Who you know is equally important to your actual performance 
-Too much emphasis placed on attending social functions and extracurriculars. Great if you're a young graduate but not so much if you're slightly older or an experienced hire 
-Experience varies wildly based on project.  Almost all of mine have been good but there are some painful ones out there (atrocious hours, stress etc)

headline: Confusing but with great rewards
pros:
Very well paid at analyst level with good bonus rates

Company credit card, laptop, can apply for mobile phone

9 months parental leave full pay, healthcare schemes, gym subsidies, company hotel and shopping discounts

You get very well looked after if you travel

Lots of bright people working at the company

HR is very supportive in case of conflict with client / management etc

If you don't like your project you can leave (with some effort...)
cons:
Very confusing system, lots of acronyms, you can't really understand the company or how it works 

Performance achievement is a complicated process of feedback from seniors. You set your own priorities so it is completely unstructured and it just feels like it's very personal and depends on whether your manager likes you. 

Biggest annoyance is having to hunt down your own roles and network to get onto good projects. It feels like a lottery with your chances of getting a promotion/having a good work/life balance or enjoying your job are literally down to either incompetent schedulers that don't care about matching you with anything you are actually suitable for but filling a gap or having to be lucky and meeting the right people.

I have met a disproportionate number of great analysts and consultants and really weak and incompetent managers and senior managers. Some SMs at Accenture behave worse than children. I guess all the best people leave after a few years!

headline: Extremely Difficult for Experienced Hires
pros: I'm not sure I can think of any pros right now - maybe if your motivation is money and status then Accenture wold be for you.
cons:
- expected to be knowledgeable about consulting even if you're not from a consulting background
- there is the official way to do things in Accenture - and then there is the actual way, and as an experienced hire it's not possible to know the actual way, so getting on projects - even making friends with colleagues is difficult
- sold to customers as an expert in something you are not - covered in a blanket statement by Accenture as sometimes in the beginning you won't 'get the project you want'

headline: Great place to work
pros: Talented people. Super pro-active attitude. Lots of opportunities for development and try different roles.
cons: Can be long hours and at out of town locations. Sometimes about who you know rather than a true meritocracy

headline: Good company, if you can avoid the politics
pros: Good company, strong culture, smart people, good training and mentoring
cons: Everything is done by consensus and powerpoint. Lots of aligning, coordinating and "buy-in". Lots of talk for a limited amount of real action

headline: Great place to work and build your career
pros:
- Great environment especially in Digital
- Accenture employees collaborate and encourage with you in a way that makes you feel like you're part of a family
- Great progression for those who know what they want
- Accenture leadership are heavily invested and genuinely interested in supporting inclusion and diversity
- Very high calibre of people, skills and experience
cons:
- Difficult to carve your own path especially for experienced hires
- Constantly changing, making it difficult to navigate
- Experience hires may find it difficult to practice or concentrate on their trade

headline: Work Hard Play Hard
pros: Great people, interesting roles, lots of opportunities, travel
cons: long hours, travel, work life balance

headline: Experiences will vary
pros: wide variety of opportunities, excellent structure, decent benefits package
cons: can be extremely difficult to align yourself to the area in which you want to progress your experience. General experience can be highly dependent on the calibre of manager - as can career progression.

headline: Good opportunities if you're willing to fight for them
pros:
1) Flexibility. The firm is ultimately governed 'bottom-up' (by employee base) rather than 'top-down' (by leadership). Relationship building always trumps job description and formal policy. I've staffed myself on good projects, and whilst HR and management might not always endorse these moves (partly to prevent all-out chaos), their hard policies have limited coverage. This is a good mix of creating paths of least resistance that benefit the overall firm, whilst also keeping opportunities open for you if you're good and self-motivated. This is arguably a positive side-effect of some systemic problems within the firm.
2) Above market rate salary.
3) Excellent managers: people at the manager and senior manager level have been unilaterally great. Junior enough to care, but senior enough to materially help out. 
4) Pockets of progressive policy, such as promotion discussions and performance evaluations (although implementation has something to be desired).
5) Diverse opportunities. Accenture is a huge professional services firm. They do everything from old IBM mainframe maintenance, to M&A due diligences, to marketing. What you're after is probably here.
6) Easy to move on. Even if things don't work out (e.g. an immovable policy blocks your progression within the firm) the experiences and skills learnt are easy to sell (after all, ACN does a bit of everything)!
cons:
The key driver of all the below problems is that consulting at Accenture (and perhaps the wider UK market) is highly commodified.

1) Lack of investment: particularly on benefits, training and office capacity (only 2 weeks of fairly austere onboarding, no phone provided, not enough desks in Fenchurch Street, tight controls on expenses, limited event budgets, few opportunities to work abroad).
2) Poor quality analysts: generally boring and lacking rigour (typical 2:i graduates from mid-table universities with a sports team and summer internship on their CV).
3) Poor quality projects: Accenture's bread-and-butter for new joiners are PMO and solutions roles on chunky systems integration projects that can last 1+ years. It's common in the firm to have spent your entire career working for a single client. This to me is not a consulting business, but a glorified job agency. You have to fight against the current to avoid these roles and go for the more 'interesting' work, which is definitely out there.
4) Demoralising and byzantine HR policy and controls. Most of this can be avoided (see pro above), but if you don't fight or get unlucky, company policy can railroad you. I personally joined on a management consulting offer, only for it to be converted in a tech consulting offer (upon day 2 on the job) - and HR lied to me on record about the change. This would be a bigger issue but it hasn't affected my career progression so far. Also: anxiety-inducing pressure from utilisation and changeability targets, poor scheduler relationships, and demands to engage in a narrow set of sanctioned extra-curriculars.
5) Bad reputation within consulting.

headline: ACN
pros: Plenty of room to grow and expand knowledge and skills.
cons: If you don't manage your time well and aren't up front about your capacity you can find yourself drowning in it.

headline: Review
pros: Travel, work ethic, cross industry experienxe
cons: Salary, Long hours, aggresive staffing

headline: Good opportunities
pros: Good opportunities of you are lucky enough to have a suitable role available when rolling off from one role to the next. Timing is a big factor. Need to be willing and able to play the  game and go above and beyond your role to progress.
cons: Huge variability in quality of roles. Once you secure a role, if you find it's not challenging/ not what you understood it would be, you can be stuck in that role for a year or longer. You can then be pigeon holed into doing that type of work thereafter.

headline: Significant changes over the past 3 years
pros:
A lot of the reviews are quite dated and refer to an organisation model and culture that is far removed from what exists today.  Over the past 2 years a number of significant changes have happened within Accenture. 

Most notably, 
- Merging of Solutions workforce into Consulting
- Move away from the 'forced rankings' into a Performance Achievement model
- Market relevant roles and pay structures - plus bonuses and rewards that recognise exceptional contributions
- Shift into bringing cutting-edge technology and innovation to our clients/projects - and providing incentives, trainings to the entire workforce to facilitate this thinking across all levels
cons: The mindset change of the performance appraisal has not yet fully permeated throughout the organisation. It will be some time before this change has fully taken affect, but this should not be seen as a major drawback.

headline: Working from more than 6years
pros:
Good onshore opportunities 
Challenging work
Employee care
Flexible working timings
Reachable leadership 
Nice working environment 
Lot are f opportunity of project selection 
Various locations and growing faster
cons:
Recognitions
Competition within employees 
No much learning programs
No payout for certifications
Good for laterals but need to handle pressure 
Need to prove on future role before getting promoted

headline: Very good in some areas, but much could be better
pros:
Accenture is deservedly widely lauded as one of the best places to work in various high profile surveys. It's employment conditions and perks are very good compared to others, certainly one of the best in my experience. 

Community spirit is strong (circles, networking events, associations etc). Whilst everybody benefits from this, there is a particularly strong (and deservedly well respected) focus on women and the LGBT community (which is great to be part of and in no way detracts or acts to the detriment of people outside of these groups).

Working from home is positively encouraged which is well received and helps family and work/life balance.
cons:
The bureaucracy is simply mind-numbing. Getting even the simplest thing done in terms of admin, recruitment, invoice payment etc is often a monumental task and takes hours of precious time. It also seems to involve at least 10 people being copied into every email, but nobody seems able to troubleshoot problems (when you do find somebody who can, it is well worth adding them to your contacts list or speed dial so you can circumvent the usual hurdles every time). Most frustratingly of all, when you have spent hours accomplishing something that should take a few moments and the click of a mouse, you will be asked for the same task or information two weeks later by people who should already have it.

Quality of office space is variable. Fenchurch Street has some quite poor aspects to it (crowded and outdated in some but not all areas), but other locations such as the new Chancery Exchange building are much, much better.

headline: Corporate behemoth which fails to deliver for its employees
pros:
As many other reviewers point out, many people view Accenture as an impressive addition to your CV – however that view is mostly held by people who have no experience of Accenture, as either a client or an employee. 

The health insurance and maternity/paternity benefits are strong. Those in the most senior managerial positions are paid handsomely in terms of remuneration, shares and other benefits (although the same cannot be said for the other 95% of employees).

Could offer you a career for life if you’re prepared to be at the mercy of performance process which doesn’t award ability or achievement – see Cons below.
cons:
The epitome of a corporate behemoth which is too big to offer employees the true nurturing and career progression everyone deserves. Nothing about Accenture feels personal – you really are just another number in a huge multinational machine. As someone who has a great deal of professional experience, I’ve never worked anywhere which made me feel so unimportant as Accenture. It really lacks a soul. If you are joining, or already have, and soon after feel that the company is not the right place for you – leave! Your client(s) or role(s) are important in shaping your experience within Accenture, but ultimately if the company’s culture, ethos and its people feel foreign to you, then escape quickly and without regret. 

Accenture sells a dream and delivers something far short of that. The training offered is sub-par to competing firms by quite some distance, something which is particularly obvious to clients when they meet recent joiners to the company. Accenture also fail to utilise employees’ previous experience – for example why would you force someone with years of Resources industry expertise into a Financial Services role – because you need a number to fill a role and really don’t care who that individual is. Failure to offer people the true ability to build on their experiences and shape their career is one reason why so many people decide to leave. It’s also worth saying that your working hours are entirely dependent on client, location and role, so this really is pot luck – some people really do end up with an intolerable work-life balance.
 
If you’re prepared to perform significantly above the level at which you’re paid to, and wait for the overly restrictive performance achievement process to promote you up the career ladder then Accenture is a company that could offer you a career for life. However don’t be fooled, Accenture is not a meritocracy - very talented individuals will not necessarily progress much more rapidly than those who consistently just do enough year-on-year. Long-time employees I met who (at least said they) enjoyed working for Accenture, where those with an almost robotic approach to their work and their career. I truly believe that those who benefit the most from being at Accenture long-term, are the shareholders.

headline: Great Opportunities

cons: Extremely competitive. Complex matrix organisation structure. Sometimes seen as penny wise and pound foolish. Long hours and too many productivity stealing meetings.

3. Great Team Work
cons: 1. Short Term Assignments

headline: Great company
pros: The people that work here, great benefits
cons: Moving projects and travelling around the country

headline: Great experience

cons: Performance Management process, there is too much of a focus on time at level over performance & pay is low at analyst and consultant level

headline: Variable, but good overall
