headline: Management don't care. Unfair reviews
pros: Diverse projects, some (majority not) clever people, opportunities for training
cons: Very poor performance appraisal process, i.e. project delivery, personal chargeability and client/project feedback does not matter in the review process. What does matter is how much brown nosing you can do to progress up the corporate ladder, if you are good at this, then please join! Senior Managers and Leadership are in it for themselves...more bonus for them, forget about everything else. Sales people? Well, they have 'specialist' sales people who have no idea how to win projects and minimal consultation is done with the people who will actually be delivering the project (if they win it). Lots of incompetent people hide away and somehow get recognized for their work!

headline: Great Opportunities, Poor Communication (and sometimes treatment of employees)
pros:
- Fantastic opportunities to work on projects with world-leading companies.
- Good benefits for a company of its size, including: gym subsidy, private healthcare, decent pension plan, sizeable individual training budget.
- Bi-annual opportunities for promotion (although within the business its commonly seen as only one – due to mid-year budget restrictions).
cons:
- Information is delivered very impersonally, and can appear very blunt at times – making you feel more like a number than a human employee.
- Accenture have an incredible talent for making standard emails sound stressful, even though they like to preach about employee mental health.
- Opted out of the government furlough scheme and decided to cut people from the company months later into the pandemic – not very employee-friendly IMO.

headline: A mixed bag
pros: Mostly talented and helpful colleagues, interesting projects, opportunities for training.
cons:
Work life balance can be dramatically different depending on the project. Project deadlines don't move even when dependencies have been missed or the project has not been staffed fully, and the delivery team always ends up making ends meet through putting in lots of extra hours.
Being successful is hugely a case of 'upwards management' and is mainly down to the how influential your career counsellor is and how far they will back you. The result is generations of project managers who understand nothing about the projects they are managing because they were promoted too early and move freely between subject areas.
Projects are often sold to you as being very innovative and exciting but end up being the same old same old because nobody budgeted for enough time to do anything beyond a tactical house of cards solution.

At my 10lvl I was sold on project as team lead and did a great job, client was very happy, but no one have promoted me, even I was soooo promised... Promises its a second name of this company...
Second thing I hate is amount of administrative work you must do. But this is common in big corporations.

headline: One word - TOXIC !!!
pros: Nothing, absolutely horrible place to work.
cons:
-Insane hours for little money
-Absolutely toxic work culture based on bullying, everyone is afraid to speak up and as a result everyone is exploited by managers and MDs
-HR is useless, I voiced concerns to HR about the toxic culture and certain managers, and they held it against me
-Managers are insanely biased on their feedback, they are stereotypical consultants which value soft skills over objective performance
-No flexibility to steer your career, you have to do exclusively what you are told by others
-People are not only immoral, but they also break professional and ethical standards. They lie to clients and tell them constantly that the people on projects are more senior than they actually are so that they can charge higher fees.

headline: Not for me
pros: Perks, Share scheme, generous nights out on the right contract.
cons:
To get on it is implicitly expected that you work long hours, far more than legally allowed. 

The different facets of work are separated in a way that allows different senior leaders to absolve themselves of responsibility for your well being. The result is one of isolation, a feeling that you aren't supported, valued or even wanted. 

This is not a job for someone who just wants to work hard and get paid, its dog eat dog and hard working yet unambitious staff are not welcome. Nor should you want to, it's an unrewarding and ultimately soul destroying place to be

headline: Mixed
pros:
Amazing company culture overall. 
People are fantastic and really make the place what it is.

cons:
Disconnect between management (8 and above) and the team on the ground. Often have no experience in the subject matter and have been promoted purely based on working for Accenture for decades or who they know. Resulted in a loss of engagement within Newcastle ops big project.

Promotion process is unfair/political. expected to work into roles but will not be paid for it and are unlikely to ever be promoted. 'Secondments' are given to favourites on the project with no fair application process.

headline: Considered the leader across the Fortune 500 Technology spectrum
pros: Interesting work keeping well ahead of the Tech curve (and competitors). Frequent exposure to senior Accenture and client leadership to keep you focused on business value. Diversity, innovation and change are part of Accenture's DNA. Your skill set can be maintained building on stretch work experience and learning opportunities to develop your Technology Quotient and business acumen. At Accenture you are your own leader. You "own your career" and "own your work / life balance". You will thrive if you navigate the corporate complexity, build a diverse network, maintain a positive 'can do' attitude, proactively support extra-curricular capability development, seek your own mentors and obtain frequent feedback on your performance. Keep delivering value and this will drive further opportunities for growth.
cons: High performance delivered under constant pressure to balance work / life can sap your energy and may not align with your life journey. Choose your right time to be at Accenture.

headline: Awful culture
pros: #NAME?
cons:
- performance process is flawed and biased. Based solely on your network and who you know. Very little of your actual performance or feedback from direct line managers taken into account. Building your  ‘personal brand’ is the primary concern of the company from day one, which encourages people to cosy up to management who will help them through promotion, rather than focussing on building up useful skills. 
- incredibly competitive and toxic culture, particularly in ACG. To be expected when you are ranked against one another during performance review 
- analysts have no say in shaping their career - schedulers and management only care about charge-ability.  If you turn down unsuitable roles you will be penalised. 
- analysts are taken advantage of by senior staff eg forced to work on clients without a chargeable code, which is then used against them at performance review 
- questionable management of the recent redundancy process - Accenture now having to rehire multiple roles, no senior management pay cuts etc 
- it looks bad to be throwing countless freebies at your employees whilst laying off 6% of the UK workforce 
- on paper, great policies regarding valuing the individual - yet to see this translate into the culture

headline: Makes margin from under paying employees
pros: I can't think of any
cons:
You are sold for much more than they pay you, that's how Accenture makes its margin. Watch out for when they sell you as a senior consultant and pay you an analyst rate.
No matter how many years you spend (think 7 years), other 'favourits', will get their training paid for, and you won't.
Favourism is a real problem. If you aren't good at selling yourself and talking about your work, and much better at delivering, you'll be overshadowed by management, who will get their bonus for your work, and you'll get nothing, because someone else is claiming your work! And sometimes, you'll have a colleague you know does virtually nothing throughout the day, but spends most of his time having a laugh with management, he gets promoted and you don't :)
This is even worse when you know that you can't represent yourself in promotion meetings, and your senior management (who will usually have no clue what you're doing, thanks to your manager claiming your work), and you won't even get a salary increase beyond 200-300 a year!!
They didn't care to promote women, in 2018 they promoted 5 ppl, all were men! Questioning them, they failed to explain why 2 were promoted over another lady in the team. She was yet another person who wasn't good at selling her work, but she worked hard and everyone knew she was great.

I should write in the Pros that this place, taught me what I'm actually worth the hard way and to not allow them or anyone else to benefit from my work if they won't pay me. Look elsewhere if you're looking to feel valued and not just a number that increases their bonuses. Great experience is everywhere believe me, now that I left, I've learnt much more in the last year than I did in the last two years.

headline: Good pay and benefits, lack of transparency
pros: The pay and welcome bonus is great for a starting salary and the benefits are good (30 days holiday)
cons: When you join they tell you that you can create your own career path at Accenture and chose projects that align to your career goals. However, after you join they make it very difficult to do so and try to force you into where the business needs are at the time. If you're open to working in any industry then Accenture is great, but if you are joining and have an industry in mind that you really want to get experience in, then I would advise you to work for a different consultancy or just get a job in that industry!

headline: Meat factory with fantastic career opportunities
pros: Great way to build a CV and experience working on different challenges with biggest clients across the globe
cons:
You might get stuck in a back office local role difficult to get out of to client facing assignments - you need to be ruthless sometimes to go after the contracts you want.

100% of your alive time is on Accenture business - be it client work or company socials and events. Fantastic if you don't have family/outside interest or are senior enough in the company to set your own schedule, but very difficult to progress if you need time for any non work related aspects of your life (as to progress you're up against a ton of people who are happy to work/be engaged with Accenture activities 24/7.

I must stress this doesn't fully qualify as a con - it's a successful business model that creates limitless career opportunities if you have the time and will to dive in 100%.

headline: Questionable team dynamics
pros: #NAME?
cons:
- Stress vs Benefits is unreasonable. Consulting in stressful. For some reason it can be more stressful in Accenture due to some particular managers / senior managers. I wasn't lucky and all my projects had at least one regularly screaming team member.

- Nearly not enough projects for all hires. I understand the churn rate in consulting, but firing people because they cannot find a project, while being a junior team member is questionable.

- Promotions are not transparent. The loudest screaming drama person would typically get an early promotion. If you are not ready to be loud and drama - maybe boutique firms will be a better option.

I later found out they'd had a poor career progression from analyst to consultant and that it was common for such people to pass down the torch of bad career progression.

headline: DON'T BE DECEIVED BY THE BS THEY FEED YOU
pros:
Great brand in the market. They also pay significantly better than their competitors.

It's great if you like a structured ladder to climb and are willing to play the game. However, If you are entrepreneurial you will HATE Accenture.
cons:
Don't be loyal to this company they will NEVER be loyal to you.

The political games you have to play is staggering, and there are layers and layers of it. They say things publicly but in private they mean something else. Always do what is best for you. The only person that has your back is you.

They claim to be innovative but they aren't. you aren't allowed to fail. 

Don't sacrifice your family, friends, relationships and things you care about for this company, they promise you heaven and NEVER deliver any of their promises. 

Do not work longer than your contract states, there is no point, there is no reward no pot of gold and the end of the rainbow.

headline: ATC Newcastle - Avoid
pros: Nice enough office, space to walk at lunchtime and accessible from city by car. Parking all ok.
cons:
ATC Newcastle labels itself as a "tech" centre but its actually a sales centre.

I would echo the other reviews of life at Newcastle ATC here the atmosphere at that office was very very bad. 

I felt very uncomfortable working alongside certain people. 

Cliquey management, appalling ethics, openly racist and nasty. 

Very personal and a specific group go on the attack against anyone who doesnt have the same 'sales' mindset as them.

Nice people need not apply to Newcastle ATC and especially avoid the Ops area.

headline: The people are their best asset
pros: Great colleagues - Accenture focuses on hiring personable bright candidates and it shows. Your colleagues are high quality and dependable. The pay, benefits, and policies (such as the parental leave - 7 months full pay, which can be shared between you and your partner are great)
cons: Cons are broadly to do with consulting rather than Accenture. Be prepared for long hours, you may often have to work weekends depending on your role. It is tough coming in as an experienced hire - they tend to come in a grade below there level of experience to help them get used to the culture, but then get promoted quickly. Whilst it sometimes ‘sold’ as an experience to try different things, in reality you get rewarded better if you don’t move around. This can be an expectation gap for new hires. Particularly if you want to make the most of the innovation areas of the business.

headline: Modern workplace and inclusive environment
pros: As a Consultancy who's entire model is based around best-practice, Accenture are always ahead of the curve in terms of the latest Employee incentive schemes or softwares. The company is also noticeably more diverse and inclusive than other consultancies, and really makes this one of their USP's.
cons: Requires strong self-starters and pro-activity. Nothing will be handed to you and it requires a competitive spirit. Can make you feel a bit lonely at times, as if you have no support or team. Also strong expectations on chargeability which creates a little bit of toxicity.

headline: Great branding, some great people, dreadful culture
pros: Opportunity to be involved in great, high profile projects, hands-on experience, recognised global brand that is well perceived, particularly with older generations who remember Anderson consulting, that will help you build a credible network and get great exit opportunities. Lots of access to training. Some of the people are excellent. Corporate perks like gift cards, etc.
cons: Likely underpaid for what you do, lots of weak management who are arrogant and don't realise they actually need support on management and to develop leadership skills, rapid promotion of people with low competence, culture that dislikes thought in favour of highly transactional work that can on occasion be completed to a low standard but passed off as gloss. Can be incredibly hierarchical - but not necessarily pinned to level, depends who likes you. People no matter how good their background and output is are essentially told to 'shut up and make it look pretty', that they 'don't know anything' by very mediocre people rehashing non-sensical ideas in front of clients, or just repeating things they've heard and using consulting jargon to mask things. It's very much a taker culture, full of backstabbing, especially around promotion time. They don't care about people, you are just your employee number. They pay lipservice to all the right things but good luck finding action to actually back it up around things like diversity, work-life balance and mental health. It's mainly marketing, show pony-ism and people stealing other people's ideas while telling them their worth nothing. Disgraceful culture - filled with people who don't even bother to report harassment because they don't feel they'd get much help, particularly if the perpertrators are perceived to be company favourites. Senior people who won't report incidents of people using offensive language around protected characteristics, or intimidating employees who've called these things out (admittedly this seems like a bigger problem in the larger parts of the business), but will go on linkedin and post about their commitment to diversity and promote the completion of conduct surveys, citing that bad behaviour should be called out. People discussed like they are chattle being sold to clients.

headline: Bully culture and forcing people against Gov Guidance in Covid
pros: Big Company load of projects
cons:
Dirty politics i left Accenture in 7 months, forced to come to office and travel during Covid where work can be done from home. On same project other people working from home mostly ethnic minority sitting in the office on Financial sector project. Alot of covid cases in team been forced to travel London to North East. Bully culture and racism on high. People scared to speak due to probation and new to company. 
Some people approach mental health there was a case when one person had serious mental health issue and luckly got support from close friend. Group of people lack Accenture core value of mutual respect and abusing team member. Gov should take action for forcing team to come to office when work can be done from home by speak to Team confidentially. hope other team member raise voice and approach independent bodies to take action. Client Ethical moral value is very high they are not aware how team is getting treated and the behaviour of Accenture management in not acceptable.

headline: Challenging but rewarding
pros: Challenging but rewarding place to work. Fast paced and can often be working under pressure but great opportunities to learn and build a wide range skills. Great place to start your career as a graduate. The best thing is the people - in general people are very supportive and prioritise people development.
cons: Sometimes you can get stuck in a bad project or role and struggle to get out (supply and demand!). You can mitigate this by putting in the time to build a strong network who will help you navigate through the business.

headline: Terrible employer

headline: Not recommended!!!
pros: You get to work for different clients and take up varied roles (this can be a con if you absolutely hate the role and get a toxic client - that too if it is a long term project!!)
cons:
- Low pay compensation 
- You cannot possibly drive your own career - forced to take up any role to maintain chargeability, even if you are up for promotion you will be judged by strangers via multiple discussion rounds, opaque talent discussion process - career counsellor puts you up for promotion but at the end you don't end up getting promoted and there is no formal reason/feedback for the same!
- Career heavily dependent on Networking - you can be a rockstar in your client account but if you are not friends with seniors, leads or anyone who sits in the talent discussion rounds - well tough luck! Finding good roles is also based on knowing the 'correct' people. This is stressful and can easily impact the actual work you need to do to excel. Also sometimes this can be very unfair as if a person is not good at their work and do not possess the relevant skills but excellent networking skills as opposed to someone who is actually very good at their work - the latter will always have a disadvantage and can take ages to climb up the ladder.
- No clarity on different streams - people with good technical background and skills start on level 12 and people who have background in music, geography, biology, chemistry, math etc. start at level 11 because Accenture does not appreciate graduates who have computer science degrees and relevant experience!

headline: Good career spring board
pros: Very good in getting varried experience as consulting work is project based and changes a lot. Excellent place to start a career as you can find what you like and what you do not like. There is a strong sense of identity which can be nice if that is what you are looking for.
cons: Despite what Accenture says, obtaining interesting projects is often based on luck. As there is a 0 bench policy, people are encouraged to take whichever project is available. This is not ideal if you want to follow a particular direction. There is also a general expectation to do a lot of extra curriculum activities (read as free work to support more senior people in their sales efforts) to stand "out". Doing one job's well is often not sufficient for promotion. Finally, there is this sense of superiority which can sometimes lead into arrogance.

headline: Project Manager in Prodcuts team

exposure to challenging working environments

innovative and dynamic with market demands
great networking culture
great for anyone wanting to join as Grad
cons:

Need to be seen at all events to be visible for promotions and career growth
End year review can often be based on who you know rather than individual merit
Staff turn over is extremely high

headline: False promises, low pay, everyone wants to leave
pros: If you want to work with average people and get low pay it’s a great place to slack. Minimum hours if you want.
cons:
- Work is not valued, being friends with md is more important. Only bum kissing will get you far, good people either left or looking to leave 

- the system encourages mediocre people staying so no inspiring/intelligent colleagues in most part of the business - people either just clock in and out; or are burnt out from bum kissing. No one likes/cares about what they do

- people in strategy looks down on everyone; digital looks down on MC, MC looks down on TC, TC looks down on operation etc etc - very toxic environment

- promises for promotion/career progression but will not happen and you wouldn’t know why despite being told you’re a “top performer” and “keep doing what you are doing”. They will say there was no budget, then few months later acquired 500 people from other small competitors in smaller markets (sad) to be your boss. They don’t want to grow from within - it’s a lie

- Very low pay, 40-60% lower than industry. If you ask them they will ask you to just walk especially if you need visa sponsorship

- Loads training available but if you take them it will impact your chargeability and hence your performance. Its a joke.

- no knowledge/support function compared to MBB. Every project feels like it’s the first time ACN doing it you have to start from scratch. You will be left in the wild Wild West with no support

Sometime I feel that Accenture is too big for itself with over 500,000 employees. Its all about being on project, relevant or not, based on your career or not just be chargeable.

headline: Good place to learn but low salary
pros: Efforts made from management on personal development and upskilling but the experience varies greatly from project to project. Lots of fluffy perks and the people are generally nice and engaged. If you are lucky you land on managers that are focused on cultivating talents and that accelerates your learning.
cons: You can go backwards in terms of responsibility if you shift to a new project where nobody knows you and need to start all over. It's best to stick to an account/project for growth but it defeats the purpose of joining consulting to be exposed to a variety of industry. Salaries are also very low at analyst and consultant level, particularly for the level or responsibility and working hours.

headline: Great for developing, not so great for progressing
pros:
- Wide variety of projects
- Lots of opportunities to learn and develop your skills
- Everyone is usually very helpful
- Lots of opportunities for exposure and taking on responsibility
- Lots of researching being done to improve QoL of employees, although not always reflected in changes.
cons:
- Some changes are not really thought out and are often aimed at benefiting new hires, instead of current employees.
- Some roles simply dont give you enough exposure to senior management, which makes it extremely difficult to get promoted.
- The "competitive" pay is still not on par with some of the competition.
- A lot of politics and whilst a lot of senior personnel is very welcoming and helpful, some are outright patronizing.
- HR requests are very slow.

headline: A tangle of bureaucracy
pros:
Working from home
Friendly colleagues
Average perks & health package
Great work life balance
cons:
If you work in a creative role - forget about being able to do your job the way the rest of the industry does, the Accenture processes will put a stop to that.

Regular mandatory time consuming technical tests and 'training' that has nothing to do with your job.

I'm sure it's great for someone who's into processes, admin & the technical side of things but it's not an atmosphere for anyone creative.

headline: Terrible place to work
pros: Not many pros to report
cons:
If you work here, be prepared for a wave of bureaucracy around every single internal process imaginable.

The terrible mandatory ‘training’ you have to do that everyone just flicks through without actually reading

As an apprentice you get absolutely minimal respect from both the apprentice team and the people on your project 

The company pretends to care about its employees but when I was suffering from mental health issues and had to take sick leave, upon my return I was met with a barrage of abuse from the apprentice lead for newcastle saying I can’t take a single day off or do a single thing wrong or I’ll be fired on the spot and criticising me for needing time off

If you file a complaint with HR, expect it to come back to bite you

Unfair performance reviews

No recognition for anyone except boot lickers to senior people within the newcastle management team

Terrible pay for the amount you do

Sub par holiday allowance

All the benefits that were good have now been taken away

Very little opportunity for progression

Toxic work culture and a cut throat environment with people fighting for scraps - this isn’t the 1990’s, shouldn’t be this way anymore

No real sense of being part of a team

headline: Great company with room for improvement

cons: During covid workload is crazy with no team moral or company rewards. At a leadership level initatives like 'no meeting Friday's after midday' are created but never implemented at the project level. Promotion opportunites are not often and generally and based on time at level

headline: Hard to beat

Good pay and market leading benefits package. Potential for quick and meritocratic progress if you show strong performance. Fantastic and almost limitless training opportunities (internal and external).

Market leading focus on diversity and equal
opportunities.
cons:
Expect to work hard if you want to do well. Semi-regular late nights are expected.

Experience differs greatly depending on the practice / area of the business you work in - high degree of networking required to chart your own path

headline: Large company with opportunity to grow
pros: Global company that you have opportunities to determine your career path. In non-covid times you get good global training in chicago.
cons:
A positive is you get to work with many different teams, including managers. Sometimes that means you get stuck with a manager or leader that does not gel with you. But the positive side is you can often find a way to put yourself into another team for the next project. I'm referencing Strategy and Consulting work in particular
One big con is the promotion cycle which is not very transparent.

headline: Excellent, but highly political/corporate
pros:
- Opportunity to work for big tech companies and learn from their amazing people
- Accenture people are often great to work with
- Amazing place to begin your career in tech
cons:
- No guarantee you’ll find a good project
- Low salary for the amount of work you do and hours you put in (below career level 9). Infrequently rewarded
- Highly political, you will not progress upwards through merit or work ethic alone — networking and making the right connections is essential
- Sometimes poor employee treatment. Laid off 9% UK workforce mentioning everyone was in scope for redundancy, 1 or 2 months later ACN were on a huge recruitment drive — all while stating employee mental health is top priority…

headline: Friendly but Hardworking Environment
pros:
Friendly Colleagues
Company Benefits are really good, with discounts on all Accor hotels worldwide and 2 free 2 night stays at any UK hotel.
Free use of the gym and spa.
Management is very friendly and focus on your satisfaction at work whilst continuously monitoring your performance with various assessments.
Monthly Staff meeting, very motivating.
Free travel to and from work.
Rather Flexible shifts. Employee caring company.
cons:
With most hotels, disputes between departments are very common.
A lot of different customers, means a lot of rude people.
Tips can be unfairly shared.
Work load can be too intense sometimes.
Amount of customers can be unpredictable leading to a constant change of the weekly rota.

headline: CHAOTIC
pros: Accor's name on your resume, I guess.
cons: Everything at this Novotel was wrong: clients complain about the same things not working in their rooms, front desk staff has to work unpaid overtime on a daily basis and things always go wrong. How could they? Every single department in this hotel is understaffed, everybody works for 3 people and mistakes are bound to be made... by the hour. Clients are checked into already occupied rooms or rooms that haven't even been cleaned, reservations repeatedly get lost and unprocessed and others duplicated. Housekeeping hands out the wrong rooms for the front desk to assign and the restaurant charges the wrong clients for someone else's bills. I swear I'm not making this up.

headline: An OK experience overall, did work in 2 different hotel branches in 2 different countries.

cons: Ibis and its concept of giving an unreasonable workload to one person at a time at the customer service's expense(Night auditors in particular), as a matter of fact, when working nightime with no security one person is expected to deal with the reception(calls, reservations, check in and outs and all) AND the bar(at least it works that way for a lot of Ibis in the UK). Little to no care whatsoever for staff security on night shifts, they will tell you they do care, but really they don't.

headline: Good place to start a career in Hospitality
pros:
great relationship with your colleagues and multicultural staff where everyone is treated equally no matter your race, age, religion, etc,...
really good benefits as it is a big company with hotels all over the world, you will be able to stay in different hotels at a reasonable rate because of their discounts and free nights in the UK
cons: Salaries are below average but you get bonuses at the end of the year which is usually an 8% of your annual salary.

headline: Company for first step workers without experience
pros:
Good for unskilled people who want to step in the hospitality world.
Good for learning up to supervisor / team leader level for example.
Good team spirit and culture, working in Accor is like working in a family atmosphere.
Employees are likely to become multiskilled, it makes them more productive to compare with the competitors' s employees.
Holidays increase 1 day per year up to 25 days
Moving through the network is easy and give more opportunities to learn different methods of work.
cons:
Employees need to be flexible taking responsibilities without limit.
Lack of modern tools (IT development is slow and late), the Softwares and tools provided could be more developed.
Staff cost cutting is too much.

headline: Best hotel group, but overrated employer
pros: Large group and variety of opportunities, group still growing. Reputation, consistent focus on quality of service. Some really great people to work with. Belief in others potential and if you get your head down you can grow. If you are wanting a career in Hospitality in Asia Pacific, this is the group to work for.
cons:
Politics on top level. Some senior, well established people who can get away with murder. 

High tolerance for bad habits and pure laziness when it comes to management, as long as they are well liked by the top level (if not related to financial performance, service and not stepping on toes of someone more senior, it just goes on unadressed)

Low pay, below competitors, and slim  manpower. Read work more and get paid less.

Little money spent in innovation. Old school in many things.

Get the potential wrong a lot if times to stick with personality likes (the wrong types above who wing along but can talk. even if everyone knows, no one seem to do anything).

headline: Front Office Team member -Ibis
pros: No experience is needed to get the position, which is good if you are planning to start your career in hospitality. Flexible hours that can fit around your other arrangements.
cons: I have been working for the company for 2 years and what looked like a great opportunity at  the beginning was a big disappointment. There is absolutely no consideration of staff safety. You will often be left alone with a full hotel of guests that are aggressive and abusive. There is no training, duty managers or security provided, and managers do not want to hear about the issues as their main priority is cutting costs. Managers often violates health and safety or working hours regulations in order to meet the targets.

headline: Company cares about financial results only

headline: More good than bad
pros: Accor has great learning & development initiatives - training (virtual, classroom or on-the-job) is available for every employee who is willing to learn. Hard work and the drive to go further can earn you a promotion. There are talent development programs for every employee level. International mobility is available when opportunities are present. As a hospitality company, the employees are also treated well and there is a great culture throughout the group.
cons: Too much politics going on at the corporate level which could affect the teams and employee engagement/satisfaction.

As well as getting the balance with my personal wish as becoming one of the best and successful women leaders of my kind.

This is something employees do through their own network in the company and while it allows you to try many things, this can limit longer term growth opportunities. Also compensation in terms of salary is below industry averages across the board.

headline: Unprofessional Management
pros: Friendly colleagues; approachable, yet unprofessional managers.
cons: Hotel Management tends to think of themselves only, and doesn't invest on staff development. My experience with lower management was that of unprofessional, rude, sexist, confrontational, selfish and petty behaviour. They go to whatever lengths necessary to cut on costs, which includes having interns working for free and cutting down on hours that part-timers and 0-hour contract workers desperately need. Minimum wage and very little room for career progression.

headline: The Menzies Hotel, Sydney - One of the best...
pros:
Very supportive managers.
Fun environment.
Good recruitment policies leading to people who fit the culture and keep things positive all the time.
Very good policies for development of staff as well as being flexible.
cons: Can't think of any. I worked there part time for 1.5 years and it was the most relaxed and fun job I have done. I was part of the F&B team. We were given a lot of autonomy for such a job, our dress code was fun as well. The managers were great at being flexible with my roster - they understood that most of us were Uni students and that was a big priority. They did not ever spitefully cut back shifts just because our availability was less due to uni schedule. This had happened to me in another workplace and it can be very stressful. Infact, I was sad to leave that place even though I was stepping into my real career.

headline: International Sales Consultant

cons: The Sales department is the worse, lack of true leadership, to many people that believe they're more important than they actually are. Lots of gossiping like high school from both male and female. Hard to there is any "true leadership", when management in the department plays favoritism  and partakes in the gossiping. The company has no true training program, and lacks any type of "real" growth opportunity. Last thing  I would say is, anyone with any type of ambition will loathe this position. They will sell you it and make it sound real important and has a fancy title, but all you really are is an assistant. They give you all the work that they are to lazy to do.

headline: Good experience. Good people.
pros:
I used to work in Ibis London City for 9 months as a F&B team member.
Definitely good experience, people come from all over the world, friendly enviroment and customer service. Good training an possibilities to grow up.
Good benefits, staff food and laundry included, but they pay the minimum wage which is not good, especially if you are living in London.
Of course it is hospitality so you will work hard, but for sure you will also have fun.
cons: Management sometimes is really messy, reception is really busy and underpressure, f&b usually short staff. Really hard job.

My contract was stating "you are required to do the amount of hours needed to run the business efficiently" which means it all. Whenever I was making a 7.5 hours days I felt guilty about it.

headline: Working for Accor in the UK
pros: Accor is a very successful and profitable business in the UK. The training you receive is very good and there are opportunities to progress within the network of hotels both in the UK and overseas.
cons: Having said that Accor is very successful most front line employees are paid at the minimum wage and many are on zero hours contracts. This suits many employees particularly students but sometimes staff (particularly in the Restaurant) are sent home early if there are few customers which seems a bit unfair if you have been told your shift would go on for longer and you don't get paid for the extra hours.

headline: GSA Multiple hotels
pros: Global chain, easy relocation opportunities. some great staff. Good independence working encouraged to self operate.
cons:
Every hotel its its own kingdom run differently with different cultures. 

Owners have no real reason to spend money as each hotel is individually owned so they wont benefit from the increase in brand reputation, this results in many run down hotel rooms and facilities. 

Accor prides itself on running hotels cheaper, often at the expense of guest and staff experience, prepare to spend your life apologizing for the owners decision to not upgrade the 15 year old rooms etc. 

Many times  I've seen a promotion offered internally, only for the staff to be told that we no longer require it as a "manager position" etc so it will be the same job just no salary increase. Leaving the staff member with an increased work load but no salary increase or even title recognition, lost a few good staff this way.

headline: Not bad, though could do with some organisation
pros: Very friendly/laid back atmosphere in my department (kitchen), met a LOT of new people over my two years there, subsided NVQ training, (mostly) cooperative, learned a lot
cons:
Salary - I was there two years and given increasingly demanding tasks/responsibility and was never on more than minimum wage. Worked on average an hour overtime each day (longest was three hours) and never got paid extra. Towards the end had my hours cut so I didn't even have enough time to do my day's work, and then got complained to for not having it done (???)

Some staff have a superiority complex and think it's OK to watch you struggle because you're lowest on the rung. Managers do nothing to help.

Never enough staff organisation on busy nights, constantly overworked. Saw multiple housekeepers/KPs who didn't speak a word of English, so communication issues abundant.
Also had an issue with one of the staff stealing money from the cloakrooms which was never dealt with.

Quite a hypocritical environment in the kitchen, though still prefer it to being front-of-house.

headline: Tele Sales
pros: In the first week of training you get to play games, have fun and it is a really positive environment. The employees are really nice and the hours are flexible.
cons: There is sooo much wrong with the company. Firstly the positive environment vanishes within the first few weeks and you realize it was all fake. Secondly they said we could get all the training we needed but I feel they don't teach you enough. Thirdly you need to be really pushy and have really thick skin to be able to sell and do well. While I was there in a month and a half they hired 30 people so the turn over rate is very high which is to be expected with this type of job but I gave it a shot anyway. Also trying to sell to people who don't want/wont use the membership is hard.

headline: Managers will throw you under the bus

cons: Managers will not hesitate to throw you under the bus to protect themselves. There is no team spirit. Managers do not defend their team members. No gratitude towards hard working people. Many years working for this company and I left because of harassment. Nothing in writing so I could not bring it to court. But it almost cost me my sanity. The way Managers can talk in front of you amd back stabb you or their team to be sure to get the position they want is very common in this company. I would not recommend anyone to work for the head office of Accorhotels UK and Ireland

headline: As a hotel level manager, you will spend all your time there
pros: Free meals, some ok benefits
cons: Poor pay, no overtime and you will be working 50-60+ hours per week will consecutive 15 hour days at weekends, always on your feet. Management are not supportive and always looking to cut casual hours at your expense. Very little progression unless someone leaves and you are the only candidate. You are also contacted frequently on your days off/holidays meaning that you can never really switch off.

headline: Worst Employer ever
pros: I wish there had been some
cons:
These people were shoddy : worked there a few weeks before I was threatened with cut hours 1 to 1 in managers office. I checked and other employees who had made less bookings were not subjected to the same making it a clear case of bullying.
Training was totally sketchy with management making it clear to me they were really too busy with other people to bother.
I found another job I now enjoy after that but I think the worst thing was the lack of organisation in the company - work was not logically explained and people were wandering around the office daily looking for missing headphones and computer parts ! Seriously ? Not cool.

Not a fan of Robina HQ either it’s a depressing place to work ....!

headline: STAY AWAY - Unhealthy Environment, In-Fighting, Siloed, 50%+  contractors
pros: Large corporation with lots of potential.
cons: Two-faced staunchy "old boy's club" management protecting their siloed jobs (I was in management so I saw the politics first-hand) destructively and overtly aggressive, screaming in meetings, bullying and alienating new employees brought in with more relevant modern skills and experience than their own out of "turf wars".  Management coming from the USA have no idea how things work in France and have no guts or integrity to fix things. More than 50% of the employees are currently contractors...that is another major problem...the contractors have no vested interest other than continuing to get a paycheque. They promise the world, great environment, etc., and deliver nothing but the opposite. Sick environment. Stay away.

cons: Work/life balance could be better but is not below average to any other hotel company. Accor is making huge gains on this front and puts its employees as the centre of everything the company stands for.

headline: Fantastic Hospitality Group
pros: Accor invests in their employees and are dedicated to training staff on understand how people want to be made to feel. They offer the same respect to the people who work for them.
cons: I was on a work/holiday visa and had to return to my home country.

headline: Understaffed and Overworked
pros:
Free food (but not that many options) 
Free stays all over the UK 
Discounts Worldwide
cons:
The position is called Multitask Receptionist because you are supposed to cover reception (where there is no reception desk), bar and restaurant, so you work reception and F&B. 
For the time I worked there they were always understaffed, there is too much pressure on employees, lack of training and high expectations. 
The shifts are constantly changing, you can't have a balance or social life, although some people got special treatment and all the days off/holidays they wanted. 
There is a lack of communication, teamwork, and appreciation. They expect everything from you and don't teach you enough. There is the staff who have been there for 5 years who don't know basic things and are still learning. If you wanted to know how to do something you had to ask, and everyone is very reluctant to help you. The managers aren't there so you have lots of responsibilities and have to fix problems without knowing how to. This is visible to the guests, who are constantly disappointed. 
It seems like ACCOR is a great company but the values are not being expressed in this hotel.
